I have wanted to play the Arkham games for ages now and started with Asylum.
There were few issues while starting up and with the audio, but there are plenty of community guides that helped me fix them.

The game itself if amazing and I'm going to be shocked if the others are better than this. Arkham Asylum itself is interesting to explore with incredible atmosphere and well designed areas if the map. You are free to experiment in combat encounters, which are not overly complex but enjoyable, with the numerous batman gadgets you unlock. The writing so far is amazing, with tons of the best batman villains incorporated really well given the Asylum setting and some of the best voice acting I've heard in video games. R.I.P Kevin.

On top of all this, the fact the game was released in 2009 is insane as it holds up incredibly 15 years later!
I'm so glad that I can highly recommend this game because I have been looking forward to playing them for ages. Definitely pick this game up, especially if its on sale!
 I already can't wait to try the rest now!
Great love letter to the Batman franchise. I've completed it twice in the past as well, but something always leaves me coming back for more.

I just finished the end of the story and I have to say that this game is great, even if the game is sometimes repetitive in level design or repetitiveness of boss fights. These problems are to be expected, considering that Batman Arkham Asylum is the first title in the series and was released in 2009. I like the number of boss fights in this game because it manages to go through the story nicely and it's not like it's clearly going to a boss fight. Unfortunately there is nothing much to get excited about in the final boss fight, it's constantly the same and boring, the game has gorgeous graphics for 2009 and portrays the darkness beautifully.

At least we could load into Arkham Asylum. Rocksteady's spectacular and hyperdetailed setting is still great today. It is effectively grim and atmospheric. The place isn't static, it is vandalised ober the course of your playtime. I don't konw if Arkham Asylum is the best game in the seriesâ€”the refined controls and increased scale of City and Knight are hard to ignoreâ€”but thereâ€™s something I really like about the more focused structure of Rocksteadyâ€™s first attempt at bringing the Batman universe to life. The story and characters are really fleshed out. The combat with it's freeflow approach is still challening to keep up your combo. Overall it packs some truly fun gameplay elements and has fanatastic voice talent. Rocksteady nailed what Batman is supposed to feel like. Custscenes could be of a better visual quality and Riddler is still annyoning, but in my opinion this are the only flaws which are itching me.

This is a fantastic game.

Everything from the visuals to the audio to the dialogue are all excellent. The performances of the two leads are fantastic, the story and ambiance are very good, and perhaps most notably, the combat system is a lot of fun.

This game is right up there with the original Gears of War and Resident Evil 4 as one of the most innovative games of the 2000s. It introduces so many clever gameplay mechanics, the combat has depth to it (later emulated in the excellent Sleeping Dogs), and it's just a fun game. The use of gadgets is also pretty fun, although there are so many of them, and some I never used.

You can see just how much effort went into every aspect of Arkham Asylum, with the art design and even with all the character bios and audio tapes. It's just a really impressive game. And the Riddler secrets are actually fun enough that I went through and collected all 240 of them.

I also appreciate the game's length. You can probably power through the story in 12 hours, but it's realistically a 15-20 hour game for most people, which is a good length for this. It doesn't overstay its welcome.

The one major criticism I have is the level design. It looks beautiful (especially for a 14 year old game), but some of the levels are mazes that can be a real pain to traverse, especially after you've finished the story and are going back for the Riddler secrets. Finding all the sealed doors and remembering all the alternate paths to get around the Caves and the Medical Facility can be a real annoyance.

Also, while I enjoy the Detective Mode mechanic, sometimes I felt the game wanted you to use it too much, which caused a FOMO because it masks the game's excellent visuals and art design.

All in all, this game is a classic. I'm giving it a 90%, but I would have given it a 95% if it had not been for the maze-like level design.

Highly recommended.

[h1]Why didn't Man take Jonkler to court?  Is he stupid?[/h1]
[i](Disclaimer:  I'm no stranger to the Arkham series up until Knight, having plugged in time on a PS3 prior to this review - Please don't take my time here as gospel!)[/i]

Batman: Arkham.  Hoo, boy.  Rocksteady, fellas, [b]what happened to you?[/b]  Well, here goes nothing I guess.

In this game, we play as esteemed hero Man, taking his arch-enemy, the Jonkler, to Arkham Aslume for treatment.  The problem is, Jonkler jonked himself loose in a take-over of the entire facility, and I'm cutting those stupid memes out going forth.  Long story short; Joker has broken out of DC's least secure prison, taken the entire place over, and it's up to you to put an end to his plans before he does as Joker does best.

From there, the madhouse embodies that term as literally as possible, with Batman having to face down rogue after rogue in a story that feels like it could be lifted straight from the comics.

Gameplay-wise, well let's just say there's a [i]reason[/i] that 'Arkham-esqe' became a standard for open world combat, and that this series is why.  Your combat is free-flowing, as enemies begin working up the nerve to hit the friggin' Bat.  What can begin as rough-hewn combos consisting of basic attacks strung together can become a ballet of dodges, counters, attacks, gadgets, and finishing moves all strewn together near-seamlessly.  Getting into the system is easy enough - It's mastery where the challenge lies.

There's also stealthy 'predator' sections, where you're against gun-toting enemies, who can shred you to Bat-paste within moments and forces you to consider your stealthy options instead, from using gargoyles to your advantage, to stealth ambushes, to using your gadgets in conjunction to better control crowds.

When you aren't introducing the cowardly, superstitious lot to your fists, you're exploring the island via running, jumping, sliding, gliding, grappling, and using your gadgets as exploration devices.  Your Batarangs might be good in combat to soften someone up, but they can also remotely trigger switches, for instance.  The Batclaw can be used to quickly grab enemies, sure, but it can also yank out vent covers.  Explosive Gel can be used to detonate weak walls just as easily as it can be used to knock your foes unsteady, provided you have the mythical [b]prep time[/b] that Batman can use to become Bat-God.  The standout feature of puzzle-solving is 'Detective Mode', which shades the world in blue and highlights elements of puzzles, lights enemies up like Christmas trees, and helps you realize how much you miss color.

Speaking of; Game's muted in color.  Now, this is very old hardware we're talking about here - By this point, I'm pretty sure any PC can run Arkham by now, to say nothing of dedicated gaming rigs - And yeah, I can't and won't judge the experience's graphics on pure fidelity.  When you are talking about a game that released almost fifteen years ago, you kind of need to give it's graphical fidelity some slack.  What I will say is that in terms of the spirit of DC Comics, this game captures it.  Rocksteady evidently got into the comics and read a fair few Arkham-related stories, and used those stories to shape their take on the iconic island and the rogues gallery.

No multiplayer.  No problem.

In terms of replay value, Arkham generally doesn't have much in the main game - Most of the replayability is sequestered into it's challenge modes, small gauntlets and challenges laden with enemies for you to fight, perfect for training yourself or simply having a little more fun with the game.

Would I recommend Man: Arkham Aslume?  I would, yeah.  It still holds up nearly 15 years later as being one of the best Batman games released, one of the best DC games ever released, and kickstarted a series that only escalated and, for the most part, only got better with every installment.

A fun and classic game from the Seventh generation of gaming. I really enjoy the way the asylum slowly open ups as you explore more and as you continue the story more. This is still my favorite batman game. And I think it holds up pretty well 15 years later. The detective mode that allows you to see enemies through walls is really well used in this game. The fact that it has 4k resolution support is really nice. (Though the subtitle text is a little small).

Though it definitely has some rough parts. The final boss is a bit of a letdown, and some of the other sections can get a bit tedious, especially any of the parts that result in an instant failure. But overall this is still a ton of fun. Took me only around 7 hours to beat. Granted I have played through this game before, but is has been a few years. So a more casual play through make take a bit longer.

Considering what Suicide Squad did to Bats, I will be replaying this game. This game is still enjoyable after 14 years. When Arkham Collection is on discount, I can highly recommend it and play them all. Arkham Asylum has only two missable Steam achievements so pay attention to those!

As for Suicide Squad? I'll just pretend it never happened.

The start of a genre defining game series. Batman Arkham Asylum give its players an immersive adventure into an action-packed, gritty, chaotic night of the caped crusader's life. The story of this game is simple but bursting with exciting turns. Batman is locked inside the Arkham Asylum, the iconic correctional facility for criminally insane near-do-wells. Loose inside the asylum are a large number of Batman's iconic villains, each with their own dastardly plans for Gotham City and the Dark Knight. Batman must fight for his life and city trapped with the hulking Bane, the bewitching Poison Ivy, the mind bending Scarecrow, and Joker, the mastermind behind the entire jailbreak.

The combat is rudimentary in comparison to its immediate predecessor Arkham City. I had played Arkham City before Asylum, and could feel the immediate difference. Asylum's Batman is slower, heavier, but still maintains a fair amount of variety that leaves players with options. Asylum's enemies also have their iconic horde variety; with armoured opponents, armed opponents, titanic opponents, and of course sheer numbers.

The boss battles of Batman are underwhelming. The simple use of one or two gadgets to stun them followed by mashing the attack button, leaving these villains looking like insidious and dangerous maniacs, and more like inhabitants of a Zelda dungeon. This simple boss design is supplementary by minion combat, which is the far more engaging experience, and does increase the difficulty and overall enjoyment of the boss fights. This does not negate the issue of boss battles however.

The predator combat system is a unique experience, similar to the likes of Assassin's Creed or Dishonoured. Using cover, grates, and gargoyles, you survey hostile environments, pick your targets, and can choose to silently take them out, or go loud and draw attention to a certain spot as you disappear back into the shadows. The dialogue of minions as you pick them off one by one is a great rush, as you truly feel yourself acting the part of a legend that crime fears.

But whilst the rush of swiftly taking out armed thugs is exhilarating, the threat of retaliation is very real. The damage dealt by armed enemies, makes the need for stealth and quick take downs very clear. The Batman might be a legend that criminals cower from, but beneath the mask, there truly is a man. And behind the controller is a player. This game does an excellent job of punishing mistakes in both combat and predator encounters. As the damage dealt by a goon with bat, breaks your combo (and flow) and the damage of guns is just as frightening. You need to play smart, careful, and quick, which makes every aspect of combat incredibly engaging.

The Asylum is not just a single building, but an entire island of facilities that contribute to the incarceration and attempting healing of Gotham's lunatics. Batman's traversal options, allow you to cover the island grounds with ease, however the interior level designs leave little in the way of shortcuts, which make backtracking for collectables and certain missions slightly irritating. Similarly the exterior is segmented into three section, none of which are particularly large, which leaves very little excitement after an initial playthrough. 

This is a rather minor flaw however, as this adventure is designed to be entirely linear to experience. There are no side missions in Arkham Asylum, unlike its sequels. Riddler provides the only side content to the game's story mode, through riddles, trophies, and the secrets of Amodeus Arkham. Completing Riddler's challenges certainly isn't a neccessity, but it the resulting lore bits and defeat of enigmatic egomaniac are satisfying enough to reccomend taking it on.

Outside of the story and the Asylum are the challenges. Timed encounters that test your skill in combat mode and creativity in predator mode. Unlocking three medals in each challenge is a rewarding experience and a great way to hone your skills outside of the story if you feel like challenging yourself with higher difficulty enemies.

As said at the beginning, Batman Arkham Asylum was the start of a genre defining series. It has all the hard edges and clunky starts of most gaming innovations, but its adventure is action packed, its characters engaging, its challenges are rewarding to accomplish, and you come away truly feeling like the Batman.

Iâ€™m not big on super heroes, but Spider-Man is awesome.  I know this is a Batman game, but hear me out.  I got back into achievement hunting after earning a platinum trophy on my PS4 in Spider-Man.  Shortly before finishing that game, we took on a roommate who is a Batman guy.  I came in from work one day while he was playing one of the Arkham games (I donâ€™t recall which) and we chatted about what he was doing as he was doing it.  I said, â€œso this is basically Batmanâ€™s version of Spider-Manâ€™s game?â€  He said they werenâ€™t quite the same, but theyâ€™re similar enough I might enjoy it.  Now again, Iâ€™m not really into super heroes, but Batman is the coolest of the DC bunch.  The Arkham series wasnâ€™t on my radar before this moment, but it was afterward.

The controls make sense, but they arenâ€™t intuitive for someone whose favorite games include Spider-Man and the Yakuza series.  I really struggled with combat for the first several hours.  Something finally clicked, and I can string together 30-hit combos fairly consistently, but I absolutely lucked into the combo where I managed to string together a 57-move combo using all of Batmanâ€™s moves.  Iâ€™m mad that Iâ€™ll probably never repeat that feat again.  The key here is patienceâ€”Batman doesnâ€™t like to be rushed.  What billionaire does?  I used a DualShock 4 to play this one, like always.  I also have a PS4 copy of the game, and I got my feet wet with that.  If I had to guess, it took me around 35 hours between the two versions for that click with combat.  (7/10)

Graphics are good.  Iâ€™ll admit the remaster on PS4 is much better, but the original version is solid.  I think this game is much nicer to look at than several others of the era, such as Assassinâ€™s Creed or Dishonored.  The Steam port retains the original graphics.  Some areas were incredibly dark, but not impossible to complete.  I tend to spend a lot of time in detective mode, so switching back and forth can be disorienting sometimes.  Itâ€™s not so bad that I couldnâ€™t handle it, and I donâ€™t consider it detrimental to the experience.  (7/10)

Usually, music is one of my favorite parts of a game.  With this game, itâ€™s good, but it doesnâ€™t always have the oomph I need.  The little melodies interlaced throughout Arkham Island are interesting and very Batman-esque, but I feel like more could be done.  The sound effects on the other hand, are robust.  The wind whipping off Batmanâ€™s cape as he glides is easily one of my favorite instances in the game of immersion. (7/10)

I once wondered in my review of Lego Batman: The Videogame why all these villains were running amok in Gotham City.  Arkham Asylum shows you the why right off the Bat (hehe).  Joker is painted to be the absolutely diabolical mastermind he deserves to be, and itâ€™s incredibly compelling.  I loved seeing enemies Iâ€™m not familiar with, such as Killer Croc, and a few fan favorites make a return, like Poison Ivy.  The little character biographies were a cool touch, and finding the interview tapes scattered across the island gave more insight into the plot.  Rounding all this out, I still wish to know more about Amadeus Arkham, and I hope more mystery surrounding him is available to unravel in the later installments of the series.  (10/10)

Finally, the extra content in the form of challenges was interesting to explore and sharpen skills with.  I did well with the stealth challenges initially, but Iâ€™m not sure finishing hard mode wouldâ€™ve been doable for me without that extra practice.  Also, screw Shock and Awe.  I never want to play that one again.  (8/10)

Overall, this game helped me better appreciate the character that is Batman, and I can connect more with the love for the character my husband and sons have.  I will definitely play the later games in the series, and I may rewatch the animated series with my older son to get a better feel for certain characters.  Walking into the game with only a passing interest in Batman and walking away with an increased appreciation is enough for me to absolutely recommend the game.  (8/10)

This is a Metroidvania game from the 360/PS3 era. It's aged incredibly well. The main criticisms people have are the combat can be a bit dull, though at the time it was a new type of content. The atmosphere, and voice acting are top notch. The story is fun, and graphically it's still amazing looking. My main criticisms are the fact the port has some issues that aren't fixed. It won't run in full screen on my PC, has to be played in Windowed. On Steam deck, you have to install the latest version of Proton, it won't run naively, has be Proton 8.3 +. Sometimes it does have some artifacting as well when you start it up, but restarting the game fixes it. (This is not just my machines, this is a common bug you can find footage of) If you can get past these things you'll have a great time with it. My main criticisms with the actual gameplay, are that it doesn't have a mini map, but this is more immersive. Granted, with a metroidvania it gets hard to find your way without pausing in some areas, due to the fact there are a lot of winding corridors. Main story you won't get lost, but for finding collectibles you'll have to check the map a lot. There is a tool you use where you have to mash a button/key a lot before it works, this part hasn't aged well either. But those small blemishes aside I fully recommend this game to Batman, Comic book, or Metroidvania fans.

A fantastic game that I thoroughly recommend to any fan of Batman or action games.

The story is functional and quite engaging, with comedy, mystery, and elements of horror. The side mystery of the Spirit of Arkham is worth the time completing for the story it tells through the audio logs, and the riddles from the Riddler are quite engaging to solve as well.

The presentation is top notch: the graphics are fantastic for 2009, and the art direction is the perfect comic book blend of over the top accents on a grounded setting. The music is fitting for all situations, and every character is a visual treat: Joker, Batman, Harley, Scarecrow, Poison Ivy, even the generic henchmen look idealized physically. 

The gadgets are quite good for the most part. I found the sonic Batarang to rarely be useful, but every other tool felt uniquely qualified for different combat and traversal challenges.

I have one major gripe: the invisible "lock-on" system that the game uses during combat. Due to the game not having a clear indicator of which enemy you are latched on to, you can press the parry button when an enemy is trying to attack you, and instead of parrying the enemy, you parry thin air, then take damage. This is a rare occurrence, but happened often enough for me to notice and for it to bother me. Unfortunately, this effect is exaggerated in the game's two spectacle boss fights. The camera is moved to a mostly static position at the back of the arena, and enemies are spawned in. For some reason, the lock on seems very unreliable for beginning targeting an enemy or for switching enemies in these two encounters. My final other gripe is the inconsistency of immunity when using the "Instant Takedown" upgrades when in encounters with Titan Henchmen. When using an "Instant Takedown" in normal Henchmen combat, the other Henchmen wait for the take-down animation to complete before attacking you, incentivizing the player to keep their combo meter going so that they can continue to use the "Instant Takedown." However, when a group of Henchmen is accompanied by a Titan Henchman, the Titan Henchman isn't given the same AI change when "Instant Takedown" is used, meaning that in mixed fights, it is actually more dangerous to use an "Instant Takedown" than to run in circles around the arena until the Titan Henchman charges, allowing for you manage the fight. It simply leads to a greater feeling of tedium.

Overall, however, this is a fantastic game. Challenge maps are not my thing, but there are plenty in this game, and if they are at the same level of quality as the base game, I imagine they are fantastic if that is your thing! I recommend this game whole-heartedly.

[h1]Setting a standard for superhero games that still holds up today[/h1]
It's been over a decade since this game released yet it only feels like it came out three years ago, it's [i]that[/i] good. The graphics are amazing for a 2009 release and still looks great now, but graphics aren't much if the game itself isn't very fun.

Fortunately, it is. The combat system is an excellent example of easy to learn, hard to master while rewarding players that master how they work as higher combo chains grant extra XP you can use to unlock upgrades. You cannot just button mash through this game so some element of skill is required, but you don't need every single combat skill to finish it either. Dodge rolls were especially helpful when dealing with large crowds of enemies at once.

This game came out during a time where Quick Time Events (QTEs) were a very common inclusion in a lot of other games, which was something I've never liked as they either break immersion during cutscenes or over-simplify what could've been fun action set-pieces during gameplay. Fortunately, Batman Arkham Asylum does not include a single QTE whatsoever which I really appreciate.

Some portions of the game require stealth to get through, usually by eliminating every single foe in the area without letting any of them see you. The detective mode allows you to easily see enemies in the area even if they're through walls or blend in with the environment, making these sections not nearly as frustrating as they would be in other games.

There's more than enough production values to make this game feel like an interactive movie at times and there is a rather lengthy walking segment at the beginning, but once you get past the prologue, there aren't many cutscenes to interfere with gameplay so it still feels like a proper video game; the story, dialogue and atmosphere is just the icing on the cake.

Batman Arkham Asylum plays like a Metroidvania of sorts. Certain collectables can only be obtained after acquiring powerups through story progression. While you don't need to explore previous areas to finish the main story, you're still encouraged to do so as you also gain extra XP by finding these secrets throughout the island.

The bosses are easily the weakest part of the game, however. The fight against Bane is decent enough; the problem is that almost every boss in the game plays out just like it so they do get a bit repetitive after a while. Even the final boss was a huge letdown compared to everything else this game does so well. Fortunately, there aren't that many bosses so it doesn't hinder my enjoyment of the game too much.

If you're tired of the main story and are looking for more stuff to do, the challenge maps will put all your stealth and combat skills to the ultimate test. Up to three medals can be earned in each one and getting them all can be quite difficult though some are also a bit frustrating. None of them are very long, but fully mastering each one can take a lot of practice. The GOTY Edition also includes all the DLC challenge maps which there's 4 of, but sadly no playable Joker which is PS3 exclusive content.

The PC port is fantastic and I would easily recommend it even to those that already played it on console. The PS3/360 versions only run at 30FPS while on PC, it can run at 60FPS if your computer can handle it. I did not run into any major issues when playing this game and it works really well with an XBOX One controller, though keyboard and mouse support exists if you don't want to use a controller.

This game felt like it was made for Batman fans as they really do feel like Batman himself as they experience the story and immerse themselves in the world they play in, almost as if the creators of this game were true Batman fans. However, this isn't just a great Batman game for fans of the series - even those who aren't Batman fans but still enjoy great action games can sit down, play and enjoy it just fine.

A very easy recommendation from me, overall. This game frequently goes on sale so you can score a great deal on this masterpiece, but even at the regular asking price, it's well worth the money and especially your time.

Batman: Arkham Asylum, was the kind of release that could be compared to the category of games like Half Life. This is to say, action "games of the year" which are put on a pedestal because of one or two new ideas they brought to the table, which later become industry standards or, if you prefer, are copied over and over. Yet, on retrospect, these games were also very half baked and inconsistent as a whole, even at the time they were originally released. Just like Batman when he was crippled by his enemy Bane, Arkham Asylum was broken in the spine by a general lack of polish, bad script and irritating voice actors. Go past the strengths of this game, and your enjoyment will largely depend on your emotional investment to the main character, and your willingness to forgive the game's faults. And no, its age is not an excuse.

The entire game is set in Arkham, a psychiatric asylum for the demented criminals in costume that Batman fights in the comics. Despite the game world being limited in scale, it has outdoor as well as indoor areas, and you can retrace your steps in order to look for all the collectables you can pick. Some of the areas have very good texture work and art, but not all... and the game tends to look older than it really is when the visuals aren't that good. But you aren't on Arkham for vacation, and all sorts of goons and costumed psychos roam free inside its walls. Luckily, combat against them is satisfying. Although simple in mechanics, requiring just the press of one button for all the fists and kicks, it still allows your bulky version of Batman to fight lots of enemies at the same time, and perform a wide array of moves and evasion acrobatics. Its not unlike the old Bruce Lee and kung-fu movies. The combat system of the Arkham series has, in fact, become the standard in modern superhero games.

However, outside its combat, the game will fail to capture your attention in the same way. The story, centered on the (very overused) Joker character of the Batman mythos, is very non sensical and resembles the "over-the-top" kind of tone from a sunday cartoon, not having much in common with the mature, dark and psychological storylines that the issues of the comic strip were known for. Only in the campiest sense, the characters and voices are well achieved. Not great, just good. That said, the Joker character (voiced by Mark Hamill) is very central to the game, and he gets the most lines of dialogue. Having to constantly listen to a Joker who, not only is very badly written but is also mocking Batman through the comm for almost the entire playthrough, becomes almost unbearable as the game goes on. Honestly I ended up hating Hamill, and enjoyed the game the most when his stupid script was on pause.

I wish that the other characters were better written too, with less camp and more grit. The villains of comicbook Batman, despite being costumed like bad guys from other superhero comics, are actually proxies for real world mental disease, evil and psychopathy. Batman is essentially different as a character, in that his stories like to pretend that they happen in its own universe with a more realistic, pulp and gritty flavor, separate from those flying heroes with super powers. His stories aren't standard superhero narratives, they can be anything and may range from slasher horror, crime fiction, detective misteries, or even the paranormal. Consistent with that, the villains in this game should probably leave a greater degree of real life feel than they do in this game. And even if we forgive this mistake, and decide to stick only with the gameplay, this aspect also has a couple of problems...

Batman has two sight modes, normal and "detective". The last one allows the player to highlight interactive items and enemies. The problem is, there is no time limitation while you're using this mode, so the temptation to leave it on for the entire game, in order to not miss anything, is high. All the colors turn blue when we turn the mode on. This means that in practice, and for most of the game, you'll see the graphics through an ugly blue filter... not to mention that a couple of areas have a very blocky, very square architecture. Not great to look at, honestly; they seem like coming straight from a Playstation 1 or 2 game. Mechanically, your character has limited moves too: you have a grapling hook, but no button to truly jump over obstacles on demand like in true platform games. You have to use the hook for everything. It doesn't feel natural, neither the animations which contribute to your character looking very stiff as it walks around. But even in terms of the challenge to the player skill, Arkham is inconsistent: it is very easy on normal difficulty. But on hard, it can be very hard. There's no middle ground. And still, the stealth sequences are always very disappointing, and dead easy, regardless of your chosen difficulty. I view this as one of the critical gameplay problems in Arkham Asylum, because if you add stealth into your game, you have to make sure its done correctly. Lousy stealth mecanics can really lower the standards of a game, and I think that's precisely what happened here.

I don't totally regret buying Arkham Asylum, because before Rocksteady, the developer, came to the scene there weren't too many games in the market using the Batman license. If we overlook its presentation and gameplay problems, Arkham Asylum can still be enjoyable at times. Enjoyable, never great. However, be warned that the hype was always high with this game, and if you pay too much attention to it, you may quit your playing in utter disappointment. Arkham Asylum is in many aspects just a normal game, a mediocre game, not worthy of being selected as GOTY back in its day. Its highest merit was to open the way to the later, and much better, games in this franchise... and also serving as inspiration to the also newer, and outstanding, "Marvel's Spider-Man"... a polish work over the Arkham formula, but truly deserving each one of the critical acclaims and the hype it got.

great game

my second batman game after Batman Arkham Origins. 
The date tells you that this is indeed the first batman game in arkham universe. Honestly, the graphics are still up to par with modern games. A satisfying combat experience for me, both exploration wise and boss wise.

Probably an important question that people may wonder: "Can i enjoy this game even though I know nothing about batman?" short answer, yes. Though this game is to make the DC fans hyped when meeting their favorite villain or characters, there really isn't any lore dumping that only fans understand. If anything, this is newcomer friendly! So don't worry about getting lost in the story, because they focus more on about the lore/story of Batman: Arkham Asylum and not the entire Batman lore!

The game isn't about combat action, there's easy puzzle, collectibles, challenges (from riddler) that makes the game isn't 100% completed just because you finished the story.

There are plenty memorable boss fight that really gets you, the hardest difficulty isn't that hard for me.


I'm personally are the type of player who wants to 100% everything, or pretty much around 90% done with the game. So really, collectibles are what gets this game hard to beat 100%.

Story building is very nice, each boss fight is unique, never repetitive.
Overall 9/10

A Batman game written by a Batman: The Animated Series writer, made by an English studio that previously only ever made a riot control FPS, and it all seems to have been the perfect combination for one of the best Batman games ever. Though there have been plenty of games based on comic book characters that are a "must-play" -- and this isn't even the first to be such -- Arkham Asylum set a new standard, and created a formula and combat/stealth system that'd influence a significant number of games to follow.

It can run a little rough on some modern hardware, but the NVIDIA PhysX are absolutely stunning in this game, especially being as early as it is with that. I had a couple crashes, and the resolution seemed to insist on not quite fitting my monitor's resolution no matter how I set it, but aside from those set-backs, the game itself still holds up. I'd played it before on PS3, and on PC it's still an amazing game with a brilliant voice-cast, and and excellent story, with a Legend of Zelda/Metroid formula of returning to places with new gadgets to get the super secret things that'll give you a little bonus XP/story.

I highly recommend this game to everyone who loves games, even if you know very little Batman lore, they've got notes to help. So give it a shot, and see for yourself how excellent a game can be.

Batman: Arkham Asylum remains a timeless gem, showcasing a masterclass in game design that has aged remarkably well. 

Its groundbreaking gameplay mechanics, particularly the fluid and intuitive combat system, set a new standard for modern third-person action games, influencing the genre for years to come. A solid story, with insanely characterful performances keep this game feeling alive throughout. 

From stealthy predator encounters to intense hand-to-hand combat, every moment makes players truly feel like the Dark Knight himself, solidifying its status as a must-play classic.

[h1]Batman: Arkham Asylum - an introduction to one of the best superhero game series[/h1]

Here is my review of Batman: Arkham Asylum.

[h2]Story[/h2]
Although it took me 18, I'm sure that the story can be beaten in about 12 to 14 hrs. As someone already said the plot of Arkham Asylum is like a typical Batman Tuesday. And I don't have much else to say. Basically Batman is trapped on the island and has to stop Joker(who's got special drugs this time) teamed up with some others classic Dark Knight's villains.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Not as rafined as in later installations, but still fairly good. Also the further you get in the story, your enemies will use new tactics or equipment to even their chances with Batman. And you can have gadgets as well - 5 obtainable through playing the main story and 3 additional, that you get from upgrades. Stealth segments are stellar, too. There is one big disadvantage to Asylum -  the lack of replayablity after you beat the game. Other than that, everything is great

[h2]Combat[/h2]
One word - smooth. The Arkham games are known for their excellent combat. And Asylum paved the way for that. The enemies are fine. It's always nice to throw some thugs and twist their arms or legs. About the bosses... They're also fine, 2 of them are amazing imo, but the final boss sucks.

[h2]Collectibles[/h2]
There are no side missions in this game, but we have 3 types of collectibles: Riddler's trophies, Arkham's chronicles and interview tapes. The last ones are propably my favorite, since they give insight to many Batman's villains.
Riddler's trophies obviously count to the Riddler's challenge, which consists of 240 tasks(or rather riddles) to complete.


TL;DR-story is your average Batman night, gameplay is great, combat is great and you have puzzles too.

With 70% completion and 133/240 riddles(as for the time of writing this review), I can say that Batman: Arkham Asylum deserves the praise it gets. It can be both challenging and tricky, but also engaging and fun. If you ask me, the game is worth it's price, but if you're still unsure, you can wait for a small discount. Overall, a solid [b]8.5/10[/b]. I definitely recommend you to play it.

The original Arkham Asylum has definitely been dwarfed by later releases, hell, it was immediately and substantively outsized by the immediate sequel.

But that's its greatest strength in my book, the story is tight and focused without a ton of side missions to distract me, the environment is detailed and haunting, and it just gets everything right in tone about the post post DKR Batman we have now.

Truthfully (aside from combat), i think it's the better game of the two (asylum and city), because it's smaller. It's definitely worth playing these days if you haven't done so before.

I remember playing Arkham Asylum not long after it came out when I was about 8, and it was one of the most insanegaming experiences I've ever had. Just turning off the lights and setting up the room with the right ambience made for an awesome playthrough. 

I recently got back into Arkham Knight and felt like replaying the whole series, something I usually avoid because I find it hard to get back into older games once I've seen better graphics, like with the 'Uncharted' series. But, this game still holds up really well. Even 15 years later, the combat feels just as good, the story still grabs you, and the graphics, while not top-notch by today's standards, are still pretty decent. It's rare for a game to not show its age, but Arkham Asylum manages it and it's still great to play.

This is still a great game, even surpassing Rocksteady's newer games, though that's not really saying much (it's saying barely anything, actually). At this point, you can sometimes see the age of the game, but it still looks, plays, and sounds better than many modern games, including a little-known game about murdering a certain group of world-renowned heroes.

Seriously, Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy both have/had amazing voices (R.I.P the Batman), along with the voices of Harley, Gordon, Riddler, and others. The gameplay is the biggest reason why I got so into it, all the actions and movements flow so well. It's a bit clunky at times, but the underlying concepts and mechanics behind it is great. And, of course, the graphics still hold up.

You [b]should[/b] play this game. 8/10

I strongly recommend Batman: Arkham Asylum. 

Even though it released all the way back in 2009 as someone's first time playing in 2022 (13 YEARS LATER) I can gladly say with full 100% confidence its still a phenomenal game. 

Both gameplay and story is like an action-packed thrill ride that holds up as the gold standard for third-person action-adventure games (at least in my opinion.)  Story isn't a total 10/10 top-tier masterpiece, more of a 9/10 comic-book tale but still satisfying from beginning to end and gameplay more than makes up for it. 

Best part of this game is without a doubt the combat, its so brutal yet flows together so well that anyone can pick up, and don't even get me started on the stealth sections! And the harder difficulties certainly push your skills to the test, which makes it even better!

All in all 10/10 certified masterpiece - This game really is incredible and deserves the praise.

You know how The Dark Knight is an awesome Batman movie that starts and just doesn't stop for 3 hours? That's this, except is a game and it's 12 hours. Absolute masterpiece.

"Batman: Arkham Asylum," developed by Rocksteady Studios and released in 2009, redefined superhero video games with its immersive gameplay, compelling narrative, and atmospheric design. Set in the iconic Arkham Asylum, players don the cape and cowl of Batman as he faces a night of chaos orchestrated by the Joker. This review evaluates "Batman: Arkham Asylum" based on its gameplay mechanics, story and character development, graphical and audio presentation, and overall entertainment value.

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Batman: Arkham Asylum" delivers a finely tuned gameplay experience that balances combat, stealth, and exploration. The FreeFlow combat system is intuitive and rewarding, allowing Batman to seamlessly engage multiple enemies with a variety of moves and gadgets. Stealth sections, featuring Batman stalking enemies from the shadows, emphasize the character's detective roots. Puzzle elements and environmental challenges utilizing Batman's gadgets further enrich the gameplay, making the player truly feel like the Dark Knight.

Story and Character Development
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The narrative of "Batman: Arkham Asylum" is engaging and faithful to the source material, weaving a dark and compelling tale that explores the psyche of both Batman and his adversaries. The game's script, penned by veteran Batman writer Paul Dini, captures the essence of the Batman mythos. Voice performances by Kevin Conroy (Batman) and Mark Hamill (Joker) bring depth to their iconic roles, enhancing the story's impact. Character development is handled with care, providing insights into the complex relationships and histories shared by the characters.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 8/10 - Good
At the time of its release, "Batman: Arkham Asylum" was praised for its detailed environments, character models, and atmospheric effects that brought the eerie Arkham Asylum to life. While some aspects of the graphics have aged, the art direction remains strong, capturing the Gothic aesthetic of Batman's world. The game's audio design, from the haunting soundtrack to the environmental sounds and voice acting, contributes significantly to the immersive experience.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Batman: Arkham Asylum" stands out as a highly entertaining game that offers a definitive Batman experience. Its blend of action, stealth, and narrative depth provides a varied and engaging gameplay experience. The game's meticulous attention to detail and respect for the source material make it a treat for fans of the Caped Crusader, while its solid mechanics ensure broad appeal.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 8.75/10 - Excellent
"Batman: Arkham Asylum" is a landmark title that set a new standard for superhero games and action-adventure titles alike. It successfully combines engaging gameplay, a compelling narrative, and atmospheric presentation to deliver an experience worthy of the Dark Knight himself. The game's influence on subsequent titles in the genre is undeniable, making it a must-play for fans of Batman and action games.

Highly Recommended for fans of Batman, action-adventure games, and those looking for a deep, immersive gaming experience. "Batman: Arkham Asylum" not only captures the essence of its titular hero but also provides a blueprint for how to adapt comic book characters to the video game medium effectively. Its legacy continues to influence the design and development of superhero games, setting a high bar for narrative and gameplay integration.

Very high quality game (despite its age), has stealth areas where the enemies aren't obnoxiously stupid and making it easy, but also has a lot of action areas (given it's batman what would you expect lol) which while there aren't a lot specific combos (it's more of mashing left click on your mouse), they're still a lot of fun and take a bit of skill to deal with. The puzzles in the game are pretty clever, but still easy enough that I'm pretty sure most people can figure them out. Overall, great game, I love Mark Hamill's joker in it, and would highly recommend for anyone looking for a good time that is worth your money.

[h1]Welcome To Arkham Asylum![/h1]
Batman: Arkham Asylum puts players into the cape and cowl of the Dark Knight himself, pitting them against a host of villains after the Joker starts a riot that takes over the titular psychiatric hospital. A Metroidvania-style action-adventure title, Arkham Asylum tasks players with locating the Joker and stopping his plans to take over Gotham City, encountering some of the Caped Crusader's most iconic allies and adversaries along the way.

        [td]The game still holds up pretty well, even by todayâ€™s standards. The gritty atmosphere of Arkham Asylum is really immersive and has an incredible level design. The attention to detail is also pretty impressive. A good example of this is that the further you get into the game, Batmanâ€™s suit gets more damaged and worn out. The graphics may not blow you away, but overall itâ€™s a solid looking game with a dark atmosphere that many will enjoy.[/td]

        [td]ðŸŽ®Gameplay[/td]
        [td]The game has many good gameplay mechanics. Hand to hand combat is the bread and butter in terms of fighting. Itâ€™s the perfect easy to learn/hard to master mechanic that keeps you wanting more and more action. Batman can move really quick while in combat as well (surprising for his size). You will get many visual prompts telling you when to counter or do a special attack. Itâ€™s really fun and I never get bored of it. Scoring a high combo without getting hit is incredibly satisfying. Batman has many gadgets to use on his foes. The batarang is one of many you can use! Through leveling up, you can increase your skill and even unlock new abilities. The leveling system felt balanced and had good pacing, not feeling grindy or annoying to go through. The stealth mechanics are fantastic. Hiding in the shadows and above to knockout your enemies and hearing their buddies' reactions is so immersive and fun! The  developers really nailed down stealth in this game. You also have many collectables and will even unlock character bios to learn more from the characters in the game. The cool thing about the characters bio, is that the game will tell you what comic book they were introduced to. A great touch for many comic fans! If I had to point out some negatives to say, it would be that the boss fights felt really lackluster and underwhelming. This was disappointing because I was really looking forward to a good fight, especially having to chase them around the asylum for a good length of time. The detective mode felt both a blessing and totally unbalanced. Now I love this feature first hand. You can scan people to see if they are alive or unconscious, use it to solve puzzles, and even has a purpose for many story sections. The problem lies that  there is no penalty to using it. Seeing enemies through walls without any penalty felt really cheesy and a oversight in game design to a degree. Yes I know I can turn it off, but there are moments I forget too because you don't get like a cooldown or any penalty for it. Most of the time you have to rely on it as well, and that takes away from enjoying the game world a bit in my opinion. Also you donâ€™t get any cool outfits to unlock. Itâ€™s not a serious thing, but it would have been cool to see some classic outfits.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ðŸ“œStory[/td]
        [td]The story was pretty solid and it does a good job at keeping you interested and invested. The game has a more adult theme to it which I can appreciate a lot and fits the tone perfectly. The villains are introduced really well and respectively so! Going through the game you will even find audio logs, giving you more background about each villain and character. Some villains may have more screen time than others (which is to be expected), but I never found it to be a negative here because the pacing was really good. You will come across many encounters and sections but feel well designed and thought out. I never really had a dull moment with the story. It had some interesting twists as well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ðŸ•›Playtime[/td]
        [td]The story is roughly around 15-20+ hours of playtime. If you are looking to get 100% and complete all challenges then you are looking at 30+ hours, maybe even more! The replayability is very minor due to the game's linear level design, but overall has a good amount of time for you to put in and have fun.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ðŸŽ§Sound[/td]
        [td]The voice acting is top tier. All of the voice actors did a perfect job and absolutely enjoyed every dialogue from the game. The prisoners even had amazing dialogue!  A big praise to both Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamil as the Joker! Total class acts and memorable performances from the two. Besides the voice acting, the music was also really fitting and I enjoyed every bit of it. Batman punching enemies in the face and hearing those massive blows always sounded so satisfying. The sound design is just incredible, and I can't find any fault in it. A fantastic job from the developers![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]â—Bugsâ—[/td]
        [td]The game was pretty bug free besides some minor issues, just pop ups and some AI being a little slow. From my experience it was pretty solid. I canâ€™t complain too much here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ðŸ”…Performance[/td]
        [td]I had zero issues with performance. Playing on Ultra settings, this game was smooth sailing for me. I had no crashes or stutters. A really well optimized game from my end. A big thumbs up from me in the performance department![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]âœ”ï¸Proâ€™s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Great optimization
[*]Amazing atmosphere
[*]Voice acting is superb
[*]Jokerâ€™s banter is great
[*]Batman design is amazing
[*]Arkham Asylum looks incredible
[*]Combat is simple but satisfying
[*]Character Bios that shows interesting traits and details
[*]Many collectables that feel rewarding and provide more lore
[*]Waynetech leveling tree allow you to improve fighting, stealth, batarang, etc
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]âŒConâ€™s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Lack of customization
[*]Disappointing boss fights
[*]Detective mode can be abused with no drawback
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ðŸ†Rating[/td]
        [td]8/10
The game is worth full price. The amount of joy you can have especially as a Batman fan is worth every penny. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ðŸ”—Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Batman: Arkham Asylum is an absolute blast in both gameplay, and storytelling. Itâ€™s not a perfect game, but if you are a fan of the Batman universe and villains then grab this game. Iâ€™m not a hardcore Batman fanatic, but I even had an absolute blast with this game. This game is the start of the famous Batman Arkhym games and I have to say, this game was a great first impression. Iâ€™m excited to try the other games out! Give this game a shot, you will most likely have an amazing experience just like I did.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h3]Pros -[/h3]  

-Good story
-Fun mix of fighting and detective work
-Liked how you could use a lot of different gear (batclaw, batarang, etc) realistically
-Nice visuals/graphics even though it's a bit older
-Great voice acting
-Get your money worth in time played

[h3]Meh -[/h3]

-Controls a bit janky/hard to maneuver sometimes
-Sometimes a bit hard to see where things are/where you should go (although eventually 
 always figured it out)
-Ending felt a bit too quick

[h3]Cons -[/h3] 

-Going for achievements can be a pain; finding the riddler's countless trophies, many of which 
 are hidden in annoying places, would not be fun.
-Not too much replayability.

[h3]Overall -[/h3]

You don't need to be a comic book or superhero fan to like this game (I'm not either of those).  It just has a great story, and it's fun to play through it.  The story itself is also not too long or short; it's just the right amount of time.  Of course, plenty of action too.  That's really it!  If you like a mix of good storytelling, physical fighting, and detective work, you will probably love playing this.

Since there's no way to change your mouse sensitivity in-game, here's how you do it.

It's in a file in your user documents, not the game directory
So for example mine is in C:\Users\[MY PC NAME]\Documents\Square Enix\Batman Arkham Asylum GOTY\BmGame\Config\bminput.ini

Open the file "bminput.ini" and near the top there will be a value for "MouseSensitivity". By default it'll be set at 30 but you can now change it to whatever you want. Be sure to save the file once your done!

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I played through the game in its entirety over the course of a long weekend after buying all the Arkham games on sale and was more than content with the opening title to the series, arguably the most limited and clunky of a series of games still vaunted over anything Rocksteady as a developer has put out in recent years. The game does a lot of work to translate over the notion of *feeling* like Batman onto the gameplay, both in terms of stealthily navigating around enemies and the brutality of hand-to-hand combat, with building combos constantly fulfilling - enough so I have intentionally wandered around and taking longer than I should have to move through spaces/levels just to pick more fights for the dopamine.

The game goes on sale for sub five dollars, and while I hate seeing Warner Brothers get more money it's hard to argue that this isn't an amazing steal for that price, and even the full pricetag of $20 feels pretty solid for the length of the game's main campaign and other challenge modes aside for addicts to the combat system like myself, who fell in love with it via Shadow of Mordor.

"Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition is the cape crusader's masterpiece. Gotham's iconic madhouse becomes an atmospheric playground, blending detective work with bone-crushing combat. The graphics are Gotham's dark beauty, and the storytelling is as intricate as the Batcave. With fluid combat moves and gadgets that'd make Q jealous, you'll feel every bit the Dark Knight. The GOTY edition packs extra punch with additional content. It's not just a game; it's a brooding journey into Batman's psyche. Whether you're a fan of the comics or a casual gamer, this is your ticket to donning the cowl and soaring through the shadows."

The game play was incredible! The combat was so fluent! A beat-em-up game where the punch/kick just flows into the next. Where countering is seemless and simple. Unfortunately, it's too simple and not exactly the most challenging game I've played. But at least it was fun!

However, this is a console port. Worst of all, a Square Enix game on PC. So as expected, it doesn't run that well in low-mid tier hardware. The recommended specs are WAY too low for this game. There NO WAY any PC from 2010 could've handled this game at maximum settings (1080p), not in this port. I couldn't even handle it at 1080p with NO settings on! 

Once I entered the room with Dr. Young, I instantly dropped down to 18fps, despite having mostly 60fps (Maximum settings, 720p) the entire time I was playing before. I'm glad I was able to refund at 2h59m!

Overall, this game is just yet another shetty console port on PC. Which was expected, given my experiences with console ports on PC and with Square Enix titles (FF14 was the only one that ran properly)

Also, I think the console peasants have a remastered version of the Arkham games?

While not the best in the series, its a really solid game. 

The Story is pretty fun and does a good job at pushing the game forward. The characters are all really entertaining and bring a lot of depth to the game. Also i have to say that the voice actors that they got for these games are just the perfect match like Kevin Conroy (RIP) has such a distinct voice and is (to me at least) the definitive voice of batman and the same has to be said about Mark Hamill as the joker. 

The Setting of Arkham asylum is really well designed with there being tons of areas that offer different tones and atmospheres that all come together to make this place feel lived in and also to show how bad of a place it is. 

Visually, its impressive how well this game holds up. Performance was a bit iffy while a good portion of the game felt smooth, there were many times where there would be stutter and kinda threw me off it a bit, however there were no bugs or glitches throughout my playtime. The art direction is really well done with it being realistic but also having this grimy look to all of it. I also have to appreciate the little details here and there such as batmans' suit deteriorating throughout the game due to events or even just the minor map details when you reach certain points of the game. 

Sound and Audio are pretty good with the soundtrack being the perfect fit of making the game feel dark but also epic. The Audio is pretty decent with a good portion of the actions such as the explosive gel and batarangs but some of the sounds when an enemy hits you or you hitting an enemy can sound and little goofy. 

In terms of gameplay, its basic but still fun. Movement feels great and suits batman very well. The combat of this game has been so influential for the right reasons but, due to what the future games do with it, its pretty average but still enjoyable. All the gadgets in this game are nice to use however you'll mainly be using the majority of these to either progress through a certain part of the game or to get riddler trophies. The riddler trophies are well spread out and feel like there's the right amount of them to collect. I like the scarecrow sections when it comes to the presentation but the gameplay itself like dodging his gaze is a bit meh and the boss fights are fine with one of them just being a copy of an enemy you will run into a lot in this game. Now there are challenge modes for this game but honestly, there isn't much reason as to go back and play this game as the 2 titles that come after it have so much more to offer and make this game feel like a one time playthrough. 

Overall, Batman Arkham Asylum is a decent experience that had a lot of influence on many game to come after it. However, even though this game is good, the sequels just go above and beyond what this game had to offer.

I like this game. I bought the trilogy for $9 I think the normal price is $60. I would never pay 60 for these games, but at $9 it's a damn good deal.

 As of writing this I've completed about 30%. So far it's not that deep. It's been mostly just running around beating up henchmen, and stealth missions, with a boss every now and then. The stealth missions and bosses are pretty engaging. It started off easy, but the difficulty is definitely ramping up, which I enjoy.

Overall, I recommend this game. I haven't played Arkham City or Arkham Knight yet, but if the trilogy goes on sell, I recommend getting it.

Legendary game.  The perfect balance, a lightning strike, a true gem.  There's so much I could say about this game however it's all been said by everyone.  It has influenced countless others, brought about the amazing sequels, and more.  Simply put, Batman Arkham Asylum is "the perfect game".  I don't usually play through games multiple times however I have now played through this 3 times over the course of my life, with the third time finally achieving a 100%  story run (excluding challenges).  The first time I played this, I played it with a CRT monitor on a PC barely strong enough.  I saved my allowance, birthday money, and every penny for this PC and I couldn't enjoy the phsyx effects at the time but that didn't matter.  Fast forward to today, I am in my thirties and just completed it on a 4k TV with HDR, every bell and whistle cranked to the max, and the game still looks incredible.  Thank you Rocksteady for bringing such an incredible and iconic hero to life.

What more needs to be said about this game that already hasn't been. Batman: Arkham Asylum remains just as fun to play as it did way back in 2009 and then some. Is this game's mechanics clunky and unrefined compared to the leaps and strides City and Knight innovated on? Certainly. Are the graphics and the 720P cutscenes dated by today's standards? Sure. Is Arkham City still the undisputed GOAT of the franchise? Undoubtedly. However, what City and Knight make up for in mechanics and gameplay, this game nails in atmosphere and tone. In no other instance in the franchise is such a setting as creepy, disquieting and uncomfortable as Arkham Asylum. The dark and decrepit hallways that may just have a lunatic lurking around the corner or above you in the vents really does instill a sense of dread and foreboding as you navigate through the many rooms and buildings of the asylum. Per usual, Kevin Conroy plays an excellent Batman but I'd argue Mark Hamill steals the show with a delightfully unhinged performance as Joker, with an excellent turn from the late Arleen Sorkin reprising her role as Harley Quinn. For many fans, I think returning to Asylum after playing the later games of the franchise may be difficult given the numerous combat enhancements, gadgets and overall QOL improvements that were made, however there is a reason this game is such a masterpiece and put superhero games on the map for the modern era. It remains as one of the greatest games ever made, and undoubtedly one of the best Batman stories ever told.

Itâ€™s moody, contemplative, and it keeps you eager to find out what will happen next during the whole story. 
Well done introduction to a modern-day creepy, horror-esque Batman for "adults".
Graphics and physics hold up incredibly well.

Although it's the smallest Arkham game both in scale and length, Asylum is a phenomenal introduction to this iteration of Batman. Other games in the series certainly stand out more than this one, but that is only possible because of the incredible foundation this game established for the series. Much of what makes the others so great are improvements and expansions on key elements of this game, so my compliments for this game may also apply to its sequels. I think this game truly nails the atmosphere of the Batman world, even moreso than the sequels. The Arkham Asylum, while the smallest of playable areas in the series, feels complete and believable, with every area fulfilling a purpose. Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill excel at capturing the essence of Batman and Joker respectively, with this singular performance catapulting them into contention with live action iterations for greatest performances. All in all, while the rest of the series undoubtedly improves on the gameplay and story, Arkham Asylum pulls off the feat of pulling the player into this universe so effectively that it deserves just as much praise.

If there is one thing the start of the legendary trilogy has proved, it's how Batman himself is one of the greatest superheroes in comic culture. Batman: Arkham Asylum is not just an incredible start of the series, but also one of the best superhero games out there. It combines the Arkham Asylum into a video game and was executed in the most awesome kind of way. The story takes the setting to a new level, the riddler challenges gives extra to make the game fun, the graphics hold up a couple of decades later, and the gameplay is so unpredictable and charming that gives a lot of inspiration to the superhero. Not only would I call this a must play, especially for Batman fans like me, but also even recommend making it to full completion to look for easter eggs from all the riddles. This could even have you get to know more about Batman because those make the game welcome to the players that have not known a lot about the characters and what the series is. This game is not only one of the best things to come out of Batman, but also an example of how some superhero games can be awesome to check out.

Has to be one of the best games ever made alongside SWKOTOR. It looks good, it plays good, the story is amazing and its captivating. Cant believe it came out in 2009.

After having recently replayed it, this game still holds up very well, even almost 15 years later! While elements like combat, stealth and traversal are VERY basic when compared to future entries, it provides a very solid foundation that, even if simple, is still incredibly fun today.

The atmosphere is easily one of the biggest highlights. The asylum itself is just as much a character as Batman and his foes. It's creepy, unnerving and tells a story purely by it's appearance. I cannot praise Rocksteady enough, they did a fantastic job.

The voice acting is also a major highlight. From Kevin Conroy (R.I.P) to Arleen Sorkin (R.I.P.) and Mark Hamill, everyone did a phenomenal job.

Over-all, Arkham Asylum is still a fantastic game, and a fantastic start to the Arkham series

Having played this game back in 2009, my nostalgia has admittedly left my biased. However, I'm confident in writing a recommendation for this all-time classic regardless. Admittedly, its graphics have started to show its age, texture-wise, and the community has had to come up with custom configuration settings in the files just to make Arkham Asylum consistently functional, performance-wise, even on higher-end specs. Additionally, Arkham Asylum is no longer the groundbreaking superhero game it was back in 2009 --- it proved the genre's potential beyond cheap marketing for movies --- and since then, talented studios, such as Insomniac, have gone on to bring classic comic heroes to life. Truly, it has become a product of its time, but the amazing free-flow combat system, spectacularly voiced performances from Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, etc, and the overall immersive qualities, both in a mechanical and diagetic sense, ensure you'll have just as much fun as I did nearly 15 years ago.

With that said, I cannot recommend a poorly configured piece of software in good conscience without providing some helpful fixes:

Step 1: Install the Advanced Launcher located on Nexus Mods. You'll need it to turn off and/or configure certain performance-intensive features, such as anti-aliasing. A setting that smoothes the edges of 3D objects. I know, I know. The recommended specs above may fool you, but remember, Arkham Asylum was primarily made with the PS3 and Xbox 360 in mind. This PC port leaves much to be desired. That aside, you'll also need the program 7-Zip to extract the files. Once extracted, make sure you specifically move the launcher file into the Binaries folder in Arkham Asylum's local files, accessible from your Steam library, or your desktop's Folder application. Otherwise, the vanilla launcher won't be properly overwritten. Here's a link for that: https://www.nexusmods.com/batmanarkhamasylum/mods/117

Step 2 (for NVIDIA users): Right-click on your desktop background and select "NVIDIA Control Panel". Once there, select "Configure Surround, PhysX", and set your processor to your PC's graphics processing unit. Mine, for example, is a 1060ti. Not its core processing unit, nor the "Auto-Select (recommended)" setting. 

Step 3 (for NVIDA users): Make sure your drivers are updated to the latest software version. If they're not, use this link here: https://www.nvidia.com/content/DriverDownloads/confirmation.php?url=/Windows/9.19.0218/PhysX-9.19.0218-SystemSoftware.exe&lang=us&type=GeForce

Step 4: Use these configuration files for improved performance. Though, I recommend ignoring the "max settings" requirement for lower-end PC users. Follow the rest of the instructions to the letter: 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=946811872

Step 5: Congratulations! You're ready to play Batman: Arkham Asylum! Have fun.

I'm on a journey to %100 the Arkham series on steam.

When I was a kid my dad would take me to best buy and I would play this games demo any chance I got. Even after getting %100 I'd still recommend this game to anyone. If this game has somehow slipped by you after all these years, now is the time to try it and see where this series began. 

Getting %100 for this game isn't that difficult compared to the other games, as long as you keep on track with the Riddler trophies, getting them after the story isn't too hard. There aren't too many challenge maps so completing that is just a test of skill an patience.

This game is a must play even after all these years. And while you're at it, you might as well %100 it.

The GCPD interrogator was a stone-faced woman who'd been with the force for twenty years. The goon squirming in his seat across the table, despite his mannerisms, was somehow competent enough to have survived almost as long. The life expectancy for foot soldiers in Gotham was comparable to that of a fruit fly, but he had somehow managed to keep his head on. How was that, she wondered?

After a long silence, the only sound chains jingling as his knee bounced under the table, "Okay. Listen, lady," the goon began, breaking the silence. "I'll tell ya. I'll tell ya everything."

"Go on." A smooth, cool voice. "Let's hear it, then."

"You'd think we'd start at the Origin with something like this, but time don't work that way. No, this all began at the Asylum. See, we had ta start small. Had ta make a Metroidvania that has fun combat, where Batman is running around some interconnected areas."

"The writing."

"What?"

"How was the writing?"

"Writing? I mean, good, whatever, sure. Who cares? It's the voice acting ya actually care about, the characters, the plot don't matter. Am I right?"

"Is that really what you think?"

The goon sighed. "The plot's kinda dumb. But it's a Batman game. Th' fuck ya want, lady? Look, the characters are all on point, the voice acting's great, the redesigns of all the classic Batman stuff is grimy and trashy but it works. They even got Mark Hamill back!"

"Who?"

"The [i]original voice of the Joker[/i]. From the Animated Series? The one everyone holds up like a fuckin' religion? Jesus, lady, ya dense?"

The interrogator leaned back in her seat. A frown.

"...Sorry."

"Continue."

"The music's great, the gameplay's fine. I mean it's a bit clunky, but it was /innovating/ somethin'. Ya don't start somethin' new and knock it out of the park on the first swing."

"What about the boss fights?"

A very long, very uncomfortable pause. The goon stares down at the table.

"The boss fights," she repeated. "What about the boss fights?"

"...I mean, Poison Ivy is there, and-"

Her hands slammed on the table. The goon recoiled in terror.

"OKAY! OKAY! FINE! THE BOSS FIGHTS! THEY'RE TERRIBLE, THEY'RE NOT FUN AT ALL, THEY'RE BORING AND SAMEY AND UNINTERESTING! Fuck! Fine! You got me, okay?! But that's the ONLY BAD THING. Come ON, lady, nothing's perfect! Fine! Fuck! Can I go already?!"

"No," the interviewer said, with a gaze that could bore holes through his skull. "We're not done, yet."

[To be continued in: Batman: Arkham City.]

The Arkham Batman games are legendary. This one started a trilogy (Prequel: Arkham Origins not included, so techincally not a trilogy, but 4) of games that changed so much in such a good way. With good gameplay and pretty good graphics for its time, along with fun and interesting stories, and even more, this series contains arguably some of the best games. For this game, the first one, Arkham Asylum, it's simpler and not as complex, and it has a little bit of a creepy aura that adds so much to it. You get introduced to the Arkham world, and then jump into the next game. See my review on Arkham City. Have a great day everyone! By the way, you shoukld for sure get these games, even if they aren't on sale. I reccomend the bundle for the main three games and DLC, and origins seperately (and dlc for that if you want), but your choice.

Batman: Arkham Asylum, released in 2009, stands as a testament to the potential of superhero-themed video games. Developed by Rocksteady Studios, this game is a dark and gripping journey into the heart of madness that not only captures the essence of the Batman universe but also sets a new standard for action-adventure games.

From the outset, Arkham Asylum impresses with its atmospheric presentation. The asylum itself becomes a character in its own right, a nightmarish labyrinth of crumbling architecture, flickering lights, and haunting echoes. The attention to detail in the design of both the environments and the characters is nothing short of phenomenal, creating a visually stunning and immersive experience.

The narrative of Arkham Asylum is a compelling blend of psychological thriller and superhero drama. As Batman, players find themselves trapped on Arkham Island with some of Gotham's most notorious criminals, including the Joker, who orchestrates a chaotic takeover of the asylum. The story unfolds with a perfect balance of suspense and action, keeping players on the edge of their seats while delving into the complexities of the Dark Knight's psyche.

The voice acting, particularly the performances of Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker, adds an extra layer of authenticity to the characters. The chemistry between these two iconic characters is palpable and contributes significantly to the overall narrative impact.

The gameplay mechanics of Arkham Asylum are revolutionary, introducing the Freeflow combat system that allows players to seamlessly transition between attacks, counters, and evasions. The fluidity of combat makes players feel like the caped crusader, effortlessly taking down groups of enemies with a combination of martial arts and gadgetry. The Detective Mode, another innovative feature, enhances Batman's detective skills, adding a strategic element to exploration and crime-solving.

The game's clever level design and puzzle-solving elements make Arkham Asylum more than just a beat-em-up. Navigating the asylum requires a combination of stealth, intellect, and combat prowess. The predator sections, where Batman takes on armed enemies from the shadows, are particularly exhilarating and showcase the character's mastery of fear.

Arkham Asylum is not just a solitary experience; it's a celebration of Batman's rogues' gallery. The encounters with iconic villains like Scarecrow, Killer Croc, and Poison Ivy are memorable and serve as a testament to the game's commitment to honoring the source material.

In terms of audio, the soundtrack composed by Ron Fish and Nick Arundel perfectly complements the dark and brooding atmosphere of Arkham Asylum. The music intensifies during critical moments, enhancing the overall emotional impact of the narrative.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a masterclass in superhero gaming. Its innovative gameplay, gripping narrative, and faithful representation of the Batman universe make it a timeless classic. Whether you're a fan of the Dark Knight or simply enjoy immersive action-adventure experiences, Arkham Asylum is a must-play that continues to influence and inspire superhero games to this day.
