I strongly recommend Batman Arkham Asylum. Playing this game had not crossed my mind until I looked at all the Game of the Year (GOTY) awards from previous years, from many websites and gaming companies. Having played, I now understand. Here's why:

Pros:
-Very good immersion. You act as Batman from the very start.
-Simple but deep action combat system.
-Excellent variety and pacing: A bit of combat, I do a challenge, then back to story mode, searching for clues.
-Multiple modes of gameplay. Flying Batman, grappling Batman, investigating, fighting, talking, etc.
-The graphics are very nice. The atmosphere is dark but everything is detailed and looks awesome.
-There are hidden secrets, challenges, backstories about all the lore, a hidden batcave, gadgets, upgrades...
-Overall, everything fits well. The visuals, the upgrades, the story, the combat, etc.

Cons:
-There's no manual save. Only automatic Checkpoints and sometimes, they might save your game right after a poor performance in combat. As such, you can't load and must continue the story with that poor performance. It's not a big thing but it did annoy me at least once.

Quite simply some of the most fun you can have playing a superhero game. The combat is still badass and slick enough to make me involuntarily exclaim and smile 14 years later. Batman doesn't kill, but he doesn't mind breaking your arm in three different places and giving you a concussion. Not to mention the little details, like the battle damage Batman's suit sustains over the story or the stubble growth on his chin as the game progresses. Every bit of this game oozes polish, passion, and a love for the source material.

[b][u]Pro:[/u][/b]

+ Orchestral soundtrack that truly captures the spirit of Batman.
+ Well-balanced gameplay elements including riddles, climbing & combat

[b][u]Contra:[/u][/b]
- Stealth sections are too easy, lacking in challenge.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
"Arkham Asylum" stands as a [u]GOOD[/u] game, especially for fans of Batman. It masterfully combines various gameplay elements with a rich, dark atmosphere and a compelling plot.

âš ï¸ Played through with the Asylum Reborn - HD Texture Pack Mod version 1.1 released in November, 2022.

So this is where it all began, back in 2009? 

I came into this game expecting some of that â€œold game jankâ€. I expected to struggle with the controls. And keep in mind, I played all the other games in the franchise before this first one. So I was also worried that nothing would feel fresh. That the developers had recycled so many of the ideas between the games, that I wouldnâ€™t be able to enjoy it to its fullest. That I had, in essence, already â€œruined the experienceâ€ by playing it last. 

Well, it turns out my worries were unfounded. Because this game laid the groundwork for the Arkham games that came after. This is the foundation upon which they were built. Asylum felt fresh and interesting throughout the experience.

And not only that. Itâ€™s the perfect combination of all my favorite elements of the later games in the series. The atmosphere, boss fights, storyâ€¦ everything comes together so nicely. 

But not only does this game do the things I enjoyed just a little better - it also doesnâ€™t do the things I disliked about the later games. 

Heck, even getting Riddler Trophies was enjoyable in Asylum, and I had zero interest in getting them in the later games. 

The level design is much clearer in this one and I was able to navigate the levels much easier, without getting lost or feel unsure of where to go or what to do. 

The combat, while not as elaborate as the later entries in the series, felt more focused. There are less specific enemy strategies to worry about which means you donâ€™t have to deal with as many required button-presses. For example, there are no enemies with shields, and the annoying â€œknife dodgeâ€ isnâ€™t in the game. I personally think the lack of those two enemy types makes the game better as they frequently disrupted the flow of combat and only served to reduce player creativity during large fights.

The boss fights all felt fresh and engaging, but I do think Arkham Origins did those just a little better. 

The story, however, ended up being my favorite out of the Arkham games.

So, there you have it. Calling this game anything but a masterpiece would just be dishonest. 
Obviously recommended.

One of my favorite video games of all time. Nobody has enthralled me more than the Batman.

This game encapsulates a gritty graphic novel brought to life more than most other superhero games, and while the later Arkham games add on to the gameplay, none of them compare to the haunting gothic aesthetic of Asylum. From the sound design to the music and the beautiful UI elements, this is a true comic book game.
There are some issues to be had, some are issues of the time, and others are not worth the excuse. The combo system can be unforgiving, ending with a single mistake or even a little patience, the game won't always know who you are targeting or what action you were supposed to do if you are a bit too far from your target. The story can be odd, dialogue seems single draft, but one cannot deny the talent put forth in the performances. There's also a glaring issue in the penultimate cutscene that has still remained unfixed.
Those issues aside, the game is still perfectly enjoyable, I honestly have more issues with the sequels than this one. I make sure to play it 100% every year. If you enjoy DC, Batman, Superheroes, or goth games, this is a necessity to play. 10/10

If you've ever wondered what it's like to be Batman, congratulations! This game will make you feel like you've had a crash course in caped crusading. In just 12 hours of game play, you'll traverse a madhouse, battle baddies, and confront your deepest fearsâ€”without the benefit of an Alfred to patch you up after.

The game play? As addictive as Gotham's crime rate. The story? Good enough to make Scarecrow's gasp-inducing antics nearly as memorable as Batman's tragic backstory. His obsession with rehashing the whole 'Bruce Wayne's parents' ordeal might just make you want to sign up for a therapy session yourself.

And speaking of wear and tear, forget the Batsuit; your controller might need a replacement after the intense workout it gets from button mashing and stealthy takedowns. But hey, isn't that what being the Dark Knight is all about? The exhaustion, the adrenaline, the emotional baggageâ€”all in a day's work for Batman. Or in this case, a player determined to finish this gripping game.

So, if you're ready to immerse yourself in the shoes (or should I say, the boots) of the caped crusader, Batman Arkham Asylum is your bat signal. Just remember, when the game's over, you might feel like you've taken on the Joker and emerged victoriousâ€”exhilarated, slightly battered, but ultimately, feeling like a hero."

A Masterpiece Even In 2023.

The combat system in comparison with the future parts of the series may seem primitive, the variety of enemies and bosses is depressing, as well as the constantly repeating gameplay cycle with stealth clearing rooms with gargoyles.

However, despite this, Batman: Arkham Asylum is still worth a play through even if you don't care about gameplay for Batman. The game has a great atmosphere and wonderfully transmitted comic book characters, they are expressively designed and perfectly voiced. We can't fail to mention the direction of the story moments, and you'll remember Scarecrow bad trips for a long time.

Unlike future parts of the series, this one is a metroidvania and the process of exploring Arkham Asylum is very exciting. It's interesting to look around every corner in search of secrets, and every new device you want to try to use to open previously untraveled places.

The first in an iconic series, Asylum introduced the beloved action and stealth that made it and its successors famous. Although it can feel dated, the core gameplay is still as fun as it is anywhere else. Famous and infamous characters are portrayed and referenced in a way that will get the attention of any DC fan. Batman's gadgets and abilities allow players to take on the toughest of enemies and barriers, with some thought put in. A great action game that started a series that is loved by millions. 8/10.

The open-enough-world superhero game everyone wants. There's an engaging combat system, decently paced story, and a great amount of detail given to the characters, including the villain gallery of the Batman kind. Even the smaller dudes get a spot you'll have a reason to remember afterwards.

To note an extra time, the art and general visual direction in this game is phenomenal. AND you can get a splendor of collectibles that unlock 3D inspectable models, concept art, extra story bits via VO and text...
OH, and the music - Nick Arundel does a fantastic job on the score, which follows the exact feel you'd like out of a Batman flick, but with the added benefit of not getting repetitive in a video game.

Still worth playing even today. It may be the weakest in the trilogy but thats only because its also the oldest. The game is arcade-y enough to actually be enjoyable while also maintaining its dim essence and atmosphere. In terms of boss fights though, this game is the best out of all in the trilogy.

Decent game. The freeflow combat is quite revolutionary and spawned many imitators in the industry. Really love the gothic architecture in Arkham Aslyum, fits right in with the brooding score and gritty atmosphere. Voice actors and animations are as great as ever in a Batman game and the fact they improve on this throughout the series is wonderful. My biggest gripes though? The boss fights and the endgame stuff. Most of the bosses, aside from Poison Ivy and Killer Croc, are copy and paste and ridiculously easy. Hit them with a batarang when they charge at you and dodge roll when you need to, not difficult at all. The endgame portion is poorly paced with the backtracking and rushed in Poison Ivy part. And to top the lameness off with the plant junk, Joker's lazy a*s boss fight where he's roided up and you basically have to keep pulling him down with the batclaw over and over, it sucks. Overall though, it's a fine game.

Without a doubt in my mind I can say that this game is one of the best superhero games ever. From the challenging aspects to the absolutely magnificent story it has it all. 1. The Good: This game is the first of a beautiful trilogy. I definitely recommend starting with this one first! This games combat and story is fantastic. The graphics at the time was top tier and still holds up today imo. I love running around as the dark knight unlocking new gadgets and skills. You can rush in head first and beat the crap out of a group of criminals and you can also sneak around and take them out one by one. I very much enjoyed this game and recommend it. There are many unique ways you can play with the gadgets as well.

2. The Bad: The enemies you face can be a little repetitive sometimes and some of the bosses as well but that doesn't really make it any less fun to beat em up. Final boss fight was very underwhelming.   Anyhow I highly recommend for anyone looking for a good action-adventure game!

This may be controversial but this just isn't the best Arkham game. Why? Well, this series had humble beginnings. The combat is clunky and occasionally frustrating, the boss fights are painfully repetitive, there is an era-appropriate amount of backtracking, and graphically, this is a game that only a mother could love. However, for all of the bad, there is at least an ample amount of positive-review-worthy good. It has Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy in it for god sakes - that's ample enough for me! With this considered, unfortunately, it's still only good enough to earn my appreciation, and certainly not the adoration that many people seem to have for it.

I first played AA back on the PS3, my first 'next gen' game at the time, and what a game to kickstart the 7th gen for me.

Arkham Asylum is masterful, its a clichÃ© but the game really does make you feel like you're the Dark Knight, it accentuates the physicality, the brutality, the danger of Batman's work, while demonstrating that he may just be able to overcome whatever challenges face him.

The free flow combat is a standout, it's effortless to wrack up combos against countless things, while the game later introduces varied enemies that make things much more interesting.

The stealth sections are more about hunting the enemies, rather than hiding, you can see around corners, straight through them, and and dart around undetected as your foes freak the f**k out.

The asylum stands alongside Black Mesa, the Von Braun, Rapture and all the other quintessential locations in games, it's spooky and atmospheric, great fun to explore with wonderful pacing, you're never doing the same thing for too long.

I won't spoil the mind-blowing boss encounters, there's some dull ones but the highlights are truly special and further elevate the game, I really can't recommend it enough.

If you haven't played Asylum before, you need to get on it, it's genuinely one of the great games of all time, I can't recommend it enough, and also great on the Steam Deck if you've got one.

A masterfully crafted superhero game that immerses players in the dark and gritty world of Gotham. The atmospheric setting of Arkham Asylum, combined with the compelling narrative and engaging combat mechanics, delivers an unforgettable gaming experience. The attention to detail in character design and the utilization of Batman's detective skills add depth to the gameplay. With stellar voice acting and a captivating storyline, Arkham Asylum stands as a benchmark for superhero video games, offering an exceptional blend of action and storytelling.

An issue reviewing a game that has more than a decade is that most of its qualities are what became usual game design afterwards. Rocksteady here found a good balance between the open world "map clearing" mechanics of UbiSoft games (Assassin's Creed, Watch Dogs...) and the very Devil May Cry gameplay with loads of scripted events, AND they also took advantage of the DC world creating something that is familiar to the TV series but not really. It really feels like one of the better Batman adaptations (even when I dislike some boss battles and some characters are just mentioned) and one of the better open world games out there.

Short, fun game. Combat is simple and similar to other WB games such as LOTR (pretty much just attack and counter). The stealth sections are for the most part very fun. In the past this began my journey of further appreciation for the Batman character and franchise,
replaying this game was a trip down memory lane.

The greatest positives I have are the accuracy to the comics and gameplay. There are so many Easter Eggs for long time Batman fans and the characterisation for the protagonist, antagonists and everything in between is strong enough for anybody new to Batman to get into the characters and world or appreciate how the writers captured them for people who have known these characters for long enough.
The combat flows really well. From hitting, stunning, countering and using gadgets you will always have enough options as the player to combat the enemies and never once feel like you are taken out of the experience.
The overworld is not too big and has enough density to keep you looking out for secrets and enemies. The gadgets all feed into the gameplay within the overworld that you always feel challenged but not overwhelmed with choice for which gadget works where.

My criticisms with Arkham Asylum are the constant reuse of one particular type of boss fight and one section type(?) Both are reused a good amount but the main story makes sense for at least the former to be prevalent.
I can also nitpick that you can easily tell when the cinematics play compared to gameplay, aswell as some of the audio quality can be a bit compressed.

Otherwise this is an easy recommendation.

A game that still holds up to current standards

This is one of the best Batman games of all time. It's VERY Batman with voices from the TV show, including Mark Hammel reprising his role as The Joker! This is a fantastic game that should be used as a way to tell other people who make games based on preexisting intellectual licences how to get it right.

Though Arkham Island isn't as big as locations in the later games, it is filled with a very rich and beautiful areas with many different characters to run into from the infamous ones like Scarecrow or Bane to the more obscure ones like Zassaz and info on many others that sadly don't make an appearance.

The end boss fight is something many people dislike and I can understand why, but it fits the story and the overall game is really awesome too. I'd highly recommend it if you didn't own it already.

[b] Achievements. Don't miss out on this masterpiece! [/b]

[h1] The Game [/h1]
Third-person stealth action game where you must stop the Joker from taking over the Arkham Asylum.

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
The achievements are a mix of everything: story, difficulty, collectibles and challenges. There are guides and tips available and the game completes in about 20-30 hours, depending on skill. 

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
Considered to be one of the best video games of all time, the game provides you with a very entertaining and enjoyable experience. The campaign has great characters, level design and a good story while the challenges are although somewhat difficult not impossible. Highly recommended to play and complete!

If you're an achievement hunter like myself, feel free to check out my curator for more reviews!

Yes, I would. The game is very fun.


The good:
-If you're a Batman fan, there's a tone of lore for you. 

-There's plenty of collectibles. and there's a fair bit of challenge to getting them.

-I don't think I had any bugs, which is rare these days.

-The game looks great, although graphics aren't important.



The OK:
The combat. The free flow is fun, and requires you to pay attention. It can be fun to jump back and forth across the screen, hitting sending enemies flying. The problem is when it doesn't work. A  lot of times you aim at someone, hit the button to jump across the screen, and you just punch at air. When you get swarmed, the game can send you at the enemy you didn't want to with the wrong attack. For as fun as it is, it's flaws are equally as noticeable.

-The movement. It's blocky, and clunky. At the time this game was made, most games had more fluid movement figured out years earlier.

-The story. It's ok. It's Batman and the Joker.





The bad:
-To be honest....I got nothing. No real complaints. Damn...

Overall, if you're a big fan of Batman or the Free Flow combat, you'll love it. I'm a casual of both of those, so take my review for that. It's still a fun game, and I recommend it. I just have to laugh at people who melt down when it's criticized. It's fun, but flawed.
Bang for your buck! Though I would recommend to get this when there's a sale. Clearly this game was ahead of its time. Good story, gameplay, and graphics for something made in the 2000s

Batman Arkham Asylum is a masterpiece of stealth and action. It is nothing short of a triumph in the realm of superhero video games. Rocksteady has crafted an immersive and exhilarating experience that not only pays homage to the iconic caped crusader but sets an incredibly high standard for action-adventure games as a whole.

The game's narrative is a roller coaster of suspense and intrigue, written with the same finesse as a classic Batman comic. From the outset, players find themselves trapped on Arkham Island with the Joker, unleashing chaos in a sinister plot that keeps you guessing until the very end. The voice acting, led by the legendary Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker, is stellar and adds a cinematic quality to the storytelling.

Where Batman: Arkham Asylum truly shines is in its gameplay mechanics. The free-flow combat system is a work of art, allowing players to seamlessly switch between attacking, countering, and using gadgets in a rhythmic dance of destruction. It's easy to feel the power and agility of the Dark Knight as you take on waves of enemies with a sense of finesse rarely seen in other action games.

The stealth elements are equally praiseworthy. Sneaking through the shadows, using gadgets to outsmart armed thugs, and striking fear into the hearts of enemies captures the essence of Batman's detective skills. The level design complements these mechanics, providing a diverse range of environments within Arkham Asylum, each filled with secrets and challenges that encourage exploration.

The attention to detail in the game world is outstanding. From the iconic Bat-Signal to the gritty interiors of Arkham, every aspect of the environment is meticulously crafted. The atmospheric soundtrack adds an extra layer of tension and excitement, immersing players in the dark and foreboding atmosphere of Batman's world.

Arkham Asylum's inclusion of the detective mode adds a unique twist to the gameplay. While it aids in tracking enemies and solving puzzles, it also reinforces the idea that Batman is not just a brawler but a brilliant detective, showcasing his intellect and resourcefulness.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a stellar achievement in the world of video games. Its engaging narrative, fluid game play, and attention to detail make it a must-play for both Batman fans and gaming enthusiasts alike. Rocksteady Studios has not only delivered the definitive Batman experience but has set a benchmark for superhero games that is yet to be surpassed. If you haven't donned the cape and cowl in Arkham Asylum, you're missing out on one of the greatest superhero gaming experiences of all time.

This game (like every game) has it's ups and downs, but i think that the good outshines the bad by a long shot.
Lets start with the good:
The game really makes you feel like batman. The combat is really smooth and satisfying and gives you a good adrenaline hit when you get a high combo. Even though the island is small, every building in there is like a section of the story and i think that's cool. The story itself is awesome and it experiments with things that a lot of games today don't do anymore. The riddler challenges actually reward you with things like character trophys alongside other things and some of the "riddles" are actually quite interesting. The upgrades always add something new and they make most of the backtracking less jarring. And all of the gadgets are cool af.
Now for the bad:
 The biggest criticism that a lot of people (including me) have is the bossfights: bane is a good introduction but it should've had more different moves/AI than the titanhenchmen and rest of the fights are titanhenchmen or gimmick fights. Sometimes the counter doesn't really work or the timing is different but maybe that's a skill issue. The backtracking probably isn't something that most people get annoyed with and tbh it's not that bad, but it's still there and there's enough of it to criticize it. (it didn't stop me from 100%:ing the game though)

Overall there is more content than there is reusing it, more new riddles than old ones, the story's awesome (especially the scarecrow parts), the game isn't too long and even 100 percenting the game isn't that boring (I'd have to play the game again though 'cause I missed one achievement, if you've played the game you prob. know which one.)

Batman: Arkham Asylum, the OG of the Arkham series, serves as a captivating initiation into the world of Batman, showcasing the roots of a gaming legacy that would follow. Undoubtedly, it's a great game, and if you're a Batman enthusiast who somehow hasn't experienced it yet, it comes highly recommended. Often available at a reasonable price during sales, it offers a thoroughly enjoyable journey into the dark and atmospheric setting of Arkham.

Being the inaugural installment, Arkham Asylum does exhibit some signs of its early development. While the story is undeniably great, the ending might leave some wanting more, and the overall narrative could be seen as relatively short, lacking the depth of side quests that later entries in the series would introduce. Aside from the Riddler trophies, there's a notable absence of side quests, contributing to a more linear gameplay experience. The combat system, which revolutionized the superhero genre, is not without its quirks. Though the combat mechanics laid the groundwork for future titles, they can feel somewhat unpolished at times, especially in challenge maps where maintaining a combo can be frustrating due to occasional hiccups.

Despite these nuances, Arkham Asylum is a must-play for Batman fans. It may have its rough edges, but the game shines in its atmospheric brilliance. The hauntingly beautiful yet terrifying setting of Arkham Asylum, combined with a richly fleshed-out cast of characters, immerses players in the Batman experience like never before. You're not just playing as Batman; you are Batman, navigating the psychological depths of Arkham, empathizing with its inmates, and questioning the impact of the environment on their mental well-being. Flaws aside, Arkham Asylum delivers a unique and unforgettable experience that any Batman fan should embrace without hesitation. So, go ahead and buy the game â€” you won't regret stepping into the iconic cowl of the Dark Knight.

I just bought all 4 Arkham games and am playing through them chronologically. Obviously, this was first in line and did not disappoint in the slightest. The concept was so cool, typically you see inmates breaking out of Arkham so being trapped on the island with the villains for a change was super cool. The music was dope, the atmosphere was tense and it was an awesome experience to play. The gameplay was fairly simple, not too hard or complicated (though I really need to learn to counter better). I will say, playing on Normal mode, the bosses started out really good but I think they got continuously repetitive which kinda became a drag, especially later on with some particular bosses. I'm just starting my second playthrough on hard so if that changes with the mode I'll write that here, but overall the bosses were pretty tough which was nice. However*********SPOILER*********the final boss is very underwhelming compared to bosses played previously. It was almost pathetically easy how quickly the final battle came and went compared to how many times I died trying to beat other bosses********END SPOILER*********

In the end, this was a fairly simple yet still cool and atmospheric game and I thoroughly enjoyed playing it and will enjoy completing it :)

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a masterful start to one of the best video game series' I've ever played. The atmosphere is easily the best in the entire game and although the controls feel inferior to the rest of the Arkham Games, it still holds up pretty well compared to a lot of other games. The features like detective mode and the wide plethora of gadgets you can use make you feel truly like Batman while trapped in the Asylum. A lot of care was put into this game and it is definitely in my top 10 games of all game.

For being the first game in the series, it's a solid foundation for the others, however looking at it nowadays it just doesn't really hold up as well as I had hoped.  It was buggy sometimes the map didn't work countering was 50/50 getting hit by random things and the backtracking was tedious and walking from point to point was slow. Combat was solid and so was the plot and the graphics are still ok, but it was just a struggle to get to those good parts. Overall nice to see the foundation and the story of the arkham games, but not a very fun experience

[INT. A DIMLY LIT ROOM IN ARKHAM ASYLUM]

JOKER: (leaning against a wall, grinning) Ah, Batman, my brooding buddy, and Harley, my favorite gal-pal! Let's chat about that Arkham Asylum game, shall we? Oh, what a hoot it was! But I've got to say, Batsy, they should've renamed it "Darkham Asylum." I mean, come on, you practically run the place, and they might as well call it the "Batman Museum of Punchable Rogues."

[BATMAN and HARLEY sit at a table, both chuckling.]

BATMAN: (stoic) Well, Joker, I have to admit, "Arkham Asylum" was quite an experience. It captured the essence of the asylum and the challenges I face perfectly.

HARLEY: (grinning) Puddin', I gotta agree with the clown on this one. The game was a real blast. The story was so engaging, and it made us all look... dare I say it... cool!

JOKER: (grinning widely) You see, old chum, I had a blast making those insane riddles for you. It's like a demented version of "Wheel of Fortune," but with more fear gas and fewer vowels. And speaking of fear gas, Harley, you really ought to share some of that pie with the rest of us. It's not like we're trying to take over the world or anything... oh, wait, we are!

[BATMAN raises an eyebrow, and HARLEY giggles.]

BATMAN: (calmly) The game captured the atmosphere of Arkham perfectly. The dark and foreboding tone, the intricate level design, and the clever puzzles all added to the experience.

HARLEY: (nodding) Yeah, and the characters, Puddin'! They were spot on. I mean, who could forget that creepy Scarecrow? Even you looked pretty intimidating, Mr. J.

JOKER: (feigning modesty) Well, you know, it's hard to capture all this fabulousness on screen, but they did an okay job.

BATMAN: (smirking) And your hideouts, Joker, they were quite the challenge to infiltrate. The game kept me on my toes.

HARLEY: (grinning) And the combat, Batsy! It was like a dance of destruction. You looked so graceful taking down those thugs.

JOKER: (raising an eyebrow) All right, all right, I'll admit it was fun watching you two praise the game. But let's not forget that it's all about me, the Clown Prince of Crime, right?

BATMAN: (smirking) Well, Joker, in "Arkham Asylum," you definitely stole the show, just like you always try to.

HARLEY: (giggling) That's right, Puddin'! So here's to "Arkham Asylum" â€“ a game that let us relive our greatest hits and reminded us all that we're the stars of this crazy circus.

JOKER: (grinning) Cheers to the game that proves I'm the real star of the show, and you two are just my supporting cast. Ta-ta for now, Batsy and Harley!

[The three share a laugh, a rare moment of camaraderie in the depths of Arkham Asylum.]

The start of the definitive Batman game series. I love the combat, the puzzles, the equipment. They perfect it in Arkham City but this game packs a tight little narrative with few QOL issues.

I don't care much for all that superhero nonsense, but this is a great game, with just a few flaws. For example, the stealth mechanics are not that great, with enemies that are apparently deaf and have no peripheral vision. It also didn't run that well with Proton, even though the game is more than a decade old by now. But the game, especially the combat, is still great fun. And did you know that this Walt Skylurker guy from The Star Treks voiced the clown?

I bought the whole Arkham series(except Origins) at a rock bottom price during the sale,but this review is about Asylum so I will get started right away.

The moment you will start the game the visuals will make you feel like this is not a game that was released over a decade ago with no bugs whatsoever.

The gameplay is not like MKX or Injustice where you have to learn the combos but instead you fight with the option to evade,counter and stun which is a lot easy than learning which buttons to mash to get the fight going on brutally.

The length of the game is around 21 hours(on normal whch does not feel like a challenge) if you also collect the riddles left by the riddler side by side.I did just that and my total game progress is 82% and I have collected more than 70% of the riddles.

Overall the game play is pretty straight forward and you will hardly find yourself stuck in a pickle.

If people reading this review are wondering whether their PC is compatible then do not worry,any PC under Rs 40k will suffice. 

NOTE-If you do not have a nvidia graphic card then keep the NVIDIA STEREOSCOPIC 3D option off because it will lead to performance issues if turned on

Specs-
CPU:Intel core i3 115g4
Graphics:Intel UHD graphics(Which is a integrated graphic card for people new to the gaming community)
RAM:8GB
Storage type:SSD

It is a perfect game

Just as awesome as I remembered when I played it on my Xbox 360 back in 2009. The first of the next gen super hero games and really the one that started it all for the genre moving forward. Combat is super fun and was a good building block for later games in the series. The stealth parts of the game are fun even though the enemy behavior at this point was pretty basic (its easy to figure out the walking patterns for the enemies). This still makes for some trophy challenges, especially the extreme ones. The Arkham Asylum setting of the game is great and really immerses you into the Batman universe. The characters all have sick designs and a lot of the voice actors reprise their roles from the Batman Animated series from the 90's. This game is honestly what made me into the Batman fan that I am today.

I kinda don't get the love. Good presentation. Art direction is good for what it's trying to do, voice talent is top notch, setting is great. (hate the bobbing head camera though, makes me sick every time I have to run.) That being said, I don't actually like playing the game much. Gameplay aspects are all just kinda mid or wonky.

 Combat that's essentially mashing 2 buttons unless you have to batarang, then you press a THIRD button. Wooow.  

Final boss is literally just thugs that you've fought the whole game, but just a lot of them. That's like... every fight minus Poison Ivy, the one actual boss fight that's a boss fight. And it too, has you fight hordes of enemies in the middle of it. 

Stealth areas when they're good are fine, but not all are. Some rooms have people just off camera to almost make you fail once before trying again. Others are set up well so you can do it the first try if you're careful, but it's a mixed bag. 

 It's fine, but if you want a superhero game, newer stuff is better. Spiderman PS4 IS a better game to me. This has been in bundles, gone on sale for $5 a dozen times, etc, so it's worth it if you can't afford something else or REALLY love Batman, but even then... idk. It's fine. Hopefully the sequels smoothed out some edges, maybe I'll enjoy them more.

[h3] Worthy of the comic bookâ€™s legacy, Arkham Asylum is bat to the bone [/h3]

My perception of Batman is built entirely on the gritty, grounded realism of The Dark Knight films. These films captured my imagination as they didnâ€™t require a considerable suspension of disbelief to immerse yourself; Bruce Wayne, and all his enemies, live inside vulnerable human bodies which are easily beaten and broken. They are supplemented often by high-tech gadgetry, but these are built from supposed military designs and follows, at least on the surface, known scientific concepts. For example: The Dark Knight shows Batmanâ€™s night-vision developed from sonar technology, indicating that his only real power is his wealth.

Such realism helps us view the human stories behind Batman and his enemies. Batman and Joker are reflections of each other: both faced historical traumas but instead chose two different paths in life, yet both operate above the law and with a dictatorial authority. Thereâ€™s a sense that these characters could feasibly exist in our world, and perhaps show a reflection of two extremes that either of us could fall into. Whereas characters like Thor and Dr. Strange transcend reality and time at a whim, highlighting and boasting the fact that, at least biologically, they are nothing like us, the viewer.

Thatâ€™s why it took a few hours for Arkham Asylum to really win me over. In this game, Batmanâ€™s spandex clings for dear life against the absolutely ripped body of Bruce Wayne, and the Joker morphs into several inhuman entities which stretch far beyond the realms of realism that attached me so closely to the cinematic series. One of the villains first introduced is a giant animated Crocodile, which immediately broke my immersion despite the gameâ€™s incredibly detailed graphics.

However, after taking a conscious effort to drop my traditional thoughts of what Batman is, I started to find enjoyment in Arkham Asylumâ€™s world. Despite Batmanâ€™s voice actor lacking the gruff aggression and edginess of Christian Bale, Ben Affleck and Robert Pattison, Mark Hamill does give a genuinely funny and energetic performance as The Joker. The best voice acting comes from the audiotapes scattered across Arkham, which record psychological evaluations of Batmanâ€™s various villains as theyâ€™re posed questions of simple ethics and world views. 

Batman uses Metroidvania-esque exploration which encourages you to revisit areas to unlock additional paths once you obtain the corresponding skill. For example: half way through Arkham you obtain a hacking device to blow out control boxes, opening up previously locked doors, as well as a zipline to traverse long gaps. What makes exploration so compelling is the tangible feeling of progression, as you obtain new ability, combined with the comfort of backtracking to previous locations. Most areas wonâ€™t take longer than 5 minutes to travel to, and will reveal trophies and audiotapes to further reveal backstory, all of which are genuinely interesting, including stories of Arkhamâ€™s warden and the events which shaped his life.

The gameâ€™s stealth system, on paper, feels the most â€œBatmanâ€ of all encounters as you pick off enemies one by one from the shadows. These sections are fairly difficult as armed enemies clump together, particular when they notice their fallen comrade hanging from a stone gargoyle or unconscious near a control panel. Some elements feel underbaked: for example, the inability to drag bodies into the shadows feels like a clear omission which causes enemies to go onto high alert with little you can do about it. 

The games hand-to-hand system feels too rudimentary to be fun. Most fistfights consist of button mashing with very few combos to learn, a somewhat unreliable counter attack system, and no real opportunity to think creatively or adjust your approach. There were additional combat rooms to complete at the end of the game, which is the only piece of content I didnâ€™t feel compelled to complete. 

Overall though, Batman: Arkham Asylum faithfully taps into a wealth of comic book source material to deliver a satisfying Metroidvania explore-a-thon served with a rather mundane combat system. If, like me, your perception of Batman is shaped by recent onscreen outings, try view this as an alternative take on the series and play through with an open mind. Thereâ€™s plenty to explore, and it provides a great introduction to the wider Batman universe.

I was never into super hero stuff as a kid, but Batman and Spider-Man were my favorite, as to most kids I would imagine. Anyway, I never played the Batman games until recently since the entire trilogy was like 8$ on a random sale. Wasn't expecting much until I saw the metacritic scores. Arkham Asylum has 92/100, Arkham City has 94/100 and Arkham Knight has 87/100. I mean these are some great scores I will tell you that much. So naturally my expectations were high, and suprisingly they were met. For a game that got released in early 2010, Arkham Asylum does so many things right and even better then many games today. Give the trilogy a shot, you won't be dissapointed, as I said I got all 3 games plus all the DLCs for 8$ on Steam, so its not like you are getting ripped off.

Still currently working on 100% for this game. I do recommend to anyone looking for a good game!

I wish I could rank this in the middle to be honest. It plays well, it has good graphics for the time, and there are a lot of reasons why people liked it so much. For those saying they can't get the game to load, it took a while for me but after the initial install it always loaded up immediately without any trouble. I think fans of brawler type games will love this. For me though, I found the game play repetitive and tedious. It's really a subjective opinion rather than an objective one though. I didn't like the achievements. I found them annoying rather than challenging. I hated that I had to constantly go back to areas to find Riddler trophies and interview tapes. I also really HATED the boss battle with Poison Ivy. Overall I think the vast majority of people are going to love this game, for me I found it to be middle of the road and it felt like I was always doing busy work with it. I'd give it a 7/10 overall and not something that I'll ever play again after I 100% it.

Still the golden standard for superhero games 14 years later, including the Spider-man games, and this game's own sequels. It's not without its flaws, mainly the boss fights which range from good to disappointing. Despite its short length, the game is still worth playing, especially if you mean to play the sequels. A personal golden note for me is how much these games lean on the detective angle for Batman. Truly a 9.5/10.

This is the first Batman game I played and WOW what a great game it was! I got hooked instantly and the combat gameplay is probably one of the best combat systems i have seen in a game. It was just very fun to punch the living crap out of the henchmen and bosses.

 I don't know if the AI is different in other difficulty settings but i played on hard (which is the most difficult one) and the AI for just simple thugs could sometimes kill the Batman, which often made for some good laughs. Nothing was as amusing as thinking you made an cool escape only to get sniped by a thug in the back. I might think that hard difficulty would not be so enjoyable for some players, but i personally really liked it. But i still suggest trying on medium on your first time.

 I never really delved into the Batman universe that much before but after playing this game i re watched the Nolan Batman trilogy and bought the other games in the Arkham series when they were on sale. I really liked finding the extras stuff like Character BIOS and voice logs which really got me interested in the Batman lore. 
The setting, the characters, the story feels sometimes very raw which i really like and it doesn't treat you like a helpless kid. Its gritty, atmospheric, entertaining and most of all fun to play. 

The only complaint i would have is that the ending kinda came out of nowhere and could have been a bit longer. It could feel a bit more climactic. Other than that solid game i highly recommend!

This game is a wonderful introduction to the Batman world for anyone who isn't familiar with the Batman universe beyond the live action movies. The gameplay, story, and even graphics have all aged well considering that this is a game from 2010. This game also has a reasonable amount of collectibles unlike the following games which go a bit too far for my liking. The pacing of the game is unlike anything I've ever played, you can easily spend hours in this game and not get bored. One downside to this game is the somewhat disappointing final boss, but it certainly didn't ruin the experience at all for me. The only other downside is that when it ends, you'll still want to keep playing. This game is an addiction.

Longtime Arkham fan here, I was having so much fun with this game until I started having internet problems. It makes zero sense for a single player game to require constant online connection in order for me to play it. Had I been playing in 2009 I would have no need to be connected to internet, why the sudden change? It is absolutely anti-consumer friendly and downright disgusting for WB games to require connectivity for this game. 
Is there some information I am missing? Are henchman not really AI, but rather WB employees controlling their every move behind the screen? is the map downloading in real time from the internet? Is the Riddler himself messing with my internet to prevent me from collecting all of his trophies, saving my game or just simply having a good time? 
If you are going to buy this game and have poor internet, buy a disk from ebay or something.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is really great at combining the Metroid-esque game mechanics, with combat and stealth elements to make this stand out. I played this on Xbox 360, and it was a fun game, so was eager to revisit this on PC.

I love the voice acting of Batman and Joker using the same actors from the Batman: Animated Series, the combat moves you employ and the gadgets you get to use to explore and fight with. The stealth takedown sections are the best bit - I just love how the enemies begin to panick, particularly in the later stages, to finding out one of their own was taken down by Batman.

Recommending this to those who love this sort of gameplay and the Batman franchise as well. My advice though: make certain to play this with a controller, as its more fun than with the keyboard controls.

My least favorite of the Arkham games, but a great start to the series. The best part about this game for me is the atmosphere and setting, it is done masterfully and better than some of the later games. I can't fault the game too much for combat and traversal since the devs immediately improved it in later installments. If you like batman, you'll surely like this game.

Aesthetically a very beautiful game. The voice acting for Joker and Harley Quinn is wonderfully done. You can see how much attention and money was put into making this game. Being an old game, the enemy variety is lacking significantly. Boss fights are more like a mini game rather than an actual fight. Which is my biggest gripe. But the combat is fun and implores you to find different ways to approach a situation with a wide selection of gadgets to try making you feel like The Batman.

Holy Bat-bananas, folks! If you've ever wondered what happens when you mix the World's Greatest Detective with a madhouse full of the craziest villains Gotham has to offer, look no further than Batman: Arkham Asylum. Spoiler alert: it's a riot!

The Bat-tastic Adventure:
So, picture this: Batman, looking all broody and cape-y, decides to take the Joker for a leisurely stroll to Arkham Asylum. I mean, what could possibly go wrong, right? Well, everything. It's like the Joker planned a surprise party for Bats, and by "surprise party," I mean he invited all his Arkham buddies to play a game of "Let's See Who Can Give Batman the Biggest Headache."

Bat-nanas Gadgets:
Let's talk gadgets. Batman's utility belt is basically the Swiss Army Knife of superhero accessories. Need to hack into a security system? Batarang! Need to take out a bunch of henchmen without breaking a sweat? Explosive Gel! It's like Batman went shopping at the "Bad Guys Be Gone" store, and everything was half off.

Arkham's Got Talent:
Now, let's talk about the inmates. Arkham Asylum is like the talent show from hell. You've got the Joker, who's basically a stand-up comedian with a really twisted sense of humor. Poison Ivy is there, making plants do her bidding. And let's not forget Killer Croc - a guy who takes "going green" to a whole new level. It's like the Justice League went on vacation, and Gotham's rogues' gallery decided to throw a party.

Detective Mode:
Oh, and Batman's Detective Mode? It's like his version of Insta-filter for crime scenes. He just puts on his super cool glasses, and suddenly, he can see footprints, analyze trajectories, and probably even tell you what the Riddler had for breakfast. It's almost unfair how good he is at crime-solving.

The Bat-voice:
Let's take a moment to appreciate Batman's gravelly voice. I mean, seriously, if I tried talking like that, I'd need a throat lozenge within five minutes. But Batman? He growls, and bad guys quiver in their mismatched socks. It's like having Clint Eastwood and a chainsaw in the same room.

Conclusion:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is like a wild night out in Gotham - full of crazy characters, mind-blowing gadgets, and enough bat-punching action to make you question why Batman doesn't have his own cooking show. If you haven't played it yet, do yourself a favor and dive into the madness. It's Bat-tastic!

Batman: Arkham Asylum is an action, adventure, fighting, beat 'em' up game and also the first game in the Batman Arkham franchise made in 2009 and then remastered in 2010. It is loved by the Batman Arkham community, just like the other games. Some community members say that Asylum is the second-best game right behind City. When it was released, reviewers called it ''The Greatest Comic Book Game of All Time'' and ''The Best Superhero Game of Modern Times'', and two of the games in the franchise - Asylum and City won a GOTY award in 2010 and 2011 respectively.

Pros: 
- Spooky Atmosphere, especially once you reach a certain point in the game where new enemies appear.
- Good Boss Battles (Most Notably - Ivy)
- Voice Acting (Joker, Batman, Ivy)
- Riddles are easier to find than in the other games
The soundtrack is really good (The Asylum Intercom Chime is iconic in this game and eerie)
- The Map is really good
- The Scarecrow Battles
- Character Design (Batman, Joker, Croc, Scarecrow)
- Doesn't take up a lot of space.
- Good graphics for a game that doesn't need a good pc.

Cons:
- Enemy Designs are just a copy and paste with the Joker goons wearing the same thing almost every time.
- They could've done something better with Harley's ''boss battle''.
- Glitches like enemies can spot you through walls or explosive gel not exploding through a destroyable wall (Only happened a couple of times)
- The only mission outside of the main story is Riddler and only Riddler.

Final Verdict -

Batman: Arkham Asylum is definitely one of the best games I have ever played. The graphics are outstanding - every detail of Gotham City is beautifully rendered and the animation is superb. In particular, the opening scene of Batman's journey into the depths of the asylum is incredibly atmospheric. The gameplay is also excellent, with a great variety of puzzles and fights, as well as some interesting boss-fights. The combat system is well designed and fun to master and the overall experience is highly immersive. The story is also gripping and filled with some great moments of suspense and drama. The game also has plenty of great side-quest and additional content, so there is definitely plenty of value in it. Overall, this title is an absolute must-have for any fan of Batman or action and adventure games. Highly recommended!

The game has a great story and the visuals in some ways are stilldecent, partly because it seems to be a hybrid between a drawn comic look and 3d models, but that's where the good stuff stops.

The controls are extremely clunky oftentimes I lose fights not because of wrong reactions, but because for example a dodge automatically targets nearby enemies to jump over them resulting in dodging into a line of fire instead of out of it. Also traversal controls suck, gliding is something that's ingame but you're better off not using and the grapple hook is only usable when standing firmly on the ground below a potential grappling point. 

Also the loading of the game is pretty bad, sometimes you load in with random spikes jutting through things.

But the biggest issue is that it needs to be constantly online but somehow doesn't properly register your connectivity so even if you have stable connection it still might constantly put you back in the main screen because of dropped connection. This bug makes the game borderline unplayable sometimes.

That said, the voice acting and art style for most things are great, though the models lack expressiveness and often have very weird body language for the conversations being held, so if it's on sale and you have the patience to not always being able to play it when you wish to, it might be fun to play when it's on at least a 50% sale.

Batman: Arkham Asylum - Be the Batman in a dark, atmospheric masterpiece. Combining stealth, combat, and detective work, it's an adventure that's both intense and intelligent. If you've ever dreamed of being the Dark Knight, this game lets you don the cowl and fight the most notorious villains in the asylum. It's Gotham like you've never seen it.
Don the guise of an aerial rodent and exercise your childhood trauma on a disturbed clown and his insane posse

This game delivers. Regardless of how much you like superheroes or not, if you like third person shooters and a bit of martial arts, this is for you.

This game has been designed with love and care. The plot is smart, not too much, not too small, just the good amount. Each character is well introduced and merges smoothly in the story. The lore is given with the correct amount. The level design is amazing. Progression curve is steady and based on skills more than overpower weapons. Each new power / weapon given will find a use. 

This is a great game. I am not a big fan of superheroes and i would have expected a better system to collect collectibles, but the rest of the game is love letter wipsered softly in my ear.
peak

I never bothered playing these games because game adaptions of movies tend to be cash grabs. Not only that, but when I picked up all 3 games together on sale I was considering skipping this one due to it's age, but I am so glad I didn't.

This game exceeded my expectations massively, its game-play and combat have aged amazingly and it was far more of a blast than I expected. A really cool cinematic experience that feels open yet linear at the same time.

Also the graphics hold up surprisingly well, especially the PhysX physics - the water and fog simulations look more realistic than a lot of games today. Scarecrows scenes with the non euclidean spaces are a trip.

All in all it reminds me that games used to be far less of an "industry" and more just really cool stuff being made by really talented people.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a legendary title that truly sets the standard for superhero-themed video games. As a devoted Batman fan, I couldn't have asked for a better interactive experience within the world of the Dark Knight.

The game's setting, Arkham Asylum itself, is a character in its own right. The eerie and foreboding atmosphere, combined with the Gothic architecture, makes for a perfect backdrop to this thrilling adventure. Exploring the asylum feels like a journey into madness, and it's filled with cleverly designed puzzles and hidden secrets.

The combat system is exceptional, allowing you to feel like the ultimate detective and martial artist. The fluidity of the combat, along with Batman's vast array of gadgets, keeps every encounter engaging and satisfying. The stealth gameplay is equally impressive, emphasizing the importance of strategy and cunning as you silently take down armed foes.

The story is where Arkham Asylum truly shines. It's a dark and gripping tale that brings together some of Batman's most iconic foes, with Mark Hamill's portrayal of the Joker being a standout performance. The voice acting and writing are top-notch, immersing you in a thrilling narrative that keeps you guessing at every turn.

The game's attention to detail and reverence for the source material is evident in every nook and cranny. Riddler trophies, patient interviews, and character profiles add depth to the experience, making you feel like the World's Greatest Detective.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a must-play not only for Batman fans, but for anyone looking for a phenomenal gaming experience. Embrace the darkness and dive into this extraordinary adventure in the shoes of the Dark Knight.

I'll be honest, I know I'm many, MANY years late on this, but I finally got around to playing this recently and I am so underwhelmed I needed to post about it should anyone else be in the same boat.

So upfront, I watched the live action show and cartoon as a kid, but beyond that I've not been huge into Batman since then, maybe that's my problem, but the amount of praise the game gets I'd expect it to hold up even without being invested in the franchise. Apparently not (for me at least).

If I had to use one word to summarise it all I'd say the game is "Repetitive" because so many times I found myself saying "oh this, AGAIN".

How many times do I need to fight enemies that need to be Batarang'ed as they charge, dodge and punch? How many times do I need to beat up wave after wave of random low level nobodies?
How many times do I need to fight [spoiler]Scarecrow[/spoiler]?

Honestly the idea that this game was a Game of the Year is more a damning statement about the quality of games the year it came out than about the quality of this game. I nearly uninstalled after the second [spoiler]Scarecrow[/spoiler] section because I just could not be bothered anymore, but I checked to see if I was anywhere near the end and apparently there wasn't too much left so I pushed on to see if it got any better and Jesus Christ the final boss fight was the most anti-climactic fight I think I have ever played.

The only thing I can think of that got this game so many good reviews (not just on Steam but in general) was because it was a super hero game and it was being judged against the quality of previous franchise tie in games.

Gameplay is good but prob the weakest in the arkham series. A must play for anyone looking for an immersive singleplayer experience.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a fantastic superhero action game set on the infamous prison island containing some of the most messed-up villains to ever trouble the good citizens of Gotham.  Of course, Batman's arch-enemy, Joker, is incarcerated here, and the story revolves around progressing through the prison, dealing with his henchmen and other super-villains such has Harley Quinn, Poison Ivy and Killer Croc.

The environments you move through are extremely well done, from the open spaces on the island between the prison buildings to the depths of the prison itself, which are dark, spooky and in some cases downright terrifying!  The Grapnel Gun allows freedom of movement to get to places where you can observe and plan your next encounter using your "detective vision".

You gain a formidable arsenal of toys to deal with you enemies, and they're all fun to play with.  The combat system allows you to chain together combos as you deal with groups of enemies.  It can be frustrating at times, but you soon get the hang of it.  The boss encounters will probably also take you several attempts as you learn the timing of their attacks, either countering with an attack of your own, or just getting out of the way!

Beyond the combat there are many collectables scattered across the game, including Joker Teeth, Riddler Trophies and interview tapes with some of Arkham's inmates.  Finding these gives you experience points that can be used to unlock weapon upgrades.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Still a great game.

I went back and played this game as I got it in a bundle on sale. I originally played this game back in 2012-ish and figured I'd give it a replay to see if it still holds up. It does, although the graphics are obviously a bit dated, it doesn't hold the game back at all as the voice acting and animations are still very well done. 

The gameplay is the tried and true 3rd person stealth/action beat-em-up that laid the formula for many successful franchises since. There are some gameplay and combat issues still present that  have  been cleaned up in more recent games that utilize the same mechanics, however it rarely becomes a major issue in the core gameplay loop. 

Would recommend anyone who is a fan of this style of games gives this one a go as it is an all time classic that still holds up.

I am not a DC fan (read as I really, really don't like DC), and I'm hardly interested in Batman. I am much more into Marvel (read as I really, really love Marvel). This game is borderline perfect. You don't have to be a Batman fan, just a fan of good video games to really enjoy Batman: Arkham Asylum. This game is from an era just before all the micro transaction/live services BS really started to take off and take hold of the mainstream market. It's a complete package from beginning to end with a solid amount of content that wraps up very nicely in the end. I got this game on sale for a meager 3 bucks, the price of a McChicken these days and had a blast. I bought it and gave it a shot more because I know the reputation it has and have heard great things about this game. Everyone was right, and I am horribly late to the party. 

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a metroidvania lite in a lot of good ways. This is a character action game first, and it really nails a good feel for the combat. The buttons make sense, the attacks thrown at you are well telegraphed, each combat encounter rewards your methodical approach rather than just button mashing. It feels great to control Batman. The developers did a great job of capturing "feeling like Batman". As you progress there will be areas and secrets inaccessible to you until you unlock certain equipment or upgrades. There is some clever back tracking, with a lot of surprising level design changes as you continue through your adventure. The enemy variety throughout the game is just right for the length of the total campaign and stayed fresh enough through my play through. Some combat encounters can be pretty boring, particularly against the over-sized brutes. But when you're fighting normal goons, exploring Arkham Asylum, and solving puzzles this game is amazing. The world design, art direction, and character acting are really good and serves to sell the immersion in a great way. Some cut-scene work is meh, but it never took away from enjoyment of the game and served just to be a quick stepping stone to the next thing.

I give Batman: Arkham Asylum a 9/10 and I can see my self coming back to play it again. The only thing really holding it back from a solid 10 is some of the combat encounters I could do without or should have been made more interesting. Otherwise, this is incredible game that everyone should give a play through.
i like the part where i beat  the mentally handicapped

It's good but I got a few little notes about it.

Some of the animations can't be stopped once you started them and can only be stopped until you wait the whole time or get hit by a goon. The guns are kinda op against Batman. 

SPOILER PART:
Boss fights were... Okay but needed more of everything. 
BANE: Bane is a pretty easy boss once you figure out what to do and what not to do, which makes sense cause he's the first boss.
Then they have like 5-6 bane remakes that you have to fight through the game which operate exactly like bane. Only difference between the drugged up goon fights and bane is that the drugged up goons normally have other goons with them. Got kinda boring having to keep fighting them.

SCARECROW: His "Fights" Are pretty much you running forward trying not to be seen by his light... That's pretty much it. You fight skeletons every so often, but they are easier to fight than goons. They also have skelly's that fight the same as jacked up goons, but are even easier to fight cause all you gotta do is dodge them once and they explode.

Harley Quinn: Legit just stay off the electro-floor and beat up goons.

CROC: Croc's fight is pretty much just walk on platforms (can't run or you'll die) And collect stuff. He'll pop up every so often, but all you gotta do is throw one batatararaang at him. I wouldn't really call it a boss fight.

IVY: Ivy has a lot of "Power" in  this game, and yet she's easy to fight. Legit dodge her easily dodge-able moves while spamming batarangs at her. Then place and explosive on her. You gotta do this whole things twice, but that's all her fight is.

JOKER: Joker's fight is by FAR the biggest JOKE of the whole game.. It's the last fight and yet is the easiest.... Like super easy.. He turns into a jacked joker and all you gotta to is dodge his attacks (like 5 attacks) then he will jump off the arena and send his men in. After spending like 1-2 mins killing his men, you pull him down and punch him. You do that whole thing 3 times. Doesn't get any harder tbh. You also get more health between the rounds, so it's even easier. 


That's the whole game, not very long. If you tried to speedrun it first time playing, you could beat it in 6h.
You could do it in that amount of time not speed running it, tbh. I got 8h while taking pause breaks and exploring. 


BUT, It wasn't bad and was good when it came out. Graphics aren't too old, game play isn't ... THAT bad, and batman still be doing bat things.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I played this game back in 2009 on the Xbox 360 and was blown away by how fantastic the graphics looked. This was one of the few games where it truly felt like a huge generational leap from the PS2/Xbox/Gamecube era. The combat was unlike anything I've ever seen at the time, and was one of the main draws for me. The graphics still hold up even to this day, especially when you look up close to the characters like the Joker and the attention to detail with his facial features. This game does a magnificent job of making you feel like Batman, everything from the combat to the grappling to sneaking up behind enemies and knocking them out cold. All of the gameplay elements are fused together so beautifully - platforming, beat-em-up, puzzle solving, treasure hunt, stealth...there's never a dull moment. The music is top notch, and really adds to the dark and gritty atmosphere. To hear the legendary Kevin Conroy voice as Batman is like premium icing on the cake. Overall, this is a brilliantly crafted game from start to finish.

This is a fantastic game, and is certainly the best superhero game I've ever played, (Although I haven't played the other Arkham games yet.) It looks great, especially for it's time, and it plays great as well. There are many different villains in this game, and they are all very fun to fight (especially Scarecrow and Poison Ivy). The only bad thing I can say isn't even about the game, but getting it to launch. The first time I tried to launch it, it showed me a .NET framework error, because I didn't have some older files that were required, but all I needed to do was go into the game files at this path: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Batman Arkham Asylum GOTY\redist\DirectX\DXSETUP.exe run the installer, and if you had the same error as me it should work. If that doesn't work, you may also need to download the .NET framework 3.5 from this link: [url=https://www.microsoft.com/en-ca/download/details.aspx?id=21] finally, if that still doesn't work, install the PhysX system software found at C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Batman Arkham Asylum GOTY\redist\

The game that launched the entire "Arkham" franchise is still a solid game to play through in 2023.

The gameplay and controls make the game a real treat to play as you battle your way through Joker's minions and the released Arkham inmates.

The only difficulty I encountered was getting this game to run. You will need to check out some tutorials on Youtube, depending on the problem you come across installing or launching the game.

Some glitches I came across:

1) Having to reload your saved file again when the game does not load the graphics correctly

2) The floating leaves that are supposed to be on the floor of the Arkham Aviary

Despite the minor glitches, I was able to finish the game. Other game modes, such as survival, challenges, etc., all worked like a charm with no issues.

Note: There is no joker for you to play as in survival mode, despite this being the GOTY edition (Joker was a PS exclusive, unfortunately).

Batman:Arkham Asylum is a must-play for me. Combat, while easy for me now as I have been playing through this game so many times(which probably should explain my liking for it), still offers a satisfying experience in superhero battle design. Stealth can be enjoyed too. I will say that it's not as dynamic as say, Splinter Cell(the original), as for example the player is unable to hide bodies and noise can be avoided at all the right time if you know when to stop running and when to crouch. It's a simple system of stealth considering stealth-based games I've played in the past. However, gunfire from the armed guards Batman is up against will always pack a punch to the player's HP, even if they manage to barely survive the stealth room by fighting their way through which I don't is possible? I mean, at least not very consistently. Of course, here's a pro tip, singling out the guards will leave the one defenseless and completely open to a trial by combat approach. Try not to be in their line of sight however if you want to do him a "PERFECT K.O.". Overall, Batman:Arkham Asylum is a mechanically simple game when you narrow it down. Yet, it remains satisfying and there is also plenty of depth to be mined out of it. You will be punished appropriately if you approach groups of enemies incorrectly and sneaking can be heavily punished if done poorly. However, when those things are done right, it's incredibly satisfying. It always feels great whenever I am able to quickly and handily dismantle a room full of armed henchmen or defeat all enemies in an encounter with as little difficulty as possible. It, without question, can make you feel like Batman. Play it well, and you are for sure worthy of taking control of the Caped Crusader himself. Excellent.

Arkham Asylum is such a gem of a game, especially for being 14 years old. The combat system is something that really defines the Batman games. Other than that, the game has a great story, awesome voice acting [b]*cough*[/b] [i]Mark Hamill as The Joker[/i] [b]*cough*[/b] and is just overall a great experience that you don't wanna miss out on!

A game from 2010 that supports ultrawide, has no bugs and has a loot of fan service? Well just that earns a recommendation from me, but lets talk a bit more about it.

Batman Arkham Asylum is a cult classic, but hear my opinion on it as an outsider.
I like the old batman movies, but I wouldn't class myself as a batman fan.
Having said that, I found the game to be good, maybe not amazing, but definitely good enough to warrant a playthrough.
The gameplay is interesting and varied, you unlock new tools as you progress that give you more options for traversal and the ability to reach places that you couldnt before. It all uses the same map, but you just get higher levels of access with time.
The story is relatively simple, but there is a lot of fan service for people that have read the old comics, so this will be lovely for fans of batman (though one could argue that there maybe was a bit too much fan service? I'll leave that for you to decide). 
The graphics have aged like fine wine since the artstyle still feels very relevant for a comic book superhero game.

The only two real issues (albeit minor) I had were related to - the voice acting (seems like the audio captured was low bitrate or something else, but batmans voice specifically sounds scuffed) and the amount of one liner dialogue (honestly, a little cringe).

Having said all of that, I still enjoyed the game. It didn't overstay its visit, clocking in at around 12 hours for me (ignoring the idle time and bonus content) and was a nice change of cpace compared to big bombastic open world games of today.
You can usually get it at a huge discount as well so its a no brainer, give it a try!

As someone who has played many games over the years, I found Batman: Arkham Asylum to be a fantastic and engaging experience. The gameâ€™s mature themes and intricate storyline were a refreshing change from the often simplistic storytelling found in many modern games.

The gameâ€™s mechanics are well-designed, striking a good balance between challenge and accessibility. The combat system is intuitive and deep, allowing for strategic planning and execution. The stealth elements are particularly satisfying, requiring patience and careful observation.

The graphics are impressive, even years after its initial release. The dark and gritty atmosphere of Arkham Asylum is beautifully rendered, immersing you in the world of Batman. The attention to detail in the environment and character designs adds depth to the gaming experience.

The voice acting is top-notch, with Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill reprising their roles as Batman and Joker, respectively. Their performances add authenticity to the game and enhance the narrative.

However, as an older player, I found some aspects of the game to be a bit challenging. The fast-paced combat sequences can sometimes be overwhelming, especially during boss fights. Additionally, some puzzle elements require quick reflexes, which can be a bit tricky for some older gamers.

Despite these challenges, I appreciate the gameâ€™s difficulty settings, which allow you to customize the gameplay experience to your skill level. This feature makes the game accessible to players of all ages and abilities.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum - Game of the Year Edition for PC is an incredibly well-crafted game that offers a rich narrative, engaging gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals. Itâ€™s a game that caters to its mature audience and provides a rewarding experience for those willing to immerse themselves in its dark and complex world.

Batman Arkham Asylum is an old game that has surprisingly aged well, but doesn't really stand up to the rest of the games in the series.

Batman Arkham Asylum's graphics look surprisingly good for a game that is this old. Characters have great designs that clearly showcase their personalities. The animations in this game also look pretty good. Sound design is pretty great. Hearing the crunches and cracks as you beat up enemies is greatly satisfying. Music here is really good as well and switch very smoothly from one another. The atmosphere presented by asylum is absolutely amazing and truly makes you feel the brutality of where you are. The art for this game is also pretty good.

Gameplay is good, but there are some flaws here and there. The combat is great, as it makes you feel like a dangerous martial artist. Attacks feel heavy and satisfying. Inputs are responsive, but sometimes when you throw a punch, Batman will just randomly swing a punch in the air when there is an enemy right next to him. The stealth sections are by far the best part of this game. Using your gadgets to gain an advantage over enemies and seeing their heart rate increase as the odds get turned against them truly makes you feel like a dangerous skilled assassin. Unfortunately these sections are few and far in between. The boss fights in this game are a mixed bag tho. Bane is way to simple to be fun, Killler Croc is way too easy, and the joker is just three waves of enemies. The only good boss is poison ivy. Puzzles are alright. Most of the puzzles that you will be solving is finding Riddler trophies. Luckily these are optional and they aren't as annoying and as common as they are in the rest of the series.

The story here is alright. Characters are interesting and well voiced by their voice actors. Unfortunately the overall story is a bit generic and weird decisions are often made by characters in the game. My favorite part though is the lore set up by this universe. The tapes that you collect during the game lets you listen to a therapy session that the villains went through and they are absolutely amazing and give you a great idea of how these characters think.

Overall, while there are some flaws here and there, this game is still really good and holds up quite well today, but don't expect it to be as good as the other games in the series.
