Title: An Absolute Masterpiece of the Batman Universe

Batman: Arkham Asylum is an absolute triumph in the world of video games, offering a thrilling and immersive experience that does justice to the iconic Dark Knight. From the moment I started playing, I was captivated by its gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and impeccable gameplay.

One of the standout features of Arkham Asylum is its exceptional storytelling. The game kicks off with Batman delivering the Joker to Arkham Asylum, but things quickly spiral out of control as the Clown Prince of Crime takes over the facility. The plot is filled with unexpected twists, keeping players on the edge of their seats throughout the game. The dialogue and voice acting are top-notch, with Mark Hamill's Joker and Kevin Conroy's Batman delivering unforgettable performances that rival their work in the animated series.

Visually, Arkham Asylum is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in the asylum's dark and foreboding corridors, as well as in Batman's suit and gadgets, is outstanding. The character models are incredibly lifelike, and the animation is smooth, which enhances the overall immersion.

The gameplay in Arkham Asylum is where the game truly shines. The combat system is both accessible to newcomers and rewarding for veterans, allowing players to feel like the caped crusader as they seamlessly chain together combos and counterattacks. Batman's arsenal of gadgets is vast and enjoyable to use, whether it's the grappling hook, batarangs, or the detective vision that lets you investigate crime scenes. The stealth mechanics are equally engaging, making it just as satisfying to stalk and subdue enemies in the shadows as it is to engage in all-out brawls.

The game also provides ample opportunities for exploration and puzzle-solving. The Riddler's challenges scattered throughout the island add an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, encouraging players to use their detective skills to solve riddles and collect trophies.

In addition to the main story, the game offers a plethora of side missions and unlockable content that extends its replayability. Arkham Asylum provides a rich and immersive experience that keeps players coming back for more.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a triumph of game design and a must-play for both Batman fans and gamers in general. Its compelling narrative, stunning visuals, and impeccable gameplay combine to create an unforgettable experience that truly captures the essence of the Dark Knight. If you haven't experienced this masterpiece yet, do yourself a favor and dive into the world of Arkham Asylum; you won't be disappointed.

I loved it. While I did not play the Batman : Arkham series by Rocksteady Games in the proper order, I must say that I enjoyed the game. Perhaps, it's the world of Batman that has evolved over the years to give a sense of coolness. Originally created by Bob Kane and Bill Finger, the Arkham series is a far cry from the comical hijinks of the 1960s TV series and its silly "nena-nena-nena-nena-nena-nena-nena-nena-Batman" jingle (Yes, there are 8 nenas, I counted). The characters no longer take on the comical TV villain and are now fleshed out as the hardened versions as written by Paul Dini. The design of the characters in the Arkham series is solid. The villains take centre stage when they lose their cartoonish image and have a more "hardened criminal" look and feel. 

Gameplay-wise, you will find that it is similar throughout the series. In Arkham Asylum, you will lack the ability to free fly around the map but it's not much of an issue. Some of the most ridiculous things tend to be the duck walking through vents. As you know, ventilation ducts do not support an adult human male's weight. It is a common issue with Square Enix games like Deus Ex. It is like a running joke but whatever. The human sized ventilation ducts is kind of their thing now. It's the kind of thing that makes you go, "WTF, oh it must be Square Enix again!". Combat is simple and easy to pick up in all the series, just press left-click and right click at the correct times while facing the right direction and enemies go down. Sometimes, you wish that you could turn off the lights and play stealth or use smoke bombs (like in the cartoon series).

Conclusion, do try the entire series from start to end as the Batman : Arkham games progress in a linear fashion (Don't be too caught up with the word "linear", most good vs evil stories are linear). It's the first in the series and it helps to build up the story.

Note: Rocksteady Games is a British video game developer based in Kentish Town, London. It was founded by Sefton Hill and Jamie Walker. It is majority owned by Time Warner with Square Enix (Eidos Interactive) holding roughly 25%.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Arkham Character Design
I loved it. It's the most interesting Batman design out of all the various permutations of Batman.

2. Arkham Story
I played the Arkham series not in the proper order but the story was great. Telling the dark history of Arkham was great too.

3. Riddler Puzzles
Those riddles were pretty good. The trophy pick up sucked.

4. History of Arkham
I loved that part too.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Bugs
Some parts of the game require prior steps in order to proceed. However, the game skips steps and halts the games progress, forcing you to go back to comple a step. E.g. Dr Young's fingerprints scan can be skipped first.

2. Repetitive Mechanics
Every single Titan is just Bane. Charge, Batarang, jump out of the way, crash. Rinse and repeat. You wonder if Bane was even a boss fight?

3. No Batmobile and Batwing
It's the expectation.

4. Riddler Trophies
I don't really enjoy picking up question marks and having to ask how they got there in the first place. It destroys the whole story and the game logic. Like how and why does Riddler manage to put trophies on a rock outcrop? Or why does he place them behind a weakened structural wall? It feels like a very lazy way of just creating pick ups in the map.

5. Joker Teeth
They do absolutely nothing but chatter. Couldn't they explode when you step on them or warn the goons that you're near? You just hit them for achievement purposes.

[h1][b]NEUTRAL[/b][/h1]
1. Combat
You must take out all the enemies. Why can't you choose not to? There's a level where you can access the security system out of range of the enemies. Why do I need to KO every single one of them?

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Turning off the Lights
That's how it's supposed works for Batman, right? "I am the terror that flaps in the night!"

2. Improved Riddler Puzzles
In the story, you could make it so that Riddler could be playing both sides. He's helping out both Batman and villains but he's profiting from it. He wants to be the real mastermind, which is in character. I'd prefer this to the whole childish playground, "I'm smarter than you" gag.

3. Gadgets
Try to combine them into one. The high-powered Batclaw is a great idea. You have a whole arsenal of weapons that you can create.

4. Playin as the villains
After watching the Joker DLC, I would love to play the villains in the game. That is an entire list of content to play with. Can you imagine Scarecrow, Croc or Penguin modes? However, not interested in paying for DLC. It could even link to multiplayer modes for longevity.

I was late to the party with playing the Batman Arkham Series but man did I miss out. This game came out in 2010 and is amazing to play. I enjoy the play style with use of multiple gadgets and different fighting combos. I grew up with the Batman animated series and having Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill voice acting made this game 100/100.

Everything that can be said about this game can most likely be said about City, Origins, And Knight. The combat, the story, the voice acting, the progression, the bosses, the music, Ar challenges, and the environment are significantly better in its sequels, but that does make Arkham Asylum any way bad. All those things I mentioned are all good in this game, but when you play the sequels; looking back on Arkham Asylum just doesn't feel the same as when you first played it.

There are some things  in my opinion that haven't been upgraded upon. That to me is the Scarecrow fights and the 3rd wall breaks. I know they've been similarly done in Origins and Knight, but I think that Asylum did a fantastic job on these parts. The Riddler challenges are fine but also boring; not much of a challenge; its really just you going back to places you've already been, but with more items.

Batman Arkham asylum is a good game to start the Arkham series with, and should be played by all to really appreciate on how the sequels have improved.

Great first game in the franchise. You are batman.

Arkham Asylum is the most atmospheric game in the Arkham Series. The game is inspired by the Batman graphic novel, Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth by Grant Morrison. The Game has a very Gothic Vibe with its tone and atmosphere, and the passion of the devs can be easily felt. The Combat System called the "Freeflow System" which revolutionized combat in action games first appeared here and is like a rhythm game so it is a bit dated compared to the later entries. The Boss fights are the only weak point in this game. The Game is stuffed with Easter Eggs and References from the wider Batman Mythos and is absolutely a blast to explore and find out in the game. A Solid 9 out of 10 from me.

[h1]It Makes You [i]Feel[/i] Like Batman[/h1]

Given the quality of games these days, in the fine year of 2023, it's truly hard to believe that this game came out in 2009. I missed this game on release because I was a broke college student, but have memories of everyone saying how good it was. And they were right! They're still right! This game aged remarkably and hearkens back to an era when we were drowning in solid new releases. An era that would soon be coming to an end. 

[h1]Where to Begin...[/h1]

There is so much to praise about this game: Fluid combat and movement. Good mix of combat, puzzle solving and platforming. Insanely good atmosphere. Great takes on classic Batman villains. Not too short, not too long. There's not a whole lot to really complain about (and I'll get to that). It's an all around good, engrossing experience that begs you to keep playing.

Back in 2009, [i]Arkham Asylum[/i] introduced an innovative combat system. Everything was streamlined. No complicated combos to memorize. Everything was contextualized. By doing this, players can easily take 
 control of Batman and acrobatically beat the pulp out of Joker's thugs. It just feels right as you see Batman effortlessly gliding through and between enemies, delivering punches left and right, occasionally having to counter, throwing the occasional baterang - or three. It all holds up nearly 15 years later. 

As the world's greatest detective, you'll also be challenged to solve puzzles, mysteries, and riddles. This is again another area Rocksteady streamlined. Anytime you need to figure something out, you just go into detective mode and stuff gets highlighted. Admittedly, this got stale after a while, but the middle ground would be tough to find. If you make puzzles too challenging, a lot of players will get frustrated and quit. If you dumb it down anymore, you remove the challenge all together. It gives you something to do where you can put in minimal effort and get rewarded. For [i]Arkham Asylum[/i], it needs some mechanic like this, as otherwise there would be no incentive to explore the island.

Lastly, I want to throw some praise at the atmosphere and mood of this game. Arkham is a dark place. There is not one trace of anything other than evil and depravity. As you explore the asylum, you pick up interviews with inmates and messages from the founder. From these stories it becomes immediately clear that there are no good guys at Arkham. Coupled with the detailed environments around the island, which were clearly inspired by psychiatric hospitals c.1930, exploring the asylum fills one with a sense of unease.

[h1]Minor Criticisms[/h1]

There isn't much bad to be said about this game, at least not from a design perspective. Fights with the Titan Henchmen, for example, were easily the weakest part of the game. One is introduced early on and then they aren't seen again for a while. The basic premise of these fights is simple, but they include my least favorite mechanic: Waiting.

The Titan Henchmen fight cycle is as follows:
-Wait for Titan to charge
-Quick throw baterang and dodge
-Titan hits wall, gets disoriented
-Avoid and wait for Titan to go back to normal state
-Repeat until you can knock him out

It's a lot of waiting. And then you get sections where there are multiple Titans, or multiple Titans with 10 other basic henchmen. In these cases when you knock a Titan down you can at least ride it and make it thrash around and hit enemies, but even then it's not that satisfying.

Having said all that, while I was playing I realized that nevertheless, the design choice to make you square off against 2 Titans and 10 henchmen is interesting in theory. To fight a Titan you have to wait. But you can't wait when you 10 guys all trying to attack you at once.  I really commend the idea of making a player perform 2 diametrically opposed tasks at the same time. Love the idea. Hated it in practice.

The only other issues I had were technical and I chalk them up to this game being old. Problems I experienced:
-Game freezing at start menu, forced restart
-Occasional bad input lag
-Stopped getting achievements for some reason

[h1]Overall[/h1]

Solid game. Definitely recommend. Still amazing to me that this, a game that came out in 2009, looks, runs, and feels better than pretty much everything that's come out in the last 10 years. [b]8/10.[/b]
This game, despite its age, is still one of the most fun games I've ever played. The atmosphere, game play and game mechanics all make it a very engaging game, action and detective wise.

The start of a wonderful franchise.
I just played it for the first time on PC. I had played this previously on Xbox around when it came out. This games still holds up after over 10 years.

This game is awesome in so many ways. It's just too short. Arkham City fixes that issue a bit, except that it kind of does it by way of adding a bunch of grindy side missions. That said, I'd much rather solve Riddler's puzzles in City over searching through all of Arkham Asylum again. I really hated the map design and found Asylum kind of a chore to navigate. At times, it kind of made me want to quit and move on to City.

The aesthetic of the game holds up, even ten years later. This game is truly a piece of art, and I don't think many games are like that. The mechanics are pretty good, just unrefined. You can see why City became so much better. Directional jumping is problematic in this game, which is mostly fine... except that there are a few platforming sections where it's really bothersome.

The one area where this game has City beat is in its story, which I think is way more interesting. Joker gets himself locked into Arkham Asylum, escapes, and begins reaping havoc. That story is way more interesting than City, which is a kind of half-baked superhero plot about Strange trying to control Arkham City/Gotham. I also think that there are too many enemy types in City. But that's for a different review.

All in all, this is a great game that's worth playing. It's just definitely NOT worth collecting all of the Riddler trophies because it's not worth working your way through the maze-like map.

I can count on one hand, maybe two hands all the games I would call "masterpiece". This game (and its sequel) is one of them. 14 years later and this game still eclipses every single other superhero game out there. This is comfortably the best superhero game ever made. It is one of the best action games ever made. Its influence is still widely seen today.

Every once in a while a game comes along that innovates, changes up how things work, changes up gaming in general (e.g. Dark Souls - Soulslike genre). Arkham Asylum did just that back in 2009. Shortly after its release, we saw the first copycats emerge in the form of Shadow of Mordor and Mad Max, nowadays by the Spiderman games. All these games are imitators of the original. Not so impressive.

On top of that innovation, it still holds up visually, because of the stellar art design. Then you have the great stealth combat, the metroidvania level design that encourages backtracking, the immersive atmosphere, the excellent narrative, the fantastic character design, it all culminated into a true masterpiece and one of the very few games in existence that genuinely deserves a 10/10 score.

Batman: Arkham Asylum was an absolute revelation for me as a newcomer to the world of Batman games. It effortlessly weaves together a captivating story with thrilling gameplay. The dark and mysterious setting of Arkham Asylum provided the perfect backdrop for Batman's intense adventure, even though I was new to this universe. The combat system felt incredibly fluid and satisfying, making me genuinely feel like the caped crusader while taking on hordes of enemies. The storyline was expertly crafted, immersing me in a psychological thriller as Batman faced off against iconic villains like the Joker. I appreciated how the game struck a perfect balance between action and stealth, and the intricate puzzles kept me engaged throughout. As someone who had never experienced the Batman world before, this game was an absolute must-play, delivering an unforgettable experience that fully introduced me to the essence of the Dark Knight's universe.

A real Batman experience within the walls of Arkham Aslyum

This is the quintessential manbat game if there ever was one. We get to see Arkham Asylum in all its gothic grotesquery, sneak around choking out perps dressed in tights and if that fails beating up hordes of working class goons that never got a fair chance to break the mold and join the wealthy middle class of Gotham.. The island where the titular Arkham Asylum is located is quite a sandbox filled with nooks and crannies where you can lurk upon your enemies or find the hidden psycho-paraphernalia. The story is nothing fantastic but fits the bill.. Joker gets put under lock and key, but wait! It was a master plan all along and now he controls the asylum! Luckily ManBat happens to be right there to save the day! On the way we run into a brief yet regular entourage of famous villains and monsters from the comics. It didn't bother me even though I always find body morphology in these kinds of games jaring..  

So yea, Batman Arkham Asylum is a great game and if nothing else a damn fine example of a stealth game done right. Combine that with a fluent, almost rhythm game based combat that looks truly cinematic at times and you get a dark and brooding ballet of chokeholds, batarangs, anti-shark sprays and mighty roundhouse kicks that put Chuck Norris to shame. If you like Batman on top of it all, I imagine it is even better. Itâ€™s always great to find a game that acknowledges the sneaky rat that lives in my brain!

[u]In a nutshell:[/u] The Batman game, that started the Arkham legend.

The first game in the action-brawler Arkham series, laying the foundation on which the other three games are built. The controls may not be as sophisticated and polished as in the later games, but everything has to start somewhere. The combat is not my favourite part of the game, but the Dark Knight's movement and the gadgets feel absolutely awesome. The story is fascinating, with lots of little twists and turns, and features one of the most mind-bending 4th wall-breaking scenes in the entire gaming industry (Scarecrow's fear toxin).

[u]Recommended if:[/u] You like a dark detective story, an interesting take on well-known comic characters, and if you want to meet your favourite comic characters animated and voiced with a great attention to detail.
[u]Not recommended if:[/u] You are an achievement hunter, as most of the challenges feel not only hard, but also tedious and repetitive.

Bioshock came out 2 years before Baman Arkham Asylum, and it's very much the same game: you explore an abandoned facility run by violent wackos, you acquire new toys and powers as you go, and you fight bosses. The bonus is that Paul Dini from BTAS wrote the script, and the key actors from BTAS do the voice acting. How could they blow it? Ugliest art direction, absurd character models, the absolute worst level design. Pacing is also dreadful, a total slogfest.
Very good game

Well where do I start, it's the game that started it all and has a long everlasting legacy along with a major influence on action title these days. I played it after five years and it still holds up to this very day in the world where Spider-Man only stands as its competitor. If I am here to tell you about how good this title is I would be here all day but there are very indigenous flaws. Being the prototype and the blueprint of free flow combat it requires polish and some finesse. You get to have a pure skill if you want to go to a combo of 50 along with other aspects the traversal is also weak which is a minor gripe of mine as it harbors a metroidvania esque level design but overall this game is a masterpiece and ideal piece for the developers of the new gnereation. Oh btw atmosphere is really gnarly and horrific because of the comic it takes cues from.

This is the perfect game for a Batman fan!

This action beat'em up with stealth elements, puts you in Batman's boots after taking Joker into custody and sending him back "Home" to Arkham, but this time things are different, as this time the Joker has devised a plan to take over Arkham. 
Has the Joker trapped you inside with all of them? or are they the ones trapped in there with you?
This adventure will take you to meet and fight some of Batman's most iconic villains, Even getting to learn more about their story in the form of collectibles.
While I played on keyboard and mouse (without the option to remap keys), the game felt well enough to play and enjoy, still I would recommend using a controller.
The idea of having real riddles to solve and not only puzzles or mini games really made you feel like a detectiveâ€¦ most of the time.

There was no yank apart from the odd getting stuck in geometry, but it never became a problem.
And while sometimes it felt like Batman had a mind of his own doing stuff unprompted or the wrong prompt thing being done, apart from it breaking a perfectly good combo or leaving an open for my enemies to attack me, I didn't rage as much as I thought I would so it wasn't that disruptive.

[h1]Action[/h1]

One of the best first installation of an action adventure series in recent years, adapted from comics no less! The freeflow combat system (originated from the Arkham series) is already perfected in this first game. You also get some gadgets for personalised fighting styles. Scripted stealth events and investigations are more emphasised in the first game during which you have to use the Detective Mode for clues, but the mode is so powerful (you can see through all obstacles, find all the thugs in the room and the clues are highlighted) that I think all players spend most of time in it.

This game might not be as polished as its sequel Arkham City. The way I see it, Asylum is made for hardcore Batman fans while City is made for mainstream gamers. The attention to detail is amazing: like the art style and animations of the characters, which are very faithful to the original work. The game is dark and is designed to make you feel isolated and helpless in a locked down Asylum.

I would heartily recommend this game to anyone, not just fans of Batman.

best batman game

Hands down a must play. Easily one of the finest games ever made.

That might sound like hyperbole, but I assure you that everything comes close to making a perfect game.

You don't need to be a Batman fanatic to enjoy this, it'll show you all that you need to understand Batman, his allies and his enemies. The characterization on display is flawless with what it works with. Further, it does it without stopping the game and doing a lore dump on you. The people and their reactions to each other tells you everything.

The combat is the right amount of hectic. The different varieties of enemy have a good amount of variety while still being a reasonable challenge. Rifles, fists, stun batons...lunatics, maximum security inmates, hulking mutants, mutant plants...it all sounds like it should fall apart under its weight, but the game keeps things varied, interesting and, most importantly, doable. Beautiful...

Arkham Asylum might just be the best Metroidvania, too. The map isn't ridiculously huge, but it seems vast and imposing enough when you start. The story masterfully takes you through different locations and, as you get more gear and hence "unlock" new areas, it'll take you back through many places. Further, it'll keep things fresh as the island you're on steadily falls further into chaos through the night.

It isn't perfect or flawless, nothing is, but Arkham Asylum is must-play gaming. Nothing less. Any clunk or frustration is mitigated by a forgiving checkpoint system and fun gameplay, glued together with an interesting and engaging story.

It's an absolute gem in my Steam library and I believe it can be for your collection as well.
One of the greatest games ever made. An absolute classic, and I believe everyone should play it at least once.

It is really a stealth game much of the time and the combat, while fluid and beautiful, is pretty shallow. The combat is super easy at first, but ramps up as more basic enemies are introduced; good mix of brainless beat 'em up and difficulty. The graphics look dated but still great, even in 2023. The story feels like it comes out of a comic book and is fairly linear (not a bad thing) so it keeps things moving (it is only about 11 hours). The Controls are not great (maybe even bad in a few scenes), but serviceable; there is far too much reliance on spacebar to do 90% of the actions which makes it sometimes frustrating when you want to do A but the game does B.

This game is the godfather of basically every brawler in the last 14ish years and there is a good reason. I start the review this way because this is the most important thing to remember when you're playing this game. This game started the entire "counter-punch" system of combat that games to this day still use. And it feels almost as good in this game as it does in any of the games that copy it's design, even games made almost a decade and a half later.

There's a ton of great things to say here about the game. The story is a classic Batman romp. The graphics are great for the time. The voice acting, especially by Hamill and Conroy (RIP), is beyond amazing. And the music is just timeless. There's even a million and one collectables to collect if that's your thing.

But the biggest thing this game gets right is none of that. It's that this game makes you FEEL like Batman. You're big, your punches have weight. You are a complete badass. You can sneak and be stealthy terror. You can deduce (Detective Vision is yet another way this game shaped the industry, for the worse IMO, but still). You have an array of useful gadgets. But eventually you'll HAVE to punch. And when you punch, you feel the power behind those fists.

And that's truly this game's biggest strength. Which makes it the biggest weakness from a modern perspective as well. This combat has been done better since. Of course it has. Companies have had almost 14 years to perfect it. But that should in no way diminish this game or what it accomplished and in no way means you shouldn't still play this classic.

[b][h1]The start to one of the pillars of gaming franchises. [/h1] [/b]

The Batman Arkham franchise is without a doubt one of the best video game franchises ever to be made. It has set the bar for so many games like it such as the recent spider-man games as well as non-superhero games such as Shadow of Mordor. The games story, while basic in the eyes of comic fans and superhero enthusiasts, is a solid way to introduce the characters, world, and lore in a way thar is a breath of fresh air for Batman fans. The gameplay and characters really build this game up in ways that I haven't seen done quite as well since. While some aspects such as the sometimes rigid ways the combat system throws you at enemies or the infamous poison Ivy Boss fight didn't age quite as well they don't hurt the game enough to do anything. Definitely pick the entire series up if you can as you will have the greatest gaming experience you will ever have.

I'm Batman

I love the Arkham series. The games have fantastic stealth mechanics and gorgeous graphics. Even this 10 year old game looks beautiful, it could pass as a modern title. Except for maybe the faces of minor characters.

This is the shortest Arkham game, but it's also the densest. Small map, but full of life.

Worst part of the game is Poison Ivy. Her chapter of the story is easily the worst because it has a bunch of the most tedious parts of the game all in a row (The slow as hell sewer level with Killer Croc, the orb spitting plants, several sections that make you backtrack to places that you already explored). 

Also, her entire character is just "sex appeal" and "Wa hah hah I want to take over the city because I am evil". Her boss fight is awful, too. 

Alternatively, Harley is a fantastic character and I really wish they did more with her. I felt legitimately bad for her at certain moments in the game. Wish they had done less with Ivy and more with her.

And of course Joker is great, his chatter over the Arkham intercom is funny and never gets old. Scarecrow is great, too.

I had fun.
Is there a lore reason why Man didn't smash Ivy? Is he stupid?

A lot of people recommended me to play this game as it was called the trademark of "Amazing close combat" design and story in all Batman games.

First let me start by saying I am not a DC/Marvel or Super Hero fan at all, I don't like any of them and I don't enjoy any of their origins or stories. Except Batman Begins and Tim Burton Batman films I did not find any of them anything interesting and I have never read the comics.

Let's start with the positive:
The game has an old school feeling, it doesn't guide you to do everything step by step like most modern games and you do need to do some exploration yourself which is something that is missing in modern gaming cause every path and objective is always marked 10000 times to make sure even if you are blind you still see it and won't lose your way to it.

The scarecrow encounters. These encounters are actually brilliant, it gives you a completely different type of old school 2D platformer feeling in the middle of a 3rd person game and it is basically fantastic and shows a really good game/level design behind it.

The levels that all the enemies are armed with guns forces you to find a stealth pattern to take them out in correct order and it also gives a lot of creativity to the player which is really impressive.

And that is pretty much where the positive ends.

To the negative:
1. Close combat is pain in the butt (I played the game on hardest mode) it is extremely punishing if you do one incorrect move during combat and that being said it actually is a good thing but the problem begins with the game not registering your input correctly when you wanna do something else and it does something else and you end up dying to an action you never wanted to make at first place.
The close combat moves are really simple and boring and repetitive. There is only one attack button and one parry button and guess what... NO BLOCK button! Yes you heard me right, in a game that is mainly based on melee combat you do not have ANY block button.

Now let's compare other games like Metal Gear Rising to this, that game has stealth but it is not the focus, it is mainly and only designed for close combat and it is older than this game. You have maybe 10 different attack moves and 3 different defensive moves in addition of block button and parry button. And each of them on bound to different inputs not ONE for everything like this hot garbage Batman game here.

2. Locomotion and movement is extremely terrible. Batman is always in "slow walk" mood, you are in middle of boss fight and well his default walking style is "slow walk" you need to press that sprint button with all your fingers to make sure this batbaby starts to run. And that is if you do not get hit by some goon and get a "hit reaction" which resets you back to "slow walk" mood and then another goon comes and hits you again and half of the game boss fight turns to you fighting your keyboard to make this sprint work.

3. Level design and boss fights are extremely repetitive. I basically gave up the game right before Poison Ivy boss fight and watched the rest on YouTube to see the story. You get a boss fight with Bane and literally the rest of the boss fights except Ivy is exactly the same, some titan goon attacks you and 20000 minions spawn. Even the final boss fight is the same, Joker turns to titan and the same story again he sends his goons you need to fight the same guys over and over again until you have opportunity to attack himself then repeat for 3 more times.

4. Story: I honestly did not understand anything about the story but maybe it is because I have no idea about DC universe.

THERE IS A FIX FOR MOUSE SENSITIVITY/ACCELERATION!

Go to this path: C:\Users\[my pc name]\Documents\Square Enix\Batman Arkham Asylum GOTY\BmGame\Config\bminput.ini

put your pc name in, and open the input. Change the sensitivity to what you like and turn mouse acceleration to "false"

I enjoyed that a lot more than I expected to. Couldn't care less about the IP or superhero stuff in general. The story, admittedly, reinforced the reasons I don't generally care for the genre (vapid 'good' and 'bad' with flimsy backstories which fail to introduce any sense of moral ambiguity, with villains acting that way because "they're fuckin' mental innit mate". With that being said, my view on that probably shouldn't be of interest to fans of the franchise, or comics/superheroes generally, and I did enjoy passages about alteration of perception/loss of sanity involving the Scarecrow character.

What you do have is an extremely solid action-stealth-fighter thing which caused my eight-hour playthrough to pass in a single sitting without me noticing it had become 2am. It's unusual for games to do all of those aspects well so the fact that you have stealth which feels rewarding when you get it right, intuitive and punchy (no pun intended) fighting mechanics and boss fights which feel (mostly) unique without inventing entirely new mechanics for the player to use is a real positive.

It's not a long game, but being Â£14.99 when it's not on sale, it provides excellent VFM nevertheless. For those inclined there are collectables (with discoverable maps hinting at where they are and removing markers when found - I am now going to be disappointed whenever a game has collectables without a system like this), as well as an infinite challenge mode to play wish associated achievements.

In general, normal difficulty is probably a little on the easy side - I died/failed less than a dozen times during my playthrough and I'm far from an expert - but it also is worth noting that if a player wants to start on hard difficulty (which appears to just be a question of damage scaling), completion achievements dependent on difficulty unlock for every difficulty up to the highest one at once.

Originally played this on console back when it was released. Such a fantastic game! It has held up VERY well, runs and plays very smoothly. Definitely a 9.5/10 for me. I'd recommend playing with a controller if you have one, keyboard and mouse can feel a little clunky by comparison. There were also a few issues with the scarecrow levels that I'm assuming are optimization related causing frame rates to tank even on modern hardware.

I actually rank Arkham Asylum above City because I think everything City did, Knight did better. However both City and Knight don't replicate the experience that is Arkham Asylum.

Rocksteady had originally wanted to start their Batman series with something in the scope of City but Warner Brothers had them scale down to prove themselves first. Within these constraints, Rocksteady settled on the idea of Gotham's infamous Asylum. Because they couldn't create the open world they wanted, they had to wring and squeeze every ounce of content out of this loony bin. And the most suitable game design direction for this was the Metroidvania.

Asylum being a Metroidvania seperates it from the rest of the Arkham series into its own little niche, Nowhere in the rest of the trilogy/quadrilogy do you get an experience quite like this. Throughout the course of this game, which should take on average about 10-12hrs, you will watch the island evolve and adapt as you venture to reclaim it from its tyrants. Poison Ivy will engulf the island in plants and vines, lunatic patients will rush and pounce you, Joker's snipers sweep from the towers, there's never a moment when the island feels static. And with the player backtracking a lot during those 10-12hrs, it better not be.

Atmosphere is important and Asylum isn't lacking. The asylum itself is richly detailed and its level/room design seamlessly interwoven. Asylum is always changing things up so that you never get bored. You'll be stalking a room of goons from gargoyles, escaping the twisted world of Scarecrow, avoiding the jaws of Killer Croc in the sewers, or taking down waves of enemies aiming to knock the lights out of Gotham's savior. Walking around this claustrophobic, creepy ass place as its one and only hope is a feeling you won't get tired of. Especially with Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill as Batman and Joker. This dynamic acting duo really sell the Batman experience with their incredible performances. The game is also chock full of Batman references, collectibles, and easter eggs that fans of all kinds will greatly enjoy.

The game's prized exhibition is its gameplay, especially the combat. We're pretty spoiled nowadays but even now, having Batman's belt at your disposal along with his FreeFlow, bone crunching punches and kicks is incredibly satisfying. The Predator system along with the Bat's gadgets allow the player freedom of expression to take down rooms as they see fit. The progression of unlocking gadgets is well paced and never makes the player feel like they couldn't have played without them; only better with them.

The game does have some downsides and that's only because the later entries just kept getting better. Movement for example is not as fluid as City or Knight. Things like not being able to grapple or dive while you're gliding or the cape having a delay before fanning out after you jump from a cliff/ledge become immediately noticeable to veterans. This also applies to some combat, like the combo takedown animations in FreeFlow being uncannily slow, as well as ground takedowns taking way too long. The combat does feel great, but if you've played later entries, you'll notice that it'll feel a little stiff. Not a bad thing however, because this is Rocksteady level of stiff, which is nitpick status.

I highly recommend you play Arkham Asylum, along with the rest of the Arkham series if you haven't, because each game is better than the last and are prime examples of masterful craftsmanship with visible love for the source material. I recommend you play this game with the Arkham Reborn 4K textures as it'll give this game a much needed face lift as well as color correcting the game to get rid of that god awful green tint that plagued the vanilla version. There are guides on how to do that in the community tab. This game and the rest of the Arkham games go on sale fairly often for a ridiculously cheap price (I got the trilogy for like $6) so you should definitely pick them up.

A bit slow and uninspired in the start, but the story and mechanics grow on you.

If you know nothing about Batman or about the DC universe, you can still play this game and you would understand the story and their characters just fine. You can find character bios, recordings and hear different conversations about the characters and the happenings in the game, which will help you understand what is going on and you won't get bored by them either. There is also the fight system which looks and plays simple, but throughout the game it gets a little bit more varied and the player usually aims to get max score and combos anyway. Not even mentioning the characters and the overall atmosphere that this game has and overall with every little aspects, Batman Arkham Asylum is a gem. 

If I really want to nitpick on something, I can't really find anything about this one. Give it a try, it's worth it!

The amount of technical issues I have faced while played has ruined my experience. At first I could not even get the game to launch. After searching through steam discussions I found I have to run two programs in the games files. Then I could not get sound at all. I had to go to the NVIDIA control panel to disable sound on my secondary monitors. I still have had times throughout the game, about every 20 minutes to 1 hour, where I will lose sound and need to restart the game to fix. It seems to happen frequently when entering new areas, restarting from a checkpoint, or entering and leaving a cut scene, but it also can happen mid fight or when exploring.

I will continue the game because of its great game play, story, map, characters, collectibles, etc. However due to its technical flaws, I would only recommend the console version of this game.

The game is basically non-functional on modern computers. Here was the process: Install game, doesn't start, uninstall current up to date PhysX, start game, allow it to install its preferred PhysX, doesn't start, add DirectX patch, game starts, get partway through opening credits, fatal crash, change graphics settings, fatal crash, install visual driver patch, fatal crash.

I'm sure it's a great game. Nothing but good things from people about it. And maybe others will have better experiences. But if you're running a newer computer...cross your fingers and test quickly so you don't miss the refund window if you need it.

Its a quite short batman game and it includes the main story, a few audio clips and backstories, and collectibles. Other than that there is nothing much and it is a great first entry into the Arkham Games. The combat is okay-ish but playable.

The main problem with the game is lack of creativity and lack of challenge. You get to fight the same boss in different outfits over 3-4 times in different situations and it destroys the immersion for me.

Ever since I was a little kid I have been obsessed with Batman. The fact that he is still just a mortal human like all of us makes it easier to connect with Batman. Batman has taught me many things like no matter how hard an obstacle, it can be overcome. When I first play this game on my ps3, I was blown away by the graphics, characters and world. Arkham Asylum is truly and ageless game. The influence this game has on other games was crazy. The iconic free flow combat in this game is amazing, I remember think to my self that it was impossible for a Batman game to be any better than this. But Arkham City came out and proved me wrong. Overall this game paved the way for my favourite video game franchise of all time. Thank you Arkham Asylum for everything. So yeah it's a 10/10 for me, I cant wait to 100% this masterpiece on PC!

Personal words about the game: During my childhood, I was not familiar with the concept of original games, so I mostly played pirated games. Since I had already played City before Asylum, the game felt a bit slow in the beginning, but after the first hour, I got used to it, and this didn't affect my enjoyment of the game. This fact is evident from the completion of all achievements.

Retinal Pleasure or Art: The game takes place in a mental hospital. Yes, there is a garden and a small cave outside the hospital, but overall, it takes place in a hospital. It does not require an additional mod as the textures are still manageable. I especially liked the colors in the places where you play with Batman's mind and remember his past. Even the designs of the cells of the lunatics and Calendar Man are very beautiful. After seeing the costumes in the new games, this game may seem a bit dull, but it does not stand out because it fits the game very well.

Mechanics: Subsequent games use the mechanics from Arkham Asylum. This game received a lot of praise, especially for its close combat mechanics, showcasing Batman as a master fighter. It is also excellent in stealth, featuring a Dishonored-style stealth system rather than the typical Thief-style. Even when Batman runs, enemies don't hear him; the key is to stay in their blind spots and take them down silently. Additionally, Batman can crawl from under grates, adding more tactical options. Moreover, the game offers a variety of gadgets that provide great diversity. Although they may be slightly slower compared to the later games in the series, they are quite good for the first game in the series. The sections where you follow compounds using Detective Vision are particularly well done. Moreover, the game offers a variety of gadgets that provide great diversity. Although they may be slightly slower compared to the later games in the series, they are quite good for the first game in the series. The sections where you follow compounds using Detective Vision are particularly well done. Furthermore, gliding is already a beautiful feature on its own. Even though we may not use gliding during combat, gliding was nice for stealth and exploring the map.

Atto Finale: The game is not expensive and despite being released in 2010, it is still beautiful. Just get the game and play. If you're a bit of a geek, you'll see nice little dialogues when you collect all the collectibles in the game.
Yes, I do recommend this game; it's already a timeless masterpiece!

I have synesthesia syndrome. In this syndrome, it is difficult to react to things around me.
I am a fan of Batman.I watched all the Batman movies since I was a kid.But not the games.I could not play because of my problem.
One day, one of my friends, who realized that I love Batman, gave me this game as a gift.
The game was difficult for me in the first few minutes.But I wanted to continue.My problem in the game was that I could not react to enemy attacks.
At that time I had two choices, to continue or not.I wanted to finish the game because Batman was one of the most popular characters in my life.My decision was to continue.I tried to make a connection between what I see and my fingers.And this became the most important goal of my life in six months.
Until today, I played the game several times on hard mode.And I could even play other games.It even made me react better in real life.So I can definitely say that Batman is my hero.

Batman Arkham Asylum is a remarkable game with an incredibly eerie atmosphere and satisfying addictive combat. The voice acting is phenomenal with titans such as Mark Hamill & Kevin Conroy bringing life to such well established characters, every sentence felt iconic. The relationship between the Joker and Batman felt organic and fleshed-out here with the dialogue weaving this beautiful tale of chaos vs order maintaining suspense throughout the story. The game has you feeling hopeless, desperately containing an increasingly bigger threat reflected in the environment and new enemies keeping the gameplay evolving. The hand-to-hand combat feels so satisfying and crisp split up with engaging invisible predator segments allowing you to exploit Batman's diverse equipment and abilities. The easter-eggs and backstory to Amadeus were incredibly expansive showing the level of detail and love from the creators, adding so much content. The Supervillain bossfights were unique, memorable and in some cases outright terrifying, although some of these fights did get repetitive after a while. Arkham Asylum encapsulates the feeling of Batman, play this game.

Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year Edition, developed by Rocksteady Studios, is a groundbreaking and immersive action-adventure game that captures the essence of the iconic Caped Crusader like no other. With its atmospheric setting, masterful storytelling, and innovative gameplay mechanics, Arkham Asylum stands as a true testament to the superhero genre.

One of the standout features of Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year Edition is its gripping and intricately crafted narrative. Players step into the role of Batman as he is trapped within the confines of Arkham Asylum, Gotham City's notorious psychiatric facility. The narrative unfolds with intense pacing, unveiling a complex web of secrets, conspiracies, and psychological battles against Batman's most formidable foes, led by the enigmatic Joker. The writing is superb, capturing the essence of Batman's dark and brooding nature while maintaining a deep respect for the character's rich lore. The voice acting, led by Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker, delivers exceptional performances that breathe life into the iconic characters.

The gameplay mechanics of Arkham Asylum revolutionized the superhero genre. The game offers a seamless blend of stealth, exploration, and action, allowing players to truly become the Dark Knight. Batman's versatile combat system, with its fluid combat animations and bone-crushing combos, provides a satisfying and empowering experience. The predator sections, where Batman must silently take down armed foes using stealth and fear tactics, add an extra layer of tension and strategic thinking to the gameplay. The extensive gadgetry, from the Batarang to the explosive gel, provides a range of options for players to approach encounters and solve puzzles. The innovative Detective Mode, which enhances Batman's senses and allows him to analyze his surroundings, immerses players in the role of the World's Greatest Detective.

Visually, Arkham Asylum Game of the Year Edition is a visual masterpiece. The attention to detail in the character models, atmospheric lighting, and Gothic architecture of Arkham Asylum creates a haunting and immersive environment. The dark and gritty art style perfectly captures the atmosphere of the Batman comics, infusing every corner of the game with an undeniable sense of foreboding.

The Game of the Year Edition includes all the previously released downloadable content (DLC), expanding the already rich experience. This additional content includes challenge maps that test players' combat and stealth skills, offering endless replayability and hours of additional gameplay.

The sound design of Arkham Asylum is exceptional, with a haunting musical score that adds depth and intensity to the gameplay. The ambient sounds of Arkham Asylum, from distant echoes to echoing footsteps, create an atmosphere that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year Edition is a must-play title for any Batman fan or lover of action-adventure games. Its gripping narrative, innovative gameplay mechanics, and immersive atmosphere make it an unforgettable journey through the twisted halls of Arkham Asylum. Prepare to don the cowl, confront your deepest fears, and embrace the role of Gotham's Dark Knight as you uncover the secrets that lurk within the asylum's walls. Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year Edition is an extraordinary experience that sets the standard for superhero gaming.

Asylum is the best game out of the trilogy; are you stupid?

Probably one of the best earliest modern Batman games to come out in the past decade, followed by Arkham City, one of my favorite games, which picks up after this, and carries on that ever present continuity in the Arkham series. Batman: Arkham Asylum tells a solid story that is not too long, and not too short, either, all while entertaining us with a slew of characters, references, excellent writing, and great voice acting, particularly that of Mark Hamill's Joker and Kevin Conroy's Batman. There is nobody else who can voice these characters. 

There isn't a whole ton of replay value unless you enjoy doing the Challenges, which can be fun, though the game overall is a tad clunky, ranging from combat to traversing around the map. Still, I got about 20 hours out of it, and no regrets were had. This truly is a game for Batman/DC fans, and, playing it for the first time since it's release over a decade ago, I can say that I wish I had played it sooner, and it has made me once again appreciate Batman as a whole, particularly it's villains. It almost makes me want to go back and play DC Universe Online and futz around Gotham. Almost. And hey, here's hoping Gotham Knights isn't a total let down. Lot of that going around, lately.

Edit: It was a let down. :(

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a classic and one of the best superhero games of ALL TIME. 

Maybe it's the nostalgia, but it's just amazing all around, it made one of the best combat systems in a game, They set up stuff that they can focus on in later Arkham entries, so it's not the best game in the series. But without Asylum, we wouldn't have games like City and Knight. (and the Spider-Man game, Which I also love)

A good example of a first try, an impressive first try, but a first try. 

If this were 2010 or even 2015 I would spend a great deal of time writing about the gloomy atmosphere, addictive yet narratively deaf combat system, and the twists and turns of the story. In 2023 things are just clunky. Batman moves like a wet mop on a steep hill, the lighting is too dark even in the brightest spots, and the combatâ€™s commitment to punishment ratio is too high for a game this short. Good, but outdated.

Ageless classic

I have synesthesia syndrome. In this syndrome, it is difficult to react to things around me.
I am a fan of Batman.I watched all the Batman movies since I was a kid. But not the games. I could not play because of my problem. One day, one of my friends, who realized that I love Batman, gave me this game as a gift.
The game was difficult for me in the first few minutes.But I wanted to continue.My problem in the game was that I could not react to enemy attacks. At that time I had two choices, to continue or not.I wanted to finish the game because Batman was one of the most popular characters in my life.My decision was to continue.I tried to make a connection between what I see and my fingers.And this became the most important goal of my life in six months.
Until today, I played the game several times on hard mode. And I could even play other games.It even made me react better in real life.So I can definitely say that Batman is my hero.

BATMAN GAMES ARE ONE OF THE BEST,THE COMBAT IS VERY SATISFYING

BATMAN
INT. TRADITIONAL BATCAVE

BATMAN stands next to his batmobile and uses his batcomputer. He's sometimes Bruce Wayne sometimes Batman. Alltimes orphan.
BATMAN

This is now a safe city. I have punched a penguin into prison.

ALFRED, Batman's loyal batler, carries a tray of goth ham.
ALFRED

Eat a dinner, Mattress Wayne.

An explosion explodes. THE JOKER and TWO-FACE enter the cave. Joker is a clown but insane. Two-Face is a man but attorney.
BATMAN

No! It is Two-Face and One-Face. They hate me for being a bat.

Batman throws Alfred at Two-Face. Two-Face flips Alfred like a coin. Alfred lands heads up which means Two-Face goes home.
BATMAN (CONT'T)

It is just you and I, the Joker. Bat versus clown. Moral enemies.
THE JOKER

I am such a freak. Society is bad. You drink water, I drink anarchy.
BATMAN

I drink bats just like a bat would!

Batman looks around him for his parents, but they are still dead. This makes him have anger. He fires a batrocket. The Joker deflects it with his sick sense of humor. A clownly power.
THE JOKER

I have never followed a rule. That is my rule. Do you follow? I don't.
BATMAN

Alfred, give birth to Robin.

Alfred begins the process since it is his job. The joker now has a present in his hand. He juggles it over to Batman.
THE JOKER

Happy batday, Birthman.

Batman opens the present since he's a good guy. It contains a coupon for new parents, but is expired. This is a Joker joke.
Batman

OVERALL: 8.5/10

batman

Im a huge Batman fan and I hold the entire Arkham series very near and dear to my heart, they are all my favourite games, but this is my favourite game of all time, this game and the animated series is what made me fall in love with batman when i was a kid, and to this day, I still absolutely love the Batman Mythos, comics and all, best character ever created. The Arkhamverse is a damn near PERFECT Batman universe, this is peak Batman, if you know nothing about Batman and you want to learn, this series will give you so much to look into the characters and the lore in general, for example, Batman has easily got the best rogues gallery out of any character, and throughout the series, especially Asylum, the tape recordings and character bios are great to look through and will give a great insight to who the villians are, what their motives are, general info and stuff like that. Also, the characterization and writing of all the villians is top-notch, especially Joker, well Jason in Knight was a bit iffy but hey, nothings perfect. These games' atmosphere are just something else, the vibe and feeling you get when running around in the asylum and flying around in the cities in the other games is unmatched, not to mention their incredible soundtracks (City's main theme is amazing and the Asylum menu is such a vibe). Now, just because Asylum is my favourite, doesn't mean i think its the best game, for me that would go to City, but Asylum will always be my favourite because of how much it means to me, not only is it the game that got me into batman, but it was one of the first games i even remember playing alongside Lego batman. This game is always a gem to replay, the beginning of the game always puts the biggest smile on my face, i've pretty much memorized the entire opening sequence, line by line. This game was a massive part of my childhood and is one of the most nostalgic and exciting memories i can possibly think of. This game was the perfect way to start off the series, and honestly it was way ahead of its time, and still holds up very well today, its an absolute masterpiece, the whole series is, and yes, even Origins.



Thank you Kevin Conroy, for everything, you will always be the definitive voice of Batman, the best Batman, nobody did it better than you, thank you for giving me such an awesome childhood. R.I.P.

man aslume oy edition

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a game that will make you feel like the World's Greatest Detective. You will infiltrate the notorious Arkham Asylum, where you will face some of the most dangerous and insane criminals in Gotham City, such as The Joker, Harley Quinn, Poison Ivy, and Killer Croc. You will use your gadgets, skills, and detective abilities to stop The Joker's sinister plan and restore order to the asylum.

The game is the first in the Batman: Arkham series, and it set a new standard for superhero games. The game is a blend of action, stealth, and puzzle-solving, with a focus on exploration and immersion. The game also features a remastered Game of the Year Edition, featuring 4 extra Challenge Maps that test your combat and stealth skills.

The game is not only a great Batman game, but also one of the best action-adventure games ever made. It has a dark and atmospheric story, a stunning and detailed environment, and a gameplay that will keep you engaged for hours. If you are a fan of Batman or just enjoy a thrilling and fun game, you should definitely play Batman: Arkham Asylum.

If your curious of the order of games you should play it in, the 4 main ones are

1 Arkham Origin
2 Arkham Asylum
3 Arkham City
4 Arkham Knight

You should play Origin before Asylum and City despite it coming out later since it takes place before Asylum and City but if you don't want too (since it's not really included in the Arkham Steam bundle) it can be skipped, it's the least important

I haven't played the Arkham games in quite some time, and all of them have a massive place in my heart. So revisiting the first entry in the series was an absolute joy. 

While I know Arkham Asylum is not the best in the series, this is such an incredible start and strong foundation for the ultimate Batman game. I'm sure when this first came out people were asking themselves how it could even get better from here (it did). 
For an older game, I was pleasantly surprised how well this holds up. Like, extremely well might I add. The story is incredible, fighting and encountering all of Batman's roster of villains is such a blast, and using Batman's gadgets, glide, and combat is insanely satisfying. 

If you want to play a Batman game, or get into the Arkham series as a whole, this is such an incredible way to start your journey. As a Batman fan, I'm so happy this exists and the fact that the games only improved is the cherry on top.

[h1] Batman: Arkham Asylum - 2023 review [/h1]

Batman: Arkham Asylum is the first entry in the Arkham franchise. Although it is now over 13 years old, the game still manages to shine through its age for multiple reasons. I'll be going over everything that I personally enjoyed and disliked about the game and why I recommend it, and why you should (or shouldn't) buy it.

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*] The story is amazing, arguably the best one out of the entire franchise. The characters (and mostly the villains) really stick to their roots, the pacing is great, the voice actors are out of this world (the Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as Joker is unbeatable) and the lore behind the asylum is fantastic. I am always in love with the setting and the progression of this game whenever I replay it.
[*] The length is also perfect for a campaign game in my opinion. You can finish the story in about 7-8 hours and 100% the game with around 20 hours, which is just perfect for a casual singleplayer experience.
[*] The game is also extremely stable. Very good performances, can be played on roughly anything, very few minor bugs.
[*] The level design is also admirable. The map is fun to navigate, while staying rather short, yet all the locations are truly unique and different from eachothers. It's the only game in the entire serie that I enjoyed everything about the map and the areas in general. [/list]

[b] Neutrals [/b]
[list]
[*] The gameplay was decent, although somewhat repetitive. No need to hide it; the Batman games are mostly button mashers. Sure, you can do sick combos and prepare beforehand your fight, but you can also achieve the exact same thing by spamming your buttons. It can get tiresome at some point. Fortunately, the combat is at least very fluid, and the perk system/the gadgets unlocked throughout the game offer some variety to it.
[*] The graphics hold up pretty well, but they aren't over the top too. Fortunately, you can mod your game to make it look even better.
[*] Same goes for the sound design, except you can't do much about it. The sound quality is pretty rough on some occasions, they're also specific sound effects that feels old. However, since it hasn't triggered me at all during my experience, so I've put it in the [i] Neutrals [/i] category, but I could understand how it would break one's immersion.  [/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] It is a pain of a game to fully complete. The amount of tedious backtracking that needs to be done in order to find a TON of collectibles is just plain boring. Backtracking in video games isn't something I have trouble with in general, but when 3/4 Riddler trophies are locked behind abilities I know I will unlock in a few minutes yet won't allow me to come back to the zone for a while just doesn't cut it for me.
[*] Outside of the base game, the challenges are tedious and just not a lot of fun. They're also extremely hard to complete with 3 stars, so for anyone looking to 100% this game like I did, good luck.
[*] The boss fights are underwhelming. Every time I encounter a boss, I'm reminded why this game was made in 2010. Except for Scarecrow and maybe Poison Ivy, all the bosses act the exact same, even the Joker during the last boss battle. If you're going to give us villains with such strong personalities, make sure to reflect this upon their move sets at least. [/list]

[b] TL;DR [/b]
It's a great semi open-world linear game with good pacing. The setting and the story are both phenomenal, and the characters are perfect. Everything holds up relatively well to today's standards, aside from the bosses who were disappointing for the most part. If you're a completionist like me, chances are you'll suffer trying to 100% this game, since it has so much backtracking and ridiculously hard challenges. Thankfully, it's a very stable and easy to run game, perfect for older systems.

[b] Rating: 8/10 [/b]
THIS IS NOT SPIDERMAN REMASTERED!!!

Played this game in 2023 and still enjoyed. Made me feel like Batman, the combat animations are sick, makes you use your brain, and asks for patience at times (in a good way). The boss fights are winnable but not too easy, a perfect balance of difficulty. The storyline is what I suggest for, side missions are just collectibles.

It's fine. When it gets annoying, it gets [i]real annoying[/i] though.

So let's start with what I love about this game: I actually really enjoy the metroidvania world exploration, and the atmosphere of this gothic nightmare of an island of madness is superb, with a very classic Batman story fighting a bunch of classic villains, and voicework from Mark Hamill as the Joker and the late Kevin Conroy as Batman is as wonderful as those two always are as these characters.

So why am I posting an angry review after ragequitting an encounter?

Because this game is dated, and as I'm writing this in 2023, the actual fighting and stealthing gameplay that this title [i]turned into an industry standard[/i] is made more memorable for its flaws and all the ways other games have done it better since. These fistfights with goons [i]aren't fun[/i], but those at least go by pretty quickly. No, it's the stealth sections against goods with guns that are actually fucking miserable, and make up an important core of this game that you will have to do a lot of, die a lot in, and re-do a lot of. They aren't a fun challenge, they are an aggressive waste of your time for even small failures.

This game is charming for its atmosphere, and clearly very much adores Batman and his surrounding cast of characters, and that enthusiasm is infectious and delightful... but only carries it so far. Is it worth playing if you want to recognize its place in video game history? Absolutely, it holds up better than a lot of other games you might play in that pursuit, but just for its own enjoyment in the 2020s? No, the stealth sections absolutely [i]suck[/i] and are not worth putting the time and money into this title.

Edit: I feel like the best summation of my relationship with this game is that found all the collectibles, solved all its mysteries, did all the stuff to [i]explore[/i] and enjoy the map and all that, and then looked at the climactic final level and went "Nah, I'll pass."

I played through this game for the first time a couple of months ago, and wow, I was missing out on this series. As a huge Batman fan, Arkham Asylum made me love Batman even more than I already do. It truly makes you feel like Batman, and it aged perfectly. The combat is still amazing to this day, even if it's sequels improved on it. The story isn't too in-depth, but its a load of fun. Every villain you encounter in this game is unique, and stands out. They're over the top, which is what I love about the majority of Batman's villains. Graphics don't really matter to me as much as it matters to some people, but the graphics in Asylum still hold up to this day.  I can't recommend this game enough, its worth trying out, and the sequels continue to improve on the original formula!

Despite feeling rough around the edges, Arkham Asylum is an excellent game. The blending of 3 core elements of Combat, Stealth and light puzzle challenges is great. The grit of the RockSteady batman universe is pulping and seeps into every part of the Asylum. But i cannot say this game is perfect. Its the first child of the series, the one that mostly came out alright but a few quirks of outdated parenting lead to it not being 'all there'. The game lacks the fast, fluid and excellent movement mechanics of the future games and the bossfights...my god. Enjoy either having your camera locked to a fixed perspective or fighting the same big guy 6 times! 

But again, Asylum really sells what it has, and its flaws arent like gamebreaking or anything. Future games chose to develop combat, stealth much more, and included the excellent traversal systems only with the hindsight this game provided. I enjoy the fact this is a shorter experience, but the expansive of gotham city was missed. Arkham Asylum is what it is, and that is the foundation for Rocksteady's excellent trilogy.

This game was groundbreaking when i first played in during school days, and its still outstanding now, so many years later.
I still vividly remember the long walk with the joker strapped on the stroller, with all guards; fully armed, watchful and guns primed, all cameras following our movement and the tall and dark shadow of the Batman walking besides the convoy; silent but ever vigilant. That long walk with doctors checking in, the bio-metric scan, the killer croc cameo and the lift blackout, re-playing those moments was like reliving the nostalgia of my those childhood days.

I can hardly recall any game, let alone released in the 2010s, came to be as marvellous and iconic as Batman: Arkham Asylum. Playing this game again after nearly a decade made me travel back in time for a brief moment, reliving the immersion and thrill of being the Batman.

[b]*Recent playthroughs completed in about 6-10 hours.
**Achievement notes at the end of this review.[/b]

[b]*General[/b]
Well I'll start this off simple. This is a good game. Visually it's highly pleasing and the whole soundtrack is just spot on. You do have to be a fan of the sound of a cloud of bats flying around every time you collect an item, though. Right off the Bat (I'm not sorry) and following an interactive intro sequence putting you in the middle of the asylum, you're introduced to the combat system and Detective Mode (vision) - of which the latter will help you locate anything that lives, moves and can be interacted with.
Then you're basically playing a sort of metroidvania game. Following the path laid out by Jokers schemes, you'll enter a new area where some secrets can be grabbed and others seen that aren't accessible yet until you progress through the story and unlock a new tool.

Touching on the rather low difficulty (at least at Normal and Easy) I'd like to point out that this game does hold your hand. A lot. It's NOT intended for people that love solving clever puzzles and finding out where to go all on their own. Finding secrets is a simple matter of exploring the environments, climbing up onto ledges and into vents and the like. Riddler maps can be found which reveal the rough location of other secrets on your bat-map. Hints are given to scan (let's say photograph) items or scenes that refer to characters from the Batman world and sometimes you might think "what the hell is this referring to" until you pan the camera around and see something out of place.
The only thing that comes close to being a puzzle is finding the question marks placed in various locations which are only visible in Detective Mode and require a specific position to scan properly.
Like I said, it's sort of a metroidvania type deal where you need to unlock new tools to find secrets hidden in areas you've previously been through. This is really kind of a formality or an arbitrary barrier if you will as there is no difficulty in using these tools whatsoever, it really is 100% about just having them.
However given that it's Batman with his nifty toys, that's alright. It's still fun to use them and be rewarded with experience points, character bios and trophies.

Speaking of experience points, this is by no means an RPG. But fighting (and fighting well) as well as finding secrets will earn you points that allow you to unlock some gear upgrades and new abilities, from increasing your health, gaining more functionality with your batarang or adding special moves to your combos.
It's worth nothing that these upgrades carry over to the challenge maps, should you choose to try those. Those maps are unlocked by finding secrets so your progress in them and your efficiency will be limited by your story mode progress. If you just want to play the story mode, don't worry about them as they don't give any benefits for it.

When it comes to the dangers you'll face, the game and enemy AI were designed in such a way that with a little patience and careful timing you can easily take out unsuspecting thugs with silent takedowns and surprise attacks. Any hardened criminal worth their salt would be looking around more at opened vents, decorative gargoyles and heck, even just behind them every now and then. But they generally don't. Their vision is limited while you're above them and they'll usually only spot you if you make a move when they're nearby or don't bother to move away fast enough from the gargoyle that you used to string a thug up.
They'll punish you quickly with gunfire until you zip away and I don't recommend trying to get closer unless you're already in stunning/vaulting range and there's no back-up nearby for them.
So in other words, the enemies are dumb. Very dumb. But you can't afford to be completely reckless and just run up to them all the time. Some more on (melee) combat below.

[b]*Combat[/b]
Arkham Asylum features a clever combat system that is well balanced between making it easy to look like the calm and cool Bat-ass that Batman is and presenting a decent challenge in the optional fighting maps. With the freeflow system Batman easily takes on multiple attackers at once, automatically using appropriate attacks with just one button, executing counters with another and allowing for a handful of tools and special moves to be used as you build up a combo counter by continuously staying in motion and interacting with the enemies.
It's not a perfect system and there's plenty things to annoy you, even more so when you're doing the challenges where the combos are extremely important.

Countering doesn't seem to always work very well, leaving Batman open to take a hit because either (it seems) like the button push didn't register or you were already locked into an animation to put a beatdown on another thug. Sometimes countering an attacker (indicated by a clear blue icon popping up) isn't necessary at all as your current attack on another target will take you out of range of say, the garden variety punch or kick. But then sometimes you'll fail to dodge this way because they try to stick to you or use a melee weapon for more range.
Combos are easily broken not just by inexperience (using tools or finishing moves before the combo counter goes yellow, taking damage, punching air) but also the armed thugs. Knife thugs have to be "cape stunned" or they'll block your attack. Stun baton thugs will frazzle you unless you get behind them. And ofcourse sometimes the thugs will get their hands on firearms and become a problem unless dealt with quickly.

But with all that said, outside of the challenge maps these things aren't as problematic. In the story mode all you have to do is survive each encounter so you don't have to worry about getting big style points, a higher combo counter or getting out with full health.

[b]*Conclusion[/b]
The handholding also applies to the general storyline. At no point do you have to wonder where to go or what to do as you'll be told by the fully voice acted NPCs and Batman himself. Again though, this is fine. The player is able to fully take in the experience. A brilliant atmosphere, an island filled with known and interesting personalities, sneaking, silent takedowns and all-out cape-and-fists-swinging fighting.
A low difficulty, context-sensitive controls and a well crafted game world makes for a very memorable and super fun action game. Play this if you haven't already.

[b]**Achievements:[/b] The majority of achievements here are tied to your story progress and finding the many secrets. Even the most casual players will have no problem there. One level up in difficulty are some achievements like taking out a titan henchman without using the batarang, this one in particular requires some deliberate combat manouvers and planning. The real problem with (if you care to go for it) getting 100% in this game is the other combat and challenge mode achievements. These infernal (but optional and separate from the story mode) challenge maps offer bat medals to players who can get high scores on them using the freeflow combat system.
Consider what I said about combat earlier in this review and now apply that to a mode where you need to not just not get hit but also incorporate a number of special moves into your combo for more points and sometimes even within a time limit.
Not taking damage and punching all of the enemies out is NOT going to be enough. The so-called "predator" challenges aren't a major concern since you can take your time with them and just plan out particular takedowns but the combat ones will keep you busy for some time until you master the combos.

[b]If you're a casual player who just wants some easy fun, don't bother with 100% on this game.[/b]

***

its good

I finally hopped back into the Arkham Asylum after what must have been at least 8 years, and I found that it holds up quite well.
Game-play is rougher around the edges than its sequels, but that's to be expected. Going back to this one, you really miss how flexible Batman's move-set gets in the later games, but you still feel like you can handle whatever the game throws at you.
Tonally, the game is much more foreboding than the others in the series, although Knight tries to outdo it. Everything about Arkham Asylum as a place feels hostile and haunted, like the island itself is cursed somehow.
The voice acting is good. Conroy seems a little subdued, but I think that was a direction issue, and he's by no means bad. 
Hamill makes the most of the Joker's screen-time, and is entertaining throughout. Sorkin's performance as Harley is also good, and [i]really[/i] makes me wish she'd returned for Arkham City and Knight.

Plot-wise, this game feels the strongest out of the series. City and Knight both had some missteps, and while Asylum does as well, they're not as distracting here.
While I love these games, and City is my favourite, I will say that Asylum has a special appeal to it.
Rocksteady didn't want to rock the boat too much with the story, or do something shocking to shake things up in-universe.
They wanted to capture what a normal night in the life of Batman is like, and I think Asylum does that better than any other game in the series.
