Because of this game, I am now a Batman man.

Letâ€™s just start with the obvious: one does not have to be a comic fan to enjoy this game. And in that extremely impossible case that you somehow missed all the movies (even Nolanâ€™s ones) hereâ€™s a quick recap. Bruce Wayne whose parents were tragically murdered is insanely rich, dresses in a suit that resembles a bat and beats the shit out of all kinds of bad guys while using cool gadgets. In a devilishly insane logic of superhero comic villains caught by our hero all end up in a special kind of jail which happens to be also a madhouse. Itâ€™s Arkham Asylum. Obviously, it turns out badly; asylum is overrun by criminals, and itâ€™s up to Batman to stop them. Thatâ€™s it without spoiling too many details. After all the game is set in a separate universe which tends to follow the usual canon, but also steps out of the bounds here and there. And this is a big deal for those, who can distinguish Earth-2 from say Earth-15.

The plot revolving around events of one night and set in one place results in a rather tense game. First in the series Arkham Asylum may lack the extent, size and polish of its successors, but it has that unique feeling of being trapped inside an insane maze. These corridors, buildings, underground and open air sections are so tightly stitched together, that thereâ€™s practically no room to make a breathe, unless developers intended to let you. This is non-stop rollercoaster ride accelerating to the limit and beyond it, until you finally fall in the abyss of total madness, lose all sense of time and spend sleepless night with the game. Rocksteady Studios not just break the fourth wall with this game, they destroy it with a power of nuclear explosion. Carefully crafted props, marvelously fluid animations, diverse gameplay varying from famous â€œflowingâ€ combat to stealth, puzzle solving, detective mode and beyond that. And ultimately the story. I wonâ€™t spoil you the exact scenes happening in the middle of the game, but they are simply outstanding in their ability to convey a feeling of lunacy overcoming Batman in this nuthouse.

Gotham Knightâ€™s labyrinth path expectedly twists and bends in way that returns the player to previously visited areas with a new set of toys. That differs in tone and simplicity from most of the hard-core metroidvanias. Rather than just giving tools to overcome some obstacles game gently pushes you in the right way making sure you wonâ€™t struggle with trying to figure out what to do next. Itâ€™s not a game about exploring, though there are some clever hidden optional areas containing secrets and unobvious puzzles; but thatâ€™s for those who just canâ€™t get enough of Arkham Asylum. 

When it comes to the main progression route the game wonâ€™t let off your hand. And while in general that would be a major flaw in my eyes, this time it isnâ€™t. One can say that itâ€™s just a matter of perspective, matter of taste; that you canâ€™t just drop off the player in the middle of nowhere nowadays and hope, thatâ€™s heâ€™s clever and curious enough to figure his way from the starting point towards the ending. That may be trueâ€¦ it actually is true, I must say, but thatâ€™s beside the point. Thatâ€™s the matter of taste. Back again to perception of it. Here we have that idea of lunatic luna-park, the goal of filling player with madness. And you canâ€™t just stop and let player wander without breaking that feeling and pace. You ever had that weird nightmare where you run in circles seeing same place again and again not being able to comprehend how many times you did it, not being able to break the cycle? Even if you havenâ€™t, I think you can get it. And that pardons Rocksteady Studios.

This was a breakthrough for the video games back in 2009, and it still is a stellar interactive experience whether you care about Batman comics or not. And the actual secret for this success turns out to be rather simple. It doesnâ€™t matter if player is a fan of Bruce Wayne, it matters that developer is. Itâ€™s that special attention to the tiniest of details like animation of the main characterâ€™s coat or getting original voice-artists from Batman: The Animated Series (including genius Mark Hamill, playing Joker). And this passion just wonâ€™t leave anyone indifferent. At least when itâ€™s accompanied with such brilliant execution of gameplay mechanics. Letâ€™s just say that a fair number of games released since then simply copied Arkham Asylum freeflow combat system. And none of them came even close.

The start of a great series of games, Arkham Asylum is a little dated, but still delivers a fun and enjoyable experience that is further refined and improved in later games. Freeflow combat can be a challenge for newcomers, but once you wrap your head around the flow of hit, dodge, block, special, and so forth, it flows very well, though occasionally a ground finisher wouldn't work and would prematurely end my combo. The predator sections are a lot of fun in the campaign, but less so in the other part of the game (the word is slipping my mind at the moment) where they add in optional challenges that you need for 100% completion. I ended up looking up a guide on youtube to get them done, but that's probably more a failure on my end than the game's. Overall, I rate this game a 10/10.

One of the best comic book adaptation in Gaming History

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a short and simple superhero game which kick started a successful video game franchise and has influenced many other works. Being loosely inspired by the Grant Morrison graphic novel "Arkham Asylum: A Serious House On Serious Earth" this first outing of the Arkham series while being much more simplistic and smaller in scale compared to it's sequels does not take away from the quality of it's fun fast paced beat em up action and strategic stealth gameplay, open level design which is fun to traverse and full of collectibles and secrets, a dark and grimy aesthetic which holds up to this day and great voice acting delivered by some returning actors from the Batman Animated Series. While it's sequels add on and refine on what's established in this game, I do believe that this game aesthetically beats out the others with it's grimy, dirty, rusted and overall disgusting look of the asylum which is reminiscent of the graphic novel it's based on with a graphical style that blends the comic book designs into a semi-realistic look. If you have played the other Arkham games or not I still HIGHLY recommend playing this modern classic, you will have a lot of fun and may even appreciate and find value in this game's simplicity as opposed to modern superhero games such as Square Enix's Avengers with it's barren environments, weak visuals and repetitive gameplay. This game is also great if you have children and want a fun superhero game for them to play during the summer, and if they love Batman, that's just a bonus!

Thursday, October 31st. The city streets are crowded for the holiday. Even with the rain. Hidden in the chaos is the element, waiting to strike like snakes. And I'm there too. Watching. 2 years of nights have turned me into a nocturnal animal. I must choose my targets carefully. It's a big city. I can't be everywhere. But they don't know where I am. We have a signal now, for when I'm needed. When that light hits the sky, it's not just a call- it's a warning. To them. Fear is a tool. They think I'm hiding in the shadows. But I AM the shadows. I wish I could say I'm making a difference, but I don't know. Murder, robberies, assault- 2 years later, they're all up. And now this. This city's eating itself. Maybe it can't be saved, but i have to try. PUSH MYSELF. These nights all roll together in a rush, Behind the mask. Sometimes in the morning i have to force myself to remember everything that happened.

This game is a ton of fun and has aged very well. The combat and gameplay is great, and there are some fun puzzles as well. The only minor downsides with the game is the story could be a little better and since the game came out so long ago, there are some noticeable differences compared to the graphics and smoothness of newer games. The game can be pretty difficult at times and also has an awesome stealth system that is lots of fun to mess around with. This is by far one of the best games I have played recently and I would give it a higher score if I wasn't trying to leave room for other games. There are also plenty of riddler trophy collectibles scattered throughout the game for completionists and some special side gamemodes.

I think this game is fantastic. I have been playing it for years. This is the first game of the Batman: Arkham Series, and when it first came out, I was so excited to play because I've always liked Batman. However, I didn't play it at launch for obvious reasons. But when I did, I had a blast with the rudimentary but awesome mechanics, the storytelling, the world building, and the overall masterpiece that it is.

I've heard many people say that this game isn't that great and that people only like it because of nostalgia. Sure, it might be enticing to experience the game for the first time again. However, personally, I find that my deep familiarity and understanding of the game gained from countless playthroughs surpasses the allure of experiencing it anew. Nostalgia aside, it is the accumulated knowledge and appreciation I have developed over time that enhances my ongoing enjoyment.

If you like the dark and gritty versions of DC Comics, and/or if you enjoy video games, and/or appreciate phenomenal performances, then I recommend getting this game if you have the time and money to experience this work of art.

If you like Batman and/or games that involves around physical combat you will most likely enjoy Batman Arkham Asylum.
The Game comes with 3 difficulties: Easy, Medium and Hard. If you are new to Batman Games I recommend playing on Normal to get a fell for the Game first. My 1st play-through was on Medium and my 2nd Play-trough (for Achievement purposes) was on Hard and I have to say Medium really helped me understand all of the games mechanics. If you mainly only care about the Main Story (No Collectibles etc.) you will finish the Game in about 10 hours. If you do care about everything (Collectibles, Challenges etc.) then you would be looking at around 15 hours. Since this Game is kinda short I recommend buying this Game once it's on Sale. I recommend buying the whole Batman GOTY edition Bundle once it's all on sale since it's going to be so cheap to get all 3 Games.
In conclusion: You like Batman, Physical Combat Mechanics, little bit of stealth, a small open map area, different areas/buildings and a lot of collectibles & puzzles/riddles? Then this Game is the one for you. :)

A pretty good stealth/action game in its own right, and perfect for fans of the comic.  Suffers a bit from what I call X-Boxitis (using save points instead of manual saves, which forces you to replay easy/boring stuff and cutscenes that occur between the save point and any hard bit you need to attempt multiple times).  But that's true of most every game these days.
Batman: Arkham Asylum really makes you *feel* like Batman.

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…

Batman Arkham Asylum is a game that redefines what it means to be a superhero in the gaming world. Developed by Rocksteady Studios, this title introduces a groundbreaking fighting system and mechanics that set a new standard for action-adventure games. With its immersive storytelling, stunning visuals, and flawless gameplay, Batman Arkham Asylum proves that a superhero game can achieve AAA quality and captivate players like never before.

At the heart of Batman Arkham Asylum is the revolutionary FreeFlow Combat system. This combat mechanic is a game-changer, allowing players to effortlessly string together intricate and acrobatic combat moves. The fluidity and responsiveness of the controls make players feel like the Dark Knight himself, as they deliver devastating combos and seamlessly transition between attacks, counters, and evasions. The combat is a perfect balance of strategy, timing, and skill, providing an immensely satisfying and empowering experience.

The game's mechanics go beyond combat, as Batman utilizes his detective skills to solve puzzles and unravel the mysteries of Arkham Asylum. The Detective Mode feature allows players to analyze the environment, detect hidden objects, and uncover vital clues. This adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay and showcases Batman's unparalleled intellect and detective prowess.

Batman Arkham Asylum also excels in its storytelling and world-building. The game presents a dark and atmospheric portrayal of the iconic Arkham Asylum, with its haunting architecture and twisted inhabitants. The narrative is gripping, featuring a compelling plotline that keeps players engaged from start to finish. The voice acting, led by the legendary Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker, is exceptional and brings these beloved characters to life in a way that feels authentic and cinematic.

Visually, Batman Arkham Asylum is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in the game's environments, character models, and animations is impeccable. From the rain-soaked rooftops to the dimly lit corridors of Arkham Asylum, every location feels meticulously crafted and oozes with atmosphere. The graphics are stunning, and the art direction perfectly captures the gritty and noir aesthetic of the Batman universe.

As a superhero game, Batman Arkham Asylum sets the bar incredibly high. It demonstrates that a game based on a comic book character can deliver a AAA experience in every aspect. From its innovative combat system and engaging mechanics to its captivating storytelling and top-notch production values, Batman Arkham Asylum is a triumph that showcases the immense potential of superhero games.

In conclusion, Batman Arkham Asylum is a must-play for any fan of the Dark Knight or action-adventure games in general. Its groundbreaking fighting system, immersive gameplay mechanics, and high-quality production make it a standout title in the superhero genre. Rocksteady Studios has created a game that not only pays homage to the iconic Batman but also raises the standard for what a superhero game can achieve. Prepare to don the cape and cowl and experience a superhero adventure like no other in Batman Arkham Asylum.

Quick Scores (scroll down for full review):
Graphics: 9/10 (Incredible for 2009)
Story: 8/10
Boss Fights: 4/10
Atmosphere: 10/10
Combat: 9/10
Music: 8/10
Fun to play: 10/10
Gadgets/tools: 7/10
Characters: 10/10
Voice acting: 10/10
Overall: 85/100

Full review:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is a stunning and almost perfect example of what a superhero video game should be. With exceptional graphics that look great for a game over a decade old, and a solid storyline, it is certainly unforgettable. The music fits very well with the superb atmosphere and the combat system is still not challenged by any other game series. While Arkham Asylum misses out on its mostly redundant boss fights, there are some that still shine out, such as the Scarecrow fights and the incredibly scary Killer Croc encounter. The levels are very well designed, and give you a chance to use almost all the tools. However, I did think that some were almost entirely useless, and that there could be some other tools, particularly smoke grenades which would make stealth/predator encounters much more interesting. While the average thug in the game isn't unique, they still have some personality to listen to and maybe even laugh at before you knock them out. My biggest gripe with Asylum is that the game dies away after you complete the main campaign, with the only thing to do after that is to get all the Riddler Trophies and Patient Interview Tapes.

With that being said, Arkham Asylum is without a doubt one of the best games I've ever played, and you should definetely get it if you are interested in it. You won't regret it.

Epic game, a must have for any fan of Batman or comics in general. This is also a game I would recommend to people that dont care much for batman, as it is THAT good. and I am confident that they will change their view of the dark knight for the better after this game. Its amazing, I cant stress it enough. 

The riddler challanges, although annoying at times are clever and often feel "fair" the character models are amazing, to this day. the voice acting and the story is a 9.9/10 (I only have a super small nit-pick, its about Mr. jonathan crane. I wont say more because of spoilers) the combat is fluid and good (most of the time) it just needs a little refining (which later games have done), the graphics still hold up and the open world is immersive 

Truly one of the best DC themed games of all time, and one of the best games.. in general
So in conclusion: 

Story: 9.9/10 
Combat: 9/10 
Movement: 8.5/10 
Glitches: didnt really find any
Graphics: still hold up
Voice acting: 10/10 
Stuff to do other than the main story: 9/10, im impressed, for a story based game there is a decent amount of content

The start to, in my opinion, one of the greatest single player franchises in gaming history. Even before I was introduced to Batman and the background stories of the miscellaneous villains, I absolutely loved playing this game. As a child, this game was very spooky. The story is thrilling, offering very few moments of respite whilst constantly keeping you on your toes. I would absolutely recommend this for everyone to try out, you will not regret it. Not only this game, but the sequels as well since they are EVEN better, something which is extremely rare.

Even in 2023 Batman: Arkham Asylum is a fun game. You can enjoy the story or you can try yourself in the hardest difficulty, where you need to think twice every move you're going to do!

In case someone doesn't know the game or the story I can tell you that this game is taking place in one HUGE "map" at the Arkham Asylum. You can go to lot's of areas and you can beat up everyone as you like! But you need to be stealthy sometimes!

The story is interesting and there's plenty of suprises that awaits you in the game! Maybe the only "boring" part is finding all the Riddler's trophy's but if you're an achivement hunter (like me lol) you'll enjoy it! 

Basically this game is like a walking punching simulator (with some strategy) but for some reason it's so facinating beating up pririsoners with Batman! I'll reccomend this game to everyone who's up for a little nostalgia or even if you don't know anything about batman!

Batman Arkham Asylum, the game that started it all. While it isnâ€™t the most refined game in the series, I of course have no end of respect for this game. And I had a ton of fun revisiting it as a part of my series playthrough. While the combat and stealth are at their most primitive iterations, they are both still fantastic, especially for 2009. When the game starts, you donâ€™t have a lot of options for combat, with only 1 gadget, strikes, counters, and ground takedowns. Getting massive combos is pretty tricky for a while, but as you unlock skills like critical strikes, takedowns, and more, the combat becomes significantly more fun and I like the slightly slower approach to it. There arenâ€™t a ton of gadgets here, however, and using them in combat is not very useful. The stealth is probably the hardest in the series, but it is still really fun, especially once you unlock the inverted takedowns. There is a lot of variety to the mechanics, each encounter introduces something new, like forcing you to be nonlethal or removing the gargoyles (although that one was very irritating). The graphics still look really good even 13 years later, and the music is great too. The environments arenâ€™t that big and I wouldnâ€™t say this is an open world, but I do like the more linear approach here. As for the story, it is really intense from beginning to end. It never drags or slows down, it has a ton of different villains with memorable boss fights and encounters, and there are a ton of amazing moments. The scarecrow sections are a real highlight here and they include some incredible 4th wall-breaking horror. The performances, namely Kevin Conroy as Batman and of course Mark Hamil as the Joker, are both excellent and their dynamic was explored really well. Overall, Arkham Asylum might be a bit outclassed by its successors nowadays, but it is still an excellent start to the series. The story is engaging and very well written, the combat and stealth are highly enjoyable, and the game is absolutely worth playing if you havenâ€™t checked it out.

When this first came out in 2009, I remember watching the intro video, and not realising it wasn't video anymore and had become playable - the graphics felt that good. Considering that was 14 years ago, it feels like it's held up pretty well. I've never really been into super heroes, but this feels very accessible for anyone who knows nothing about it. The acting and animations are excellent, and it really feels like playing Batman. Melee combat is very tight, mostly based on parrying. There's also some really fun gadgets during combat. Mostly linear, but lots of collectables and lore to find if you want to know more about the world and characters. A very memorable experience.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Still looks good in 2023, subjectively
- Joker's voice acting in particular is excellent, but they're all great
- The melee combat system feels good. Sound effects, slow downs and parrying make it feel really impactful
- Stealth gameplay is really good
- Lots of tools for combat and trap setting
- Lots of lore to find if you want to find out more about the world
- A good length, self-contained batman game
- Batman has a kind of x-ray vision that helps both in analysing puzzles and electronics, but also lets you see through walls to track enemies

[b]Cons[/b]
- Batman walks very slowly unless youâ€™re running, or crouched (which is still faster than walking)
- I donâ€™t like combo counters. The combat feels good when you get it right, but breaking your flow is frustrating
- The Scarecrow sections are bad
- About once an hour, Batman would get stuck, or the controls stopped responding (even during a boss fight, which was especially annoying)
- The last fight before Joker with the two titan guys is a complete mess
- Once I beat that encounter (at last), it played a cutscene where Joker spikes himself with titan and his eyes open, then... suddenly I'm in an arena with an already-transformed Joker (it missed a cutscene) and he's just standing there not moving... had to restart from checkpoint again.

If you came from action games that makes you mash buttons to attack then you will spend quite some adjusting to the combat in this game. Now for the visuals, it looks good despite being released more than a decade ago. I also have a gtx 1050 but it runs well on ultra settings 1080p 60fps with the gpu usage not reaching 100% usage. The cutscenes are low quality though, but nothing an external mod could fix (didn't use one personally though)

An absolute classic. This game is the golden standart for a superhero linear action game. It was inovative when it came out and continues to surprise so many years later. The free flow style of combat created for this game became a staple of the action genre for a reson. Combat in this game feels perfect, giving you the sense of control and superiority relative to your enemies that plays into the power fantasy of the world's greatest detective. This game also (partly as a product of it's time and world) has one of the best collectathon's in gaming. Due to the linear aspect of the game, there aren't many repeated or meaningless collectibles (all of riddlers trophies feel somewhat fresh as there aren't as many as in later entries of the arkham series). This game is an absolute classic and must play for any gamer that wants to know the history of action games or is just a fan of fun and fast combat and a concise direct story. Now for some spoiler territory:
The pacing of this game is perfectly crafted, you start the game with a sense of overwhelming and crushing madness of comic's most infamous mental institution. The atmosphere and world building is an absolute work of art, creating one of the tensest and nerve wrecking experiences ever created. It fits perfectly the bat's lore and the dinamic betweeen Mark Hamil's Joker and Kevin''s (R.I.P) Batsman elevates this to a must see piece of Batman content.
Its one of the best superhero games of ALL TIME!!!!

A combination of competent combat and detailed detective abilities. A plot that draws from comic book lore and is injected with a interactive element. A voice actor list that includes Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and dozens more accomplished people. An environment that embodies the very theme of harrowing encounters and the fight for justice.

What has not been said of this title? The first of four (yes, I said FOUR) Batman games that redefined action-adventure for two generations. Though you aren't going to do doughnuts in the Batmobile and there is no grappel-boosting to be done, you are treated to a trip into the madhouse Arkham Asylum with an intelligent and impactful story that players have celebrated for years. Combine this with visuals that make you drool, a soundtrack that is alternately adrenaline-boosting and broodingly eerie no matter how many times you listen to it, and one of the best depictions of the Dark Knight, B:AA is a must buy both a full price and on a sale.

Buy it and prepare to be amazed!

The perfect comic book game. Gets everything right - from length, to combat, to atmosphere. As Rocksteady progressed, their games increasingly lost what made Arkham Asylum special. Arkham Asylum feels fully realised - every nook and cranny thoughtful, every boss encounter meaningful. The combat system was revolutionary. The sound design was perfectly comic book. Nothing felt like bloat. City gained size and scope but lost the atmosphere. Knight felt downright cinematic at times but lacked cohesion, with a plot that fizzles out and tapers before its conclusion. And so Asylum joins all the great debuts of the world - modern Prince of Persia, The Strokes' Is This It, the first Marvel Ant-Man film; great firsts only to be followed up by successors that don't really nail what made them so special. 

I still replay this game, only to hope that Rocksteady still has in it the genius to follow this up. Justice League perhaps. And perhaps one might vainly hope for a Superman game. Or even fainter, but devoutly prayed for - a Batman Beyond game.

normalize beating up the mentally ill

Good game for the first of the series. Pretty janky combat though, which can make combat encounters with multiple enemies very frustrating. Sometimes, Batman will do an animation that you did not ask him to do, and since it is not cancellable, it gives time for others enemies to attack you, which breaks the flow of combat. The best example I can give is at around 3/4 of the story, you encounter a big left 4 dead Tank like enemy along with a bunch of enemies that come in waves. During this encounter, you need to defeat the titan enemy while avoiding or fighting the smaller enemies. One of the tactics of defeating this "Titan" enemy is to dodge by double pressing the A button when the enemy charges at you, which will make the enemy hit a wall giving you time to hit it. The problem with this is that since there are so many other smaller enemies around you and that double pressing A with these smaller enemies makes batman dodge over them, instead of dodging left or right to avoid the charging big one, batman will go over one of the small ones and get hit by the titan. This was extremely frustrating to complete since this is ultimately not the fault of the player, but rather a game design issue. Batman sometimes simply does not listen to you. This was the first batman game and I heard that it gets a lot better with the next ones. I would still definitely recommend this one if you want to experience the full batman saga.

The game's graphics and game play are exceptional, offering players a chance to experience the thrill of being the Dark Knight. The fighting mechanics are fluid and engaging, allowing players to take on multiple enemies at once with ease. Additionally, the game's use of detective mode and stealth-based game play adds an extra layer of strategy to the game play.

The game's voice acting is also outstanding, featuring voice actors from the popular animated Batman series, which adds to the game's authenticity. The game's atmosphere and tone are also spot on, creating a dark and moody atmosphere that perfectly captures the feel of Batman's world.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a must-play for fans of the caped crusader and anyone who enjoys action-packed video games. The game's exceptional graphics, gameplay, and storyline make it one of the best superhero games ever made.

Despite being released over a decade ago, Batman: Arkham Asylum still holds up remarkably well compared to modern games. While some of the graphics may not be as advanced as more recent titles, the game's art style and attention to detail still make it visually impressive.

Arkham Asylum is terrific Batman game and a genuinely creepy horror game. I thank this game for creating the Freeflow combat system that most if not all super hero games use now, and for being the first in the greatest Batman game trilogy that is the Arkham Series. 

For those of you looking to pick this up just know this:
1. The story for Batman fans will be fun and engaging but for non fans could just be another Bad guy gets out you go stop him story.
2. The combat in this game can feel very clunky thanks to this being the first version of the freeflow combat system.
3.Bosses on easy and normal can be more of a chore to beat then a real challenge most being just spam quick batarangs, get to a beacon or just straight up mob fights with the boss only being a minor inconvenience. The only exception being killer croc but I'll leave that to you to find why.
But despite all of this the game is definitely worth the purchase and time.

Fuck the bane fight, sod the flak from you w ankers that say hehehe was easy. 
For the record I selected HARD... NOT 'Technically impossible.'
I played HZD on the hardest mode and that's about; 'tough in places.'

Granted, I will give it there could be something in the hardware and time gap between this game and modern systems. So, this is a brand new xbox controller on pc and i've tested it on modern games, i haven't recently become spasticated, it could very well be the software. 
It doesn't even let you do what your pressing either half the time, thats fine, its square enix and I know the style of combat they've used, so you think fine...
but then, its just so much more perverse than that, its not a matter of getting used to a dance or really being in the moment as it just doesnt work out that way.
Stunning bane with the baterang only works as a choreographed moment too, he cannot be facing away or doing literally anything else, only charging.
so after the point he is charging, throwing bricks from the wall and you try to jump about everywhere as some dudes jump in to help too, your basically done.
I went online had a look about but theres zero help because everyone says the same thing which just isnt really so.
Theres actually not many points he takes his own people down, you cannot take them out from stunned either as the game point blank refuses to, but then again you wouldn't really have the time anyway.
The same button that will allow you to escape through his legs also will evade away, which is fine, but it can also evade you right upto him from behind and check this, that gives you damage too from thin air.
So considering 3 hits and your out anyway, its not even fun.
A real shame, I quite like the B man, never played these games and now I wont.
Probably fine for the mortal kombat style geek who likes memorising a series of button presses perhaps, if thats key.
Oh also to see if i was going mad, I ran this using the best permutations a human can within reason...
I also let the controller be at different points too... that is really quite telling. you know, where if you are definitely doing the right thing, aka playing the game, and not even injured, sometimes you'll last longer if you walk out the room and let the bastard hit you, instead of pressing counter or, well anything.
So, I started doing it the same way, keeping all my health, using the tactics that worked... oh, low and behold, if doing the exact same thing and pissing around can have totally wildly different outcomes, and add that to the controls not really being controls?
well then its about much as fun as playing a gambling machine and hoping to win the jackpot.
You might get a little lucky, but most of the time your are wasting it on bull.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is an outstanding action-adventure game that perfectly captures the essence of the Caped Crusader. Developed by Rocksteady Studios and released in 2009, it features a captivating storyline, engaging gameplay, and stunning graphics that make it an unforgettable experience for any fan of the Batman franchise.

The game takes place entirely on the grounds of Arkham Asylum, Gotham City's infamous psychiatric institution. The story begins with the Joker being brought to the asylum, but it quickly becomes apparent that he has orchestrated a complex plan to take over the facility and wreak havoc on Gotham City. As Batman, you must navigate the dark and foreboding halls of Arkham, using your stealth, combat, and detective skills to foil the Joker's plans and save the day.

One of the things that sets Batman: Arkham Asylum apart from other games is the attention to detail in the environments and the characters. The asylum itself is a labyrinthine structure filled with hidden passages, secret rooms, and cleverly placed obstacles that require careful navigation and exploration. The characters are all faithfully rendered in a way that stays true to the source material, with voice acting that is top-notch across the board.

The gameplay is another area where Batman: Arkham Asylum excels. As Batman, you have access to a range of gadgets and abilities, including the iconic batarang, the grappling hook, and the ability to glide from one location to another. The combat is a fluid and satisfying blend of timed strikes, counters, and special moves that make you feel like you're really in control of the Dark Knight himself.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a fantastic game that is sure to satisfy any fan of the Batman franchise. With its engaging storyline, stunning graphics, and top-notch gameplay, it's a must-play for anyone who enjoys action-adventure games or just wants to experience the thrill of being Batman.

Batman Arkham Asylum is a masterpiece, it's such a good game. The story is simple but amazing and alongside the great voice acting from Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill and everyone else, it really elevates the game in every way. The atmosphere is soooooo good, the game captured perfectly the creepy and eerie feeling of Arkham Asylum perfectly. The game play is of course great, the free flow combat still holds up to this day and is responsible for influencing so many games. The graphics still look amazing to this day and the cut scenes make you feel like your watching a movie, there done so well. The boss fights are great and all unique especially, especially the Scarecrow sequences, holy shit they are so good, they come out of nowhere and sometimes I thought my computer was broken, some of my favourite moments in the game. The easter eggs around the games map is great, the voice tapes help build characters and the world and they can be quite creepy sometimes, riddler trophies are fun as well. I cannot express how good it is to have Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill back as there iconic roles, they are the perfect voice actors for Batman and Joker, period. Overall this was a fuckin great game that spawned one of the greatest game franchises of all time, what a great start to a series, definitely a must play.

RIP Kevin Conroy! His passing was the reason I got back into this series in memory of him and all the voice acting he did for this Batman and the Animated series, I am going to 100% all of these games in the Arkham Series no matter how long it takes.

I DEFINITELY RECOMMEND THIS GAME!!!!!

As a fan of stealth and espionage games I've always been intrigued by the Arkham series, without knowing too much about the DC universe myself. I saw the Arkham collection on offer and I'm having a great time with the first one right now. To me, it always looked vaguely similar in style to something like Manhunt with the stealth and execution elements, and this game delivers on that front, but it also offers so much more. The atmosphere and storytelling is unbelievable. I didn't know much about the universe but the character bios you unlock along the way really helped to bring me into the world. I never felt as if I was missing out on information/references etc and I felt I had known all the characters for years. I knew of Joker, Riddler and Harley but not too many others. Now I do! And I had a great time doing so

saw my dad play this when i was like 7 and cried when he got to scarecrow. Trauma aside arkham asylum is one of my most cherished games. the atmosphere of the asylum and the dark gritty look of this game is just classic batman. the stealth and action gameplay is very memorable with combat/predator rooms each feeling very unique. nowadays people think about spiderman as the best superhero game but it could be argued that the Arkham series set the standard for what a good superhero game should be. this series or maybe spiderman ps2 but yeah definitely worth a try.

The game is great, it is fantastically designed. The gameplay is really awesome and unique. A lot of games now try to steal the combat but the arkham series remains the best at it.the game's fighting is divided into two styles Head on punching and stealth. In stealth you use your gadgets and your surroundings to your advantage. like using your sonic batarang to lure your enemies to somewhere then detonating it or putting explosive gel on a wall thats about to fall down. Gadgets are also used while fighting. Like using your grappling hook to bring enemies to you. The game has a claustrophobic feel to it which is cool IMO. Riddles elevates the game, it gives it this feeling of being a detective. The story is also well written and the atmosphere is top-notch.

The genesis of everything that makes this series of games good is here. The story is solid, it introduces a lot of the familiar characters, the additional content for the most part is good and makes subsequent playthroughs more enjoyable. What makes revisiting this game difficult at times is the lack of polish this games has compared to later titles. If somebody knows of a mod that improves combat or removes the scarecrow levels let me know.

This game is a classic. Being the first Arkham game released and second chronologically, it is a blast from the past. When this game released I played it on the PS3 and decided recently to do a run through of all the Arkham games. This is one is definitely a strong entry but still not the best. The frame cap is definitely a solid no for me being in 2023. (You can uncap this by going into the files and changing the Default Engine.ini and find SmoothedMaxFrame rate) But other than frame rate this game is solid besides for buggy combat, you can feel the combat is not perfected yet much like the other entries.
Game still holds up... worth buying on sale forsure

You want to be Batman? Play this

I really enjoyed this game. It is an extremely well made Batman game, with tight controls that has a beat-em-up style with all the thugs that think they can take on the Caped Crusader! The graphics, for the time, were stunning, and still hold up. My favorite part is getting new gadgets for your tool-belt and unlocking all kinds of secrets!

One thing I found in this game is that it's pretty linear. There is not much exploring, like in future installments to this series. Sometimes, it can feel claustrophobic as you're forced through long series of hallways in the asylum. To me, however, that is how the game is supposed to feel, being in such a place as Arkham Asylum.

Whether you are a Batman connoisseur or just a casual fan of the character, you will find joy in playing this game. I recommend for anyone! 7/10.
A bit outdated compared to the other games in the series but still pretty damn good.

Batman Arkham Asylum is not only a great game by itself but also a great entry into the Arkham series and of course the Batman series itself.

While it did age worse than its siblings (mostly in the gameplay), it is still an immensely fun experience full with gothic atmosphere. 

Crazy to think that this game is about to turn 13 years old, it still holds up very well graphics-wise and especially with its story and characters. The voice-acting performance is great by everyone (no suprise here) but not only in the english apartment either. The german voice-acting f.e. is nothing to be ashamed of.

Arkham Asylum: Definitely the most grim and dark of the arkham series, but also the shortest and least polished. 
A great entry with even greater follow-ups. 

To talk about straights positives:  

Everything look-wise (characterdesigns, worlddesign and graphics)
Performance never budged
Soundtrack is great 
Gameplay is fun
Side-activitites are not too bloated (yes riddler has 240 "riddles" but they are found easily id say)

Everything more negative:

Gameplay is far more stiff than in the other entries (Id say this is a given as it is the oldest arkham game but I do want to mention it as some may want to start the series with Origins and not Asylum as it is the Chronological start)
The predator challenges are insanely buggy and glitched. It was a pain in the ass to get all maps done for the last 3 achivements.
Riddlers ending seemed a bit shallow, as if it was just tacked on (not much of a complaint but still a bummer after collecting all "riddles", again something that would be better handeled in the other titles)

Ive completed the game 100 percent in around 15 hours. It was a (mostly) fun experience.

Even though I am not a Batman, I really enjoyed this game, great story, great exploration, good enough combat. Only thing I wasn't fan of was the detective mode. Game makes you use a lot and it kind of kills the scenery of the game.
I love Batman.
It's very old and dated of course, and even on 4070Ti it still has frame drops with Physx enabled, but it still feels, sounds and plays better then Gotham Knights.

Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year, developed by Rocksteady Studios, is an exceptional game that sets a new standard for superhero video games. The game's masterful storytelling, addictive gameplay, and immersive atmosphere make it one of the best games in the Batman franchise.

The game's story, which follows Batman as he is trapped in Arkham Asylum and forced to confront his greatest enemies, is expertly crafted and well-paced. The game's voice acting and script are outstanding, with excellent performances from Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker.

The gameplay mechanics in Arkham Asylum are excellent, with a wide range of gadgets and combat techniques to master. The game's combat system, which relies on a combination of button-mashing and timing-based attacks, is intuitive and satisfying. The game's stealth mechanics are also well-implemented, allowing players to take down enemies without being detected.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year is a must-play for fans of the Batman franchise and anyone looking for an exceptional superhero game. Its masterful storytelling, addictive gameplay, and immersive atmosphere make it a standout entry in the genre.

TL;DR: Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year is an exceptional game that sets a new standard for superhero video games. Its masterful storytelling, addictive gameplay, and immersive atmosphere make it one of the best games in the Batman franchise. The combat and stealth mechanics are excellent, and the voice acting and script are outstanding. It's a must-play for fans of the franchise and anyone looking for an exceptional superhero game.

Batman Arkham Asylum is phenomenal. Considered by many a masterpiece of not only Batman media, but video games in general, this moody, dark and thrilling madhouse ride has lost none of its edge with the years. Sure, the animations aren't the best, and that batsuit looks quite, well, not good, but you can easily fix the textures with something like Asylum Reborn, which is what I used, remastering the games textures while sacrificing none of its original style and atmosphere. Speaking of which, the atmosphere of Arkham Asylum was the standout for me, a grimy, dirty, creepy atmosphere which would feel right at home in a horror game, or a movie about a haumted house, which works so fantastically well because that is precisely what Arkham Asylum is. A haunted house, a madhouse, a victorian freakshow populated by monsters, both literal and figurative, but above them all towers The Batman, stalwart as a rock, as iron of will as fist, making his way through the asylum letting them all know, very clearly, he's not locked in here with them, they're locked in here with him, and the story only compliments the whole mood. Honestly, the Batman Arkham games are possibly my favourite Batman media, they feature such fantastic storytelling, atmosphere, combat and detective work, really making you feel like you're Batman, as stoic and effective when tracking footprints and heat signatures as he is when snapping the bones of dozens of men. I love these games, I really, really do and I cannot recommend Arkham Asylum strongly enough.

I have synesthesia syndrome. In this syndrome, it is difficult to react to things around me.
I am a fan of Batman.I watched all the Batman movies since I was a kid.But not the games.I could not play because of my problem.
One day, one of my friends, who realized that I love Batman, gave me this game as a gift.
The game was difficult for me in the first few minutes.But I wanted to continue.My problem in the game was that I could not react to enemy attacks.
At that time I had two choices, to continue or not.I wanted to finish the game because Batman was one of the most popular characters in my life.My decision was to continue.I tried to make a connection between what I see and my fingers.And this became the most important goal of my life in six months.
Until today, I played the game several times on hard mode.And I could even play other games.It even made me react better in real life.So I can definitely say that Batman is my hero.

Here are several reasons to play Batman: Arkham Asylum:

Be the Batman: What's better than being the Caped Crusader himself? Live out your childhood dreams of donning the black cowl and fighting crime in the dark alleys of Gotham City.

Packed with action: You won't have time to blink before you're caught up in the next epic battle. The game's combat system is as smooth as butter and will have you delivering punches and kicks like a pro.

The villains: The asylum is packed with Batman's most infamous foes, from the Joker to Scarecrow. The boss fights are challenging and will have you on the edge of your seat.

Detective work: Batman is not just about brute force, he's also the world's greatest detective. The game has plenty of puzzles and detective work that will have you scratching your head and feeling like a genius when you solve them.

Dark and moody atmosphere: The game's setting, an eerie and creepy asylum on the outskirts of Gotham, creates the perfect backdrop for Batman's adventures.

Gadgets galore: Batman has an arsenal of gadgets at his disposal, from the Batarang to the Grapnel Gun. Using them creatively to solve puzzles and take down enemies is incredibly satisfying.

The voice acting: The game features an all-star cast of voice actors, including Mark Hamill as the Joker and Kevin Conroy as Batman. They bring their A-game to the roles and make the game a joy to listen to.

The replay value: Even after you finish the main story, there are plenty of challenges and collectibles to keep you coming back for more. Plus, you can always replay the game on a harder difficulty for an even greater challenge.

In short, Batman: Arkham Asylum is the ultimate Batman experience, packed with action, puzzles, and unforgettable villains. So don your cape and cowl, and get ready to save Gotham City!

It was good for 2009 but compared to Arkham City, it feels so unrefined and confused. It's hard not to make constant comparisons to Arkham City and makes me wish I was just playing that instead. The combat, stealth and level design all feel like a beta that laid the foundation for Arkham City, Origins and Knight. I find those games much more enjoyable to revisit. This game is still 'fun' but it's like going back to Witcher 1 instead of playing 2 and 3. I'd only recommend playing this game for the story--either if it's your first-time, if you need refresher or you're feeling nostalgic. Otherwise, just stick with City, Origins and Knight; they're much more refined and quality consistent.
good

Fights are won by punching random buttons and if that doesn't seem to work, my advise is to not waste any time and find the right button combination on the internet. Probably you missed an obscure hint at some point. For example: swish your cape with middle mouse button to astonish knife goons into staggering and double space salto over stun stick goons to give them a whiplash.

In general, if you are stuck, don't think too hard, the solution probably  doesn't make any sense and can be found on the internet.

After armor 1-4 the optional upgrades are quite useless so don't worry too much about the annoying Riddler riddles or any of the other collectibles.

The story is enjoyable, albeit a bit repetitive. The Joker keeps a good face on all his failures and make it seem you are doing exactly what he wants every step of the way. At times it makes me want to do something unexpected, sadly that just isn't part of the script.

After all this I will still recommend this game because I can't help myself, it's batman. You can't not recommend batman.

Alright, fellow Bat-fans, it's time for my review of Batman: Arkham Asylum, the game that's so good, even the Joker couldn't resist playing it.

First off, let's talk about the combat. It's like being the Dark Knight himself, punching and kicking your way through hordes of goons like they're made of cardboard. It's so satisfying that you'll feel like you've got your own utility belt of weapons, minus the batarangs and grappling hook (unless you count the upgrades, of course).

And let's not forget about the stealth. It's like playing a game of hide-and-seek, only you're the one doing the hiding and the seeking. You'll be lurking in the shadows, taking down unsuspecting thugs one by one like a ninja in a cape. And when you do get caught, it's like playing a game of tag, only instead of tagging people, you're breaking their bones.

But what really sets Arkham Asylum apart is the story. It's like playing through your very own Batman movie, with all the twists and turns you'd expect from the Caped Crusader. You'll be facing off against some of Batman's most iconic villains, from the Joker to Scarecrow to Killer Croc. And the voice acting is top-notch, with Mark Hamill's Joker stealing the show like a master thief.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a game that's sure to make you feel like you're the Dark Knight himself. It's like living out your wildest Batman fantasies, minus the billions of dollars and the tragic childhood. So if you're a fan of the Bat, or just a fan of kicking butt in general, do yourself a favor and give Arkham Asylum a try. You won't regret it, I promise.

I first played this game on 360 on launch and it blew my mind, then its sequels went and did it better. When I bought the Arkham Collection, I was worried that this one was going to be a drag compared to City and Knight, as this was my first time returning to this game; I was glad to see I was totally wrong in that assumption. Arkham Asylum is an incredible experience totally worthy of its place in the other two games of the main trilogy. That being said, if you can only afford one game in this series I would suggest getting City instead. The trilogy goes on sale all the time though, though it is totally worth the $60 price point.

For a game that's come out in 2009 it holds up quite well, only issue I had was the stealth sections were quite annoying. Mostly because guards won't see when you're flying in front of them but notice you through a pixel-wide crack on the wall when you're on the ground.

 Other than that, combos feel great and the big dude fights are enjoyable, although sometimes dodging in a direction doesn't move you forward but just makes you do a flip on the spot. There's also a bug when you have physX at high, a certain enemy's second encounter is laggy to the point of getting my 1070 down to 5 fps by the end of it.

 The game is lacking a lot of settings in the in-game menu because of it's age but you can fix almost all of those through the config files, check the PCGamingWiki website for Arkham Asylum.

this is my childhood. There are a select few games that define my childhood as much as this game, Growing up watching the Batman Animated Series and hearing Kevin Conroy's voice through the screen used to give me so much joy and euphoria. Then just a few years later I got a PS3 for Christmas and my first ever game on the console was, you guessed it, Arkham Asylum. I replayed this game in the wake of Mr. Conroy's death to not only re-live his work but to remind myself of his effect on the world and his effect on My World. So thank you Kevin and thank you to all the hard workers on this and every Arkham game.

Never really was too engaged with batman or anything dc produced, loved the dark knight trilogy but never really went into a deep dive or got excited about anything else.
AFTER BEATING THIS GAME I AM WHOLEHEARTEDLY CONVINCED BATMAN IS THE MOST FUN CHARACTER TO PLAY IN A PURELY GAME PLAY FOCUSED VIDEO GAME.
Batman is my dream, he is my main man, a true legend, you can do so much cool stuff with him ranging from stealth to hand to hand beatings and this game does both of those things expertly.
Stealth is cool, i love making traps with the boom boom foam, stringing people up and in general making people run around in freshly soiled trousers.
Combat is fun as hell, honestly at first i kinda hated it and thought it was a pain but by the time id beaten ivy near the end i was feeling like a badass beating the living daylights out of every fool that stood in my way.
The "platforming" -and i use that term lightly, cuz its sorta platforming and also sorta just general traversal- is really fun and blends well with the combat, especially love it when you are out on the surface of the island and can just zip to wherever the hell you want to be.
Its actually pretty cool how this game works, as the game progresses you unlock the different parts of the island and get new facilities to explore and kill people in, each of these areas is cluttered with the riddler puzzles, interviews (which were super cool) and all sorts of other stuff. The surface also has the collectables but also in general the openness lets you fight the enemies how you want to, say there's a big group all beating down on one dude, you don't feel like doing hand to hand so you can just find a tight area -like a flimsy metal bridge- place down a ton of explosive putty and then lead them all in, kaboom they are all dead problem solved well done.

In general, good game, love it, you should get it, currently downloading Arkham City!

This game is a masterpiece for it's time, but ultimately suffers with age in terms of gameplay. The story is excellent and the voice acting is absolutely phenomenal, of course I'm gonna mention Mark, Kevin and how perfect they are in their roles. The same praise can be said for the music, visuals and feel of the game. The only true problem this game faces is that the gameplay improvements from the later games are not present. This can be excused considering the fact that it is the first entry, so one can tolerate it. This truly was a start of an epic saga and you can feel it, the moment you enter Arkham Asylum. 

Use of the Asylum Reborn is mandatory at this point of time and moving forward.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. MUST PLAY FOR BATMAN FANS.

Dated and short, but still fun.  Stealth sections are a bit too cheesable with certain upgrades.  Counter-based combat is based, it makes getting good at hard mode feel rewarding.  Play on normal or easy first, hard removes the counter prompts which really ups the difficulty.  

100% difficulty: Medium
100% time: Short

Certain Riddler challenges can be a little confusing but with the maps the game provides you'll find them all eventually.  The side challenges are where the difficulty comes in.  The combat missions aren't so bad but you'll need to get used to critical striking instead of button mashing.  The predator missions require very specific and creative thinking, and almost require significant time spent experimenting (unless you just google certain ones like I did).

Garbage design. Good graphics. Okay story.
I suppose it was fun for the first few hours, but then it just becomes a mess, like there's no direction for the gameplay, they just threw in random things hoping it'd stick. This probably has the laziest stealth and combat I've ever seen in a game, to the point now where I'm going to use cheat engine to bypass the stealth. 
Let's start with the good though.

The graphics are pretty good for 2010 standards I think. Not vibrant but that is the style as far as I'm aware, it's bright though. The setting is really good, a change of pace for me too as I'm not into superheroes.

The story so far (42% completion as of writing), is okay. It feels cheesy at times but can also be really dark. It's a mixed bag and it will have something for everyone. But there isn't much interaction or lore about Batman, and we're reminded again of his fucking iconic 'I'm Batman' moment again. Yes we get it, his parents died, who doesn't know this? I think even my grandparents know this, this didn't need to be in the game.

But the gameplay is something else. It's awful. Everything. Combat is not only boring but unresponsive too. Like really unresponsive. In other games when I can counter something, or it says counter, I can press that and counter, regardless of the current action I'm doing, but in this game, you're locked to your current action and can't cancel it, meaning there's no mistakes. Stealth is similar here. I just got to the part where they blow up the gargoyles, and... ugh... I have to cheat this. It sucks. The stealth in this game is horrible. Especially because there's typically only one or two ways to approach it. This is as unpleasant as Shadow of Mordor's stealth which was buggy by the way. And the exploration is trash. It's so arbitrary. You need to progress through the campaign to reach previously unreachable areas. Which you won't even really visit that often. I haven't even touched the challenge mode and DLC, this is utter trash. Also the scarecrow sequences suck. I'm never a fan of timing based mechanics, and here it's really bad. The upgrades are also pointless. 

Overall I'm not having a great experience. It's really hard to enjoy this game for anything besides the story and graphics. I'm gonna go ahead and say it. Nothing here is GOTY material. Plus there's weird technical issues like this game having a pre-game launcher, and not allowing you to change difficulty mid game, and a weird bug where if you alt+tab enough times in the weird windowed fullscreen you can get by pressing alt + enter a few times, it will completely bug out your window, meaning if you have one monitor, you will have to restart your PC or pray you can navigate a Task Manager window you cannot see. WIndows 10 by the way.
There isn't a post-game at all but it's also literally one of the best stealth games ever tbh.

I should note that this game can have some mild sound issues on modern computers.  For me, the sound was sometimes muffled.  I was usually able to fix it by closing the game and relaunching it.  

That said, I found this game both fun and addictive.  In fact, it has been a while since I've enjoyed a game so much.  It's one of those pseudo- open world games that were popular in the late 00's/ early 10's.  You have an open  central hub area that  links to multiple areas that have a more linear layout.  In following the plot, you are also visiting the different buildings in Arkham Asylum.  

The combat was easy to learn and also fun.  I never really felt frustrated while playing this game.  Needless to say, I'm looking forward to starting Arkham City next.

Out of all of the Batman: Arkham series, this one has the best atmosphere in my opinion. It feels like I'm playing the comic book at every turn! In terms of controls and gameplay... well, I know saying "This game makes you FEEL like Batman" is super-cliche at this point, but everyone who's ever said that is completely right.

Bringing back Mark Hamill's Joker & Kevin Conroy's Batman as voice actors was an undeniable stroke of genius! They were great in the Animated Series, and they're great here! Yes, Heath Ledger was the definitive live-action Joker, but Mark Hamill will always be the definitive voice of the Joker to me, and the way Conroy & Hamill play off of each other never gets old!

The graphics aren't unbelievably perfect, but they're great enough that I don't think a remaster will ever truly be necessary. In particular, the effects on Batman's cape were & are FANTASTIC! Rocksteady could have easily screwed up on the cape animations, but they didn't, Batman's cape looks perfect. The surrounding environment still holds up really well, everything looks realistic enough to be sure, but I do have exactly one problem: Detective Mode. Chances are you will very quickly figure out that Detective Mode will help you notice secrets like Riddler Trophies, Tapes & Puzzle Solutions that you would otherwise have walked past without noticing those things were even there in the first place and if you're anything like me you will quickly develop a habit of just leaving Detective Mode on at all times. This is a good thing because it helps you find stuff, but it is also bad graphically because everything will have a blue filter over it that turns all of the bad guys into skeletons, and you'll lost many of the pretty little textures everywhere. Basically, try to remember to turn Detective Mode OFF and enjoy the scenery a little & enjoy the graphics, somewhat dated though they may be.

As for everything else, the story is fantastic, the animations are what they should be everything's awesome and if you're reading this and somehow haven't played Batman: Arkham Asylum yet, what are you waiting for?? Play this as soon as you can! It's a masterpiece! Don't hesitate for another instant! Play it!!

As you can clearly observe from my profile, I've literally "completed" the game and obtained all the unlockable achievements. As such, I found it sensible to share my  personal review of the cult classic above and express the genuine admiration I feel towards it.
Additionally, I've also "platinumed" the remastered version of the game on PS4 so I will draw some small comparisons for those indecisive about the primary platform they prefer to experience the masterpiece on.
Also, this'll probably turn out to be a fairly long and discursive discourse so proceed at your own discretion.

[b] Personal Attachment [/b] :
Before I delve into an actual "review" of the product, I'd like to elaborate a bit on the special place it occupies in the depths of both my memory, and heart:
It was 2009.
The 9 year old me had only just finally convinced my hard-going father to buy me an XBOX 360 as a reward for my then outstanding elementary school performance (Just your typical Asian family stuff). Upon the purchase of the console, as I was inspecting the store shelves, scanning the innumerable glowing cases of green which I was yet to own a sample of, my eyes drifted toward the portrait of a familiar tenebrous character that stood out menacingly among all the other present promotional artworks.
It was the same caped crusader I grew up watching a highly praised animated show of;
the very same "Dark Knight" I'd watched a recent Hollywood adaptation of;
It was the ultimate embodiment of [i] vengeance [/i]
It was a veiled creature of the [i] night [/i]
That is correct, it was [i] BATMAN [/i] !

Spare me the cringe.

Regardless, I instantly knew I'd decided upon the game I was gonna pick for my then new console.
A decision which ultimately booked me an exclusive ticket to the sumptuous festival that was to be held at the notorious mad clown's renovated amusement park: the [i] Arkham Asylum [/i] !
And boy if it didn't turn out to be a hell of a roller coaster ride.

Admittedly though, upon my first attempt at the title, I failed to play it to completion. Perhaps the mechanics were a tad too sophisticated for the [i] minor [/i] me and my frail understanding of the English language didn't exactly help with my progression (FYI English is not my primary language, so incidentally, pardon any possible errors that may occur in my composition).
Regardless, I dropped the game and didn't pick it back up until shortly after the release of Arkham City. Having grown at least a few years older, with improved knowledge around the "foreign language", I decided to give the first entry another go and consequently, finished it for the first time before jumping to the highly acclaimed sequel.

A few years later, a console-exclusive remaster of the first two classics was announced to be hitting the shelves. Of course, being the avid â€œGothamiteâ€ that I am, there was no hesitation on my part to purchase, play and "Platinum" the game on my PS4.
When I finally converted to the "PC master race" and came across a generous discount of the game during the steam holiday sale, I couldn't fight the urge to buy, play and complete the game once again. Which brings me to the next point:

[b] TECHNICAL ASPECTS (WITH COMPARISONS) [/b] :
The PC experience, despite the slightly muddier textures and somewhat lower-resolution cutscenes, easily manages to hold its own against the fully remastered variants.
The [i]con[/i] -sole versions are capped at 30 fps (unless you insert the unpatched physical disc into a 9th gen console), a limitation which imposes a significant hindrance on the overall fluidity of the gameplay.
These remasters are also mostly recognizable for employing a sharper, more vibrant color tone which in my humble opinion takes away from the intended dark, eerie atmosphere of the game and the asylum. The only departments in which the console alternatives maintain an upper hand are clearer textures, 1080p cutscenes (which are still pre-rendered with a noticeably low bitrate) and the addition of precipitation. And admittedly, the rain effect truly does make the outdoor environment of the game look a whole generation apart from the classics.
But with the addition of multiple modification packs available for the game on PC, notably Asylum Reborn, along with 4K upscaled cutscenes that are downloadable separately, the 13 year old PC version of the title is beyond capable at delivering a satisfactory visual performance.

[b] NARRATIVE EXPERIENCE [/b]
This is probably one of the rare instances in which the game doesn't seem to utilize its full potential. The story doesn't exactly offer anything too deep or emotionally engaging and instead presents you with the usual, ever-recurrent, Tom & Jerry-esque trope of "Batman chasing Joker to stop his sinister scheme". But the mere atmosphere of the asylum, the detail and attention put into the making of it and the pure thrill and joy that is derived from exploring it, more than make up for the clichÃ© plot that's still relatively fun to follow.
The small yet boisterous selection of the rogue gallery who are admitted to the asylum, each get their own tumultuous time to shine and a renowned few who donâ€™t make the cut are cleverly referenced or alluded to -invoking speculations on future possibilities.
Not to disregard the single ingredient that truly brings out the long-lasting flavor of this palette-numbing haute cuisine: the invaluable inclusion of the holy trinity of all non-live-action Batman media: Arleen Sorkin, Mark Hamill and the late Kevin Conroy, who are respectively known for reprising, and literally defining, the roles of Harley Quinn, Joker and Batman ever since the 1992 animated series. It is inarguable that their performance as the said characters was so iconic and definitive that to this day, the successors resort to imitating their irreplaceable predecessors.

[b] GAMEPLAY AND LEVEL DESIGN [/b]
The gameplay is that part of the game that keeps pulling me back to it. Simply put, it's diverse, versatile, innovative and downright addictive. The combat system and the satisfaction of countering the enemy's attacks while returning them with acrobatic critical blows was absolutely unrivaled at its time and I daresay set the bar for later games that followed. The extensive upgrade system and gadgets that allow for strategic and creative takedowns are also an absolute joy to play around with.
The enemy variety and the assignment of specific fighting methods to particular variants is also a delightful challenge that keeps your head-cogs turning even through the seemingly generic fist-fights.
The Riddler challenges and collectibles are a side-segment of the game that could actually take more time to beat than the main story mode. (That is of course in case like myself, you refrain from looking up guides and walkthroughs online and prefer to rely on your own cognitive abilities instead.) But that eventual relieving moment of satisfaction and confidence-induction when you finally manage to solve a perplexing riddle or find a way to reach the cleverly concealed trophy is truly worth the hassle.
There also exist some supplementary "secrets" to be discovered which even further accentuate the spectral ambience that permeates the virulent air of the wacko-infested islet.

[b] CONCLUSION [/b]
Conclusively, despite the simple plot and lower-poly character models, the game has maintained its once-revolutionary brilliance and still manages to cast the same bewitching spell that charmed its players 13 years ago.
Rocksteadyâ€™s first Batman simulator is not just your ordinary action superhero video game. It is an immersive experience that allows the player to truly capture the surreal sensation of gliding through a mystifying realm of madness under the cowl of Gothamâ€™s greatest detective.
So whether you are yet to experience the game, or merely wish to reminisce the memories you made playing it, the title is definitely worth your purchase in 2023.

For not knowing what a beat-em-up is before playing this game, I have to say this one is solid. Keep in mind, it's an older title and the first in a series. On occasion there's a clearly missed counter window that wasn't your fault, but how the game is programmed etc. But the feeling of flying from enemy to enemy, only slowing down to watch a takedown animation so you can plan your next three moves? Feels awesome. Playing on mouse and being able to quickly take things in makes this even better. Once you reach a certain level of play the gadgets feel a bit extraneous, as in they may not directly benefit you all the time. You may find yourself cycling through only a couple moves in harder challenges rather than your full gear set. Titans (while infrequent) also break the flow of combat by majority badly, as they ignore standard enemy attack rotation and also only have moves that go through other enemies. Boss battles feel a tad gimmicky in comparison to the regular flow of combat, or say difficult fights in Arkham City (which flow really well with the base combat system).

Stealth sections offer a lot, if not more creativity, than your standard combat section (though there is no bonuses to using your extra gadgets). Hard mode does not make them much more difficult, though that could be due to personal progression rather than game difficulty.

The environments are cool, foreboding even, the music is right on pace with it, and the story and extended lore is of course based in the comics, but provides enough twists and turns to be relatively unpredictable. This game *really* does make you feel like Batman. Small issue which does transfer to the other games, not using the cowl feels like a detriment in exploration sections. Which sucks, because it makes the environment colors go away almost entirely. As I get better and memorize where encounters take place in later playthroughs I feel more confident in leaving it off in some sections, but the amount of information the cowl provides makes it feel necessary to have.

Progression feels nicely tuned, getting a full kit in one playthrough without revisiting sections for Riddler trophies is entirely possible if you earn enough XP in combat sections.

Sum total, this game is an excellent introduction to the Arkham series due to its more limited gadget palette, but entirely good enough as a standalone playthrough as well.

Loved my time with this game, having just experienced it for the first time in the new year, 2023. I had tried out Arkham Knight some years back on a PS4, but found it to be pretty challenging, with the learning curve being a bit steep there. This first game in the series though is an excellent introduction to the combat system that kept getting more refined as later titles in the series were made. 

The game has aged very well, still looks great today. It's a very immersive experience, the camera usually positioned just over Batman's shoulder (though kindly zooming out a bit for the brawler type combat sections). The 'free-flow' combat system, even this early on, has quite a bit of depth to it, making full use of all four face buttons, as well as both shoulder buttons. While this first game is still winnable via button mashing, the player is potentially rewarded with far more experience as well as greater damage output for timing each and every button press more precisely. One button for basic melee punch/kick, one button for countering, one for stunning, and one for evasion... with the shoulder buttons used for a couple of combat friendly gadgets.

The stealth sections were my favorites, requiring a lot more thought and strategy, as opposed to merely quick reflexes and skill. Many of the boss battles were a let-down, sadly, many of them being repeats or reskins of the same enemy. But there are at least a couple highlights as well.

For those that like adventuring and exploring, the Asylum presents the player with one big open 'sandbox' to explore, including many areas to return to once you've got the gadget required to access them. The Riddler's riddles and trophies serve as the main 'collectibles' here, as well as interview tapes between doctors and inmates (by far my favorite thing to collect), giving the player more insight into how some of Batman's most iconic villains think. 

All in all, a really immersive, fun introduction to the Arkham franchise. I look forward to playing the next one (I got all three games in a package deal for $12 CDN... don't pay $80 for the trilogy, wait for a sale).

I've been playing this game on and off for almost 10 months now. The story's good enough for what it's supposed to be,  though I honestly can't remember most of it due to playing in between long periods of pauses. The game is starting to look dated, but that's a given since it's been over a decade since it's initial release. 

What I really want to bring to attention is the combat. It's a good balance between being just easy enough for an average person, but also providing a bit more variety and freedom for those who want something more challenging. You [i] can [/i] try to button mash, although it won't always end favorably. Once you actually try to get a hang of the mechanics, mob fights tend to get a little easier. Even if you don't know what you're pressing, you can still pass albeit with a bit of luck. Most of my playtime is with a controller (Xbox Series & Logitech F710), but K&M works just fine.

Stealth play is really enjoyable! Once you get your full arsenal of items and weapons, the number of ways you can take down enemies is great. You'll be able to try most of these in the challenge mode, but also gradually learn as the main story progresses. I can't be bothered to finish the challenges as I've already been on this game for way too long. Maybe someday I'll get back to it but for now I'm satisfied with what I've completed.

If you really want to play a superhero game and your PC isn't strong enough to handle the newer titles, this is a good place to start. I give this a a thumbs-up!
