Got theses all the Arkham games on sale and I'm going through them for the first time since the 360 days and all I can say is do yourself a favour and play these games if you haven't as they've all aged like fine wine!

From a constant stream of lackluster and dissapointing game releases nowadays, going back to these games has honestly been such a good sense of fresh air.

Every single main game from "Batman: Arkham" series is great on its own and you should give them a chance, even if you don't know or don't care about Batman or DC games or super hero games overall. 
"Batman: Arkham" series is just that good. Each one of those games are similar in term of core mechanics but they have own personal pros and cons making them unique from each other with no way of picking "the best one" out of all of them:



===============================================



â˜†Batman: Arkham Asylum

Pros:

+spooky and chill atmosphere of crazy asylum

+everything Scarecrow related

+not "too scary" but "ok" amount of collectibles and puzzles (collectibles that give you both experience points, healing, challenge maps and bonus in game content)

+very entertaining "Joker" DLC (only available on other platforms than PC but there is way to mod it in on PC) 

+rest of DLC's challenge maps is alright too

+not many of them but bosses and mini-boss fights are good enough for the first game in the series, I have nothing to complain about here



Cons:

-the smallest and least dense map out of all Arkham games in term of side content

-the weakest combat out of all Arkham games because of slowest animations ever, least amount of combat gadgets and least amount of ways to take down people

-predator sections feels a bit too slow with not enough ways to take down goons after playing other Arkham games 

-zero side activities beside collectibles which are not even that cleverly hidden

-no fun Riddler puzzles that require gadgets to solve

-very small amount of unique challenge maps



===============================================



â˜†Batman: Arkham City

Pros:

+bigger and more dense map than in Arkham Asylum

+improved roaming, gliding and exploration

+more NPC's to interact with

+way, way better and way more boss fights and mini-boss fights 

+extra fun side missions

+way more good and unique challenge maps and unlockable bonus content

+4 unique playable characters and lots of extra skins

+Catwoman mini story DLC was ok



Cons:

-story and motivations of few characters in this game are the least coherent out of all Arkham games

-side missions "Acts of Violence", "Cold Call Killer", "Identity Theft", "Shot in the Dark", "Watcher in the Wings" are often hard to progress on your own without a guide because the game expects you to just randomly find very specific locations and characters while traveling across the map

-Harley Quinn's Revenge was garbage DLC with no interesting mechanics, ideas, boss fights, story or gimmicks



===============================================



â˜†Batman: Arkham Origins

Pros:

+not only bigger and better map but also snowy

+both story and overall dialogue is the most entertaining and engaging out of all Arkham games

+new Remote Claw gadget (that replaces Line Launcher) is very fun to use and allows you to do for way more stuff than crappy Line Launcher. Not only more utility in both combat and predator but also in exploration. Screw Line Launcher - Remote Claw all day all night, BABY!

+Electric gloves aka Batman's Devil Trigger are way too fun in use

+even more unique and better boss and mini-boss fights. Hands down the best out of all Arkham games

+fast travel

+better ranking system encouraging you to fight better for more bonus experience points

+enhanced detective mode and lots of special missions using it

+you are not fighting only prisoners for a change but also corrupted cops

+even more unique side missions

+not as many challenge maps as in Arkham City but still a lot

+3 unique playable characters on challenge maps

+multiplayer mode (its kinda dead at this point but overall quality and gameplay of this mode was very good and fun)

+both "Cold, Cold Heart" and "Initiation" DLC's are very, very good



Cons:

-definitely the most glitchy out of all Arkham games, yet nothing game breaking like crashes or anything that would cause Game Over or corrupted saves or progression block

-few examples of bugs: sometimes you will just miss, get hit or lose combo for no reason or due hitboxes nearby walls, sometimes the room or texture may no load correctly (restart fixes that), there that one floor in open world that loads way too long so you can clip thru it and fall down into water but you never need to go there, that goofy "the dark room" in "Cold, Cold Heart"...

-very weird facial animations during character conversations during in game cutscenes, mostly noticeable while talking to Alfred



===============================================



â˜†Batman: Arkham Knight 

Pros:

+not only bigger and better map but also rainy

+Batmobile gameplay (driving around, puzzles, combat, pursuit, racing sections) is just WAY too fun

+Batmobile may be the most smooth and responsive controlled ground vehicle I had ever used over the past 30 years of my gaming life

+finally Batman can chill out inside a police station

+graphically the best out of all Arkham games with even more animations and extra details

+Arkham Knight was a really flesh out and entertaining character, despite (sadly) not being on screen very often 

+character that appears during [spoiler]hallucinations[/spoiler] later in the game is definitely the most hilarious part of this game (no, I am not talking about [spoiler] Batman or Arkham Knight [/spoiler])

+each previous Arkham game had a very good end game sequence but Arkham Knight end game sequence is just amazing

+huge number of collectibles and stuff to do 

+lots of side quests and side activities, good DLC's

+8 playable characters in challenge maps

+overall the biggest amount of in-game content out of all Arkham games



Cons:

-a proper final boss fight is replaced by a set piece for some reason. Its a good set piece but I would rather have another Joker Titan boss instead.

-detective aspect of Batman Arkham games is basically and completely gone here

-repeating some races and other challenges is really annoying just because you have to spend few extra minutes to go back to previous point. Was that hard to implement quick restart prompt?

-the game is constantly hammering you hints for the simplest in-game puzzles every few seconds like the the target audience of this M rated game and long Arkham franchise fans was 8 year olds BUT funny enough the game doesn't tell you where to find Freeze Blast gadget at all so its easy to miss

-some people may find this game way too big or overwhelming due amount of content, collectibles or batmobile sections (even tho I had no issue with it and Arkham City had had way more filler collectibles so its funny people complain about it in Arkham Knight)

-after fantastic amount of enemies and bosses in Origins.....this game decided for 10 steps back and just not bother with that at freaking all. 
Knight have weaker boss and mini-boss fights than previous City and Origins. 
Don't get me wrong: bosses in Arkham Knight are still good, fun and unique on their own but the game could do a way better job at their variety and number, especially after so many of amazing boss fights of Arkham City and Arkham Origins.
Heck, Batman: Arkham Knight had so many moments when you think you are gonna fight a boss, especially at the end of each side quest, and then...........nothing. 
Big nothing. A cutscene where you punch a villain and its over. Garbage!

I'm recommending this game as a Batman fan. Hearing the late Kevin Conroy as Batman (RIP Kevin) and the fantastic Mark Hamill as the Joker it's almost like watching (and playing) a playable Batman: The Animated Series episode.

But my god is the combat very stiff and I mean stiff -- I mean outdated; while it was 'okay' for it's time. This game really wants to drive home just how important the combo/counter system is and while it does help you; if you are in the middle of a take down chances are the counter will register or will not most of the time leaving you frustrated or how the room can quickly fill up with enemies, armed enemies, tanking enemies soo quickly you barely have any time to take down literally anyone unless you take them down via the ol' one two punch aka it takes about 30 hits on normal (No seriously that's how outdated it is). Thankfully it's sequels corrected this mistake; I mean I get it- it's Batman. But this isn't a playable movie for fuck sake -- one two maybe a flashy combo move and done. None of this got to beat them to 'death' lolol.

The audio work, visuals, and just exploring the iconic Arkham Asylum is still a treat to be had! That goes double for the riddle trophies and hey! There's actually a challenge mode where it lets you be either as Batman or the Joker and you fight wave of goons or Arkham Security forces. OOOR do these challenging silent takedown ones and as each time you progress through these challenges they become harder and harder forcing you to really strategize and adapt to your tools, tech and surroundings. 

Whether it be on sale or current full price of $19.99 if you can stomach the stiff combat, and the aggressiveness usage of combo/counter system then it's a pretty good experience.

Beat baddies as Batman
Instant classic and a real game changer.

The titans arent very fun to fight against, they could be stunned on the ground and inputting an attack towards their direction will just have Batman punch in the air instead of leaping over and landing a blow. Like bro I just want to keep my score multiplier.

Core combat is fun and simple, but there are a very few "wtf" moments like ground takedowns not working, some attacks animations being really slow, and hitting two henchmen at once (pretty sure that was intentional but its slightly annoying). But besides those hiccups I loved it. It's just a shame the game doesn't get crazy and throw diverse enemies all at once. Imagine if they put you in a room with lunatics, knife-guys, some standard henchmen, and a titan that appears at the end? That'd be wicked. The game definitely does experiment with its mechanics, i just wish they couldve done something more spicy.

Challenge maps are really really easy. 3 stars are given out to you like candy and you have a whole 4 rounds to do so in the combat ones. I feel like the predator challenge maps shine the most because it provides players with challenges that spark new ideas of interesting and fun gadget use. I didn't even know I could use the line launcher to kick a henchman off the railways and knock him out, that stuff is insanely fun to learn and do.

The atmosphere is hands down one of the best I've seen in gaming history. Whilst keeping the setting of an Asylum, Rocksteady managed to diversify the scenery. The gardens, the hospital, the mansion, all of these locations just ooze personality and is such a visual treat that still holds up to this day. 

I've loved the Arkham quadrilogy, and this game is definitely my 2nd favorite. Mostly for its setting and comic book artstyle.

by the way, the final boss was kind of lame

After sitting in my library for about 12 years, I finally got around to finishing this game.

It's not bad.  It has aged fairly decently and plays as an old Assassin's Creed clone from stealth to combat except with the Batman twist.  Graphically it hasn't aged that greatly but it still looks good at the same time.  Outside is something like 64 shades of green and indoors it doesn't feel super realistic with some pretty huge ventilation shafts.

All in all, I feel comfortable recommending it as a game and I definitely recommend it if you crave a dose of Batman in  your life.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is an incredibly fun action-adventure game that takes place in the iconic Arkham Asylum. 

Players take on the role of Batman as he attempts to stop his nemesis, the Joker, from taking over the asylum and wreaking havoc on Gotham City. 

The game features a variety of puzzles, combat, and exploration elements that make it an enjoyable experience for fans of the Batman franchise (new and old). 

The graphics compliment the environments nicely, making them appear detailed and full of life! However, much like relationships, looks aren't everything! So, I'm happy to report that the free flow combat system is equally amazing! Boasting a wide range of skills and gadgets for the caped crusader to utilize on his journey to dispense justice, the combat in the game hardly ever stagnates! You can string together crazy combos, each differing from the last (if you so choose), while taking down endless hoards of enemies. But, if you prefer a more stealthy approach, the game has also got you covered with tactical scenarios that will force you to think on the fly. 

The puzzles are challenging but not overly difficult, making them somewhat enjoyable for all levels of players; And the inclusion of lore/storytelling helps to make the hunt for the game's collectibles worth while.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is an excellent game that fans of the franchise will love. It has great graphics, thrilling gameplay, and an engaging story that will keep you coming back for more! If you're looking for a great action-adventure game with plenty of puzzles and combat elements, then this is definitely one to check out!

Overall a great action game in third person with stealth elements.
Swinging around hiding in the shadows and picking the goons off one by one and seeing their panic meter go up is great fun.
I won't dissect the combat system since that's probably the most famous part of this series and everyone knows about it. I'll just say feels good and Batman feels like Batman. The boss battles are good but can get a bit repetitive since many elements are reused throughout the game.
The style of the game is what I'd describe as gritty comic-book style. Overall the art direction with its dark, gothic atmosphere is fantastic. The locations are as diverse as you could make them without it feeling out of place.
Most of the characters are great looking although this is probably my biggest gripe with the game on a couple of levels. Firstly the variety of the goons is too small. They all look almost the same. Secondly, I just didn't like the over-the-top muscles. In my taste, it's fine to have some comic-book-style muscles here and there, but in this game every inmate in this insane asylum is about as ripped as Schwarzenegger in his prime. It gets a bit ridiculous and takes away some of the grittiness of the presentation. The supervillains were all fantastic.
The script is well written for the medium and over-the-top in a charming way. The voice acting is phenomenal. Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill are on top of their game. Both bring the game a fantastic Batman Animated vibe. Hamill will always be the best comic-like interpretation of the Joker for me and Conroy's voice simply IS Batman for me. Arleen Sorkin as always does a great Harley Quinn. Her delivery of "Bye-bye Batman" at the death screen is just great. I could go on about the voice actors because every one of them is amazing. Tom Kane and Wally Wingert are also great, alright I'll knock it off.
Finally, this is a game that actually got collecting stuff fun. There are a couple of reasons for this. Many of the collectibles give you backstories to the asylum and its inmates, some familiar that you don't meet. It's great fun seeing how the different villain's cells look. It also makes the game a bit of a metriodvania in that you need to backtrack to get many of the collectibles. But since the map isn't too big and the puzzles aren't too convoluted it makes backtracking to collect stuff feels like you're mastering the game instead of tedious busy work like many other games. There are few games that I spend the time collecting everything but this is one of them.

Overall great game. I recommend it.

I am a 55 yo father. I am a single father to my Son, who is 20 now. I gift my son this game for his birthday, then he installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Still good. It's a lot slower and much goofier than I remember compared to when I was ten, and most jarringly itâ€™s a lot more shallow (in regards to character arcs, gadget design, boss fights etc., nothing that hasnâ€™t been said a million times before, all of which is alleviated in its sequels), but the atmosphere and vibes are still dope owing a lot to the soundtrack and art design. It also still looks SO good graphically it's almost absurd. For a first attempt as revolutionary as this was Iâ€™d say it has aged quite well. 

I also got 100% in this which means collecting all Riddler trophies and completing all combat/stealth challenges, which was pretty chill to do while just listening to a podcast, although the Riddler challenges are pretty monotonous and thrown about with little thought, and the combat and stealth challenges are fun despite bringing to light some of the limitations of both systems in this first iteration of them.

"Sands of Time Clone #51: Now You Can Spam Y And Win" is in tough competition with Skyrim for the most over-rated game ever. Batman has never been so uncool, so clumsy, so [i]solid[/i]. Isn't this guy supposed to be a ninja? Striking fear into criminals with mind-games and illusions, or something? And here you are just punching them in the face like a caveman. So much for that 'wonderful combat system'. Also apparently there's a story, but it's so bloated with 'iconic villains' that it's not worth following. In fact, it's not so much 'iconic' as  'idolatrous': worshipping name- and brand-recognition over a substantial narrative. "It's based on a comic book" reads increasingly as an excuse than a description these days.

ONE OF THE BEST BATMAN GAME!!
great action adventure with a nice combat flow

If you want to get this game, here are a few things to know first (no spoilers of course);

You don't need to have played any other game before,
This game doesn't require you to have played any other Arkham game to understand the story, all you need is a slight understanding of the characters but even then there is a character information tab for each character in the game.

Although its an old game, its still really good.
Its age does not effect how good this game is, although the cutscenes are a bit old looking the game overall is still really good for its age.

The stealth and fighting in game is interesting.
Usually i don't like stealth in games however in this game it is rather enjoyable. At times it can be frustrating but after you get use to how the stealth works it is fun. The fighting in the game is mainly close range combat but there is a really cool countering and dodging techniques.

Overall the game is really good and i personally would give it 8/10. Its atmosphere is amazing which really pushes up its points for me. I have not yet played any other Batman Arkham game yet but once i do i might compare the games.
Thanks for reading

Thursday, October 31st. The city streets are crowded for the holiday. Even with the rain. Hidden in the chaos is the element, waiting to strike like snakes. And I'm there too. Watching. 2 years of nights have turned me into a nocturnal animal. I must choose my targets carefully. It's a big city. I can't be everywhere. But they don't know where I am. We have a signal now, for when I'm needed. When that light hits the sky, it's not just a call- it's a warning. To them. Fear is a tool. They think I'm hiding in the shadows. But I AM the shadows. I wish I could say I'm making a difference, but I don't know. Murder, robberies, assault- 2 years later, they're all up. And now this. This city's eating itself. Maybe it can't be saved, but I have to try. PUSH MYSELF. These nights all roll together in a rush, behind the mask. Sometimes in the morning I have to force myself to remember everything that happened.

Love the Batman Arkham series so here is my review for the first game. Beware of potential spoilers please. 

STORY: It is like a comic book that is alive. It is fun, interesting and really makes you feel like you are Batman. Its not the strongest in the series but oh man, I just love it. Villains are great, there is a very very cool game twist that you will love ( and be very confused at first!) Voice acting is on point, dialogue is so funny at times. Plus the atmosphere is so gothic, you get very drawn into the world.

GAMEPLAY: A bit rough, fighting big gangs of thugs and those Titan bosses was a mess sometimes. I died so many times because I would get cornered and then get ran over by a Titan boss. Not many options for combos and gadgets are not used much in combat (this gets improved on in the next few games). I did have an issue trying to download the game, I had to download some kind of installer to make it run on my PC. If you have this issue, I suggest Youtube, that helped me.

GRAPHICS: Textures look good. Character design, hmmmmmmmm. Why is everyone so ugly. The face modeling was definitely the weakest in this game. 

VERDICT: This is an older game but it is soooo good. I just love it and I think you will enjoy it too. :) Ignore the ugly characters and have fun playing it, it is very creative with its story and gameplay.
